For best success, watch the video tutorial, read the post, and review the recipe before beginning.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "apples, caramel", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/caramel-apples-3-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/caramel-apples-3-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/caramel-apples-3-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/caramel-apples-3.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-caramel-apples/", "recipeIngredient": ["8-9 cold apples", "1 and 3/4 cups (420ml) heavy cream", "1 cup (240ml) light corn syrup", "2 cups (400g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1/4 cup (4 Tbsp; 56g) unsalted butter, at room temperature", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Rinse the apples with water, then wipe completely dry. Removing the slippery waxy coating will help the caramel seal to the apple. Remove the apple stem and insert a caramel apple stick about 3/4 down into the apple.", "name": "Prep the apples:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-caramel-apples/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Line a large baking sheet with a silicone baking mat (preferred) or grease the pan with butter. Caramel usually sticks to parchment or wax paper.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-caramel-apples/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Combine the heavy cream, corn syrup, brown sugar, butter, and salt in a 3-quart heavy-duty saucepan over medium heat. Do not turn the temperature up or down\u2014keep at medium the entire time the caramel cooks. Stir constantly with a wooden spoon until the butter is melted. Once melted, brush down the sides of the pan with a water-moistened pastry brush and attach a candy thermometer to the pan, making sure the bulb is not touching the bottom of the pan (as you&#8217;ll get an inaccurate reading).", "name": "Make the caramel", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-caramel-apples/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Without stirring, let the mixture cook and bubble until it reaches 235\u00b0F (113\u00b0C). Some readers have been cooking to 240\u00b0F (116\u00b0C) and saying the caramel sticks much better to the apples that way. Stick with anywhere between 235\u00b0F &#8211; 240\u00b0F. Reaching this temperature should take about 15 &#8211; 20 minutes, though don&#8217;t use time as your guide because it depends on your stove. Don&#8217;t be alarmed if your caramel is taking longer, just use the candy thermometer as your guide. The temperature will heat up slowly, then move quickly, so keep your eye on the pot. Once at 235\u00b0F &#8211; 240\u00b0F, remove caramel from heat and stir in the vanilla. Avoid over-stirring which can create air bubbles in the caramel (and then on the apple). Allow caramel to cool for 10-15 minutes until slightly thickened. If caramel is too thin to coat apples, let it cool and thicken for 5-10 minutes longer.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-caramel-apples/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Holding the caramel apple stick, dip the apple into the warm caramel, tilting the pot as needed to coat all sides of the apple. Lift the apple up and swirl it around or gently tap it against the side of the pot to let excess caramel drip off. Place coated apple on prepared pan. Repeat with remaining apples. Enjoy immediately or allow caramel to set, about 45-60 minutes. If you want to wrap the caramel apples in cellophane treat bags for travel/gifting, wait until the caramel has completely set.", "name": "Dip the apples", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-caramel-apples/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If desired, you can add toppings. Immediately after coating in caramel and before the caramel sets, roll the caramel dipped apples in finely chopped nuts, toffee pieces, mini M&amp;Ms, sprinkles, or coconut. You can even drizzle with melted chocolate or white chocolate, too.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-caramel-apples/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "For displaying or serving, I recommend placing on wax paper or another nonstick surface. Even when the caramel has completely set, caramel apples may slightly stick to a serving dish. To eat a caramel apple, you can bite right into it or sit it upright on a cutting board and cut slices around the stick. (Or pull out the stick and slice.) These are great for sharing!", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-caramel-apples/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Loosely cover and store the leftover dipped apples in the refrigerator for up to 1 week.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-caramel-apples/#instruction-step-8"}], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT15M", "totalTime": "PT1H15M", "recipeYield": ["8", "8-9 caramel apples"], "recipeCategory": "Candy", "cookingMethod": "Cooking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "79", "ratingValue": "4.5"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Homemade Caramel Apples | Sally's Baking Recipes", "description": "Learn how to make real homemade caramel apples with this from-scratch recipe. It's supremely moist with a soft fluffy crumb and intense coconut flavor. For success, follow this recipe carefully including using cake flour, egg whites, sour cream, and canned coconut milk.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "cake, coconut cake, coconut", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/coconut-cake-5-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/coconut-cake-5-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/coconut-cake-5-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/coconut-cake-5.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/coconut-cake/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 and 1/2 cups (285g) cake flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "2 teaspoons baking powder", "1/2 teaspoon baking soda", "1 teaspoon salt", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 and 2/3 cups (330g) granulated sugar", "5 large egg whites, at room temperature", "1/2 cup (120g) sour cream, at room temperature", "2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1 teaspoon coconut extract", "1 cup (226g/240ml) unsweetened canned coconut milk, at room temperature*", "1 cup (80g) sweetened shredded coconut", "1 cup (16 Tbsp; 226g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "8 ounces (226g) full-fat brick cream cheese,\u00a0softened to room temperature*", "5 cups (600g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "2 Tablespoons (30ml) canned coconut milk", "1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1/2 teaspoon coconut extract", "1/8 teaspoon salt", "2 cups (160g) sweetened shredded coconut"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Grease three 8-inch cake pans, line with parchment paper rounds, then grease the parchment paper. Parchment paper helps the cakes seamlessly release from the pans. (If it&#8217;s helpful, see this parchment paper rounds for cakes video &amp; post.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/coconut-cake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the cake flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt together. Set aside.", "name": "Make the cake:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/coconut-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on medium-high speed until smooth and creamy, about 2 minutes. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a rubber spatula as needed. Beat in the egg whites until combined, then add the sour cream, vanilla extract, and coconut extract. Beat until combined. Mixture will look curdled as a result of the varying textures and solid butter combining. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. With the mixer on low speed, slowly add the dry ingredients and coconut milk. Beat on low speed until combined, then add the shredded coconut. Whisk it all by hand to make sure there are no butter lumps at the bottom of the bowl. The batter will be slightly thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/coconut-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour batter evenly into cake pans. Weigh them to ensure accuracy, if desired. Bake for 21\u201324 minutes or until the cakes are baked through. To test for doneness, insert a toothpick into the center of the cake. If it comes out clean, it&#8217;s done. Allow cakes to cool in the pans set on a cooling rack for 1 hour, then remove from the pans and place the cakes directly on the rack to continue cooling. The cakes must be completely cool before frosting and assembling.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/coconut-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a whisk or paddle attachment, beat the butter and cream cheese together on medium speed until creamy and smooth, about 2 minutes. Add confectioners&#8217; sugar, coconut milk, vanilla extract, coconut extract, and salt with the mixer running on low. Increase to high speed and beat for 3 minutes. Add more confectioners&#8217; sugar if frosting is too thin, more coconut milk if frosting is too thick, or an extra pinch of salt if frosting is too sweet.", "name": "Make the frosting:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/coconut-cake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a large serrated knife,\u00a0slice\u00a0a thin layer off the tops of the cakes\u00a0to create a flat surface. Discard (or crumble over ice cream!).\u00a0Place 1 cake layer on your cake stand, cake turntable, or serving plate. Evenly cover the top with 1 heaping cup (about 250\u2013300g) of frosting. Top with second cake layer and evenly cover the top with another heaping cup of frosting. Top with the third cake layer. Spread the remaining frosting all over the top and sides. I use and recommend an icing spatula to apply the frosting and a bench scraper to smooth the sides. Sprinkle coconut on top of the cake and apply it to the sides. This can get a little messy and you can watch me do it in the video tutorial. Measure about 1/3 cup of batter and pour into the hot oil, making one large swirl and making sure to connect some of the swirl layers. It doesn&#8217;t have to be pretty, it doesn&#8217;t have to be perfect! Fry until golden brown, about 1-2 minutes on each side. Carefully remove with a metal spatula or metal slotted spoon and place onto the wire rack to slightly cool. Repeat with remaining batter, then turn off heat.*", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-funnel-cakes/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Serve the funnel cakes while they&#8217;re still a little warm. Line two large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats.\u00a0Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sweet-vanilla-bean-biscotti/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt together in a large bowl until combined. Using a pastry cutter or fork, cut in the butter until the mixture is crumbly. Set aside. In a medium bowl, whisk the 3 eggs, oil, and vanilla extract together. Pour into the flour/butter mixture and gently mix together with a wooden spoon or silicone spatula until everything is just barely moistened. It will be very crumbly, see photo above for a visual.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sweet-vanilla-bean-biscotti/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Turn dough out onto a lightly floured surface and with floured hands, knead lightly until the dough is soft and slightly sticky, about 8-10 times. If it\u2019s sticking all over your hands, knead 1-2 more Tablespoon(s) of flour into the dough. Divide the dough in two and place each half onto a baking sheet. Shape each half into an 8-9 inch long slab, patting down until each is about 1/2 inch thick. Using a pastry brush, lightly brush the top and sides of each biscotti slab with egg wash.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sweet-vanilla-bean-biscotti/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake in batches (or together) for 25-26 minutes, or until the top and sides of the biscotti slabs are lightly browned. Remove from the oven, but do not turn off the heat. Allow to cool for 10 minutes. Once the slabs are cool enough to handle, cut each into 1 inch wide slices. Set slices cut sides upright, \u00bc inch apart, on the baking sheets. (It&#8217;s tricky to set the end slices upright, so just turn them over.) Return to the oven to continue baking for 8 minutes. Turn biscotti over and bake other side for 8 minutes. The cookies will be slightly soft in the centers with harder edges.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sweet-vanilla-bean-biscotti/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove from the oven and cool the biscotti for 5 minutes on the baking sheet. Transfer to a wire rack to cool completely before dipping in white chocolate. The biscotti becomes more and more crunchy as it cools. It&#8217;s helpful to save the baking sheets for the next step.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sweet-vanilla-bean-biscotti/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Melt the chopped white chocolate in a double boiler or carefully use the microwave. For the microwave, place the white chocolate in a medium heat-proof bowl. Melt in 15 second increments, stirring after each increment until completely melted and smooth. Dip each cookie in the melted chocolate and place back onto the baking sheets. Allow chocolate to set in the refrigerator or at room temperature.", "name": "Optional White Chocolate", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sweet-vanilla-bean-biscotti/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Biscotti stays fresh covered at room temperature or in the refrigerator for 1-2 weeks.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sweet-vanilla-bean-biscotti/#instruction-step-6"}], "prepTime": "PT40M", "cookTime": "PT45M", "totalTime": "PT1H25M", "recipeYield": ["18", "18 cookies"], "recipeCategory": "Cookies", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "Italian", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "28", "ratingValue": "4.6"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Brandon"}, "datePublished": "2022-09-04", "reviewBody": "These are delicious and came out perfectly. My hands are always really hot, though, so this was my own fault for working the dough with my hands. But, 10 minutes in the fridge helped and I've learned for next time to stick with my pastry cutter or a fork to blend in the butter."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "4"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Kath"}, "datePublished": "2023-04-07", "reviewBody": "Delicious!! I had no issues with the dough being sticky, but I did mix it in the bowl a little more than stated and made sure there was plenty of flour when kneading.\r\nJust wondering if anyone tried rolling the dough into two logs and then flatten slightly before baking. Whisk in the egg, then the Biscoff until combined. Finally, whisk in the vanilla. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and mix together with a large spoon or silicone spatula. The dough will be very soft and slick. Fold in the oats and 1 and 1/4 cups white chocolate, reserving the remaining 1/4 cup for later. The cookies will look very soft and underbaked. They will continue to bake on the cookie sheet. Remove from the oven and lightly press down on each cookie to slightly flatten, since the cookies will not spread all the way in the oven. Press a piece or two of the remaining white chocolate chips/chunks into each cookie as described above in the post. Spray a 12-count muffin pan with nonstick spray or line with cupcake liners. This recipe makes 12-14 muffins, so you may need a 2nd muffin pan or bake this recipe in batches.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-cheesecake-muffins/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Mix the brown sugar, cinnamon, and melted butter together in a small bowl until combined. Add the flour and use a fork to gently mix until crumbs form. Don&#8217;t over-mix into a paste. Just mix until it is crumbly. Set aside.", "name": "Make the crumb-topping first", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-cheesecake-muffins/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, cinnamon and pumpkin pie spice together in a large bowl. Set aside. In a medium bowl, whisk the brown sugar, granulated sugar, eggs, pumpkin, oil, milk, and vanilla extract together. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and whisk or stir until just combined. Avoid over-mixing.", "name": "Make the pumpkin batter", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-cheesecake-muffins/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the cream cheese in a medium bowl on medium-high speed until smooth and creamy. Beat in the egg yolk, vanilla extract, and sugar until combined.", "name": "Make the cheesecake filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-cheesecake-muffins/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon 1 heaping Tablespoon of pumpkin muffin batter into the muffin cups. Layer with about 1 spoonful (not quite a full Tablespoon) of cheesecake filling, then another heaping Tablespoon of muffin batter\u2014or however much batter is needed to fill the cups all the way to the top. Some cheesecake filling may poke out of the top or on the sides. Sprinkle crumb topping onto each, then press it down into the tops of the muffins to help prevent it from falling off as the muffins bake.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-cheesecake-muffins/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 5 minutes 425\u00b0F (218\u00b0C) then, keeping the muffins in the oven, reduce heat to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C)* and continue baking for another 15-17 minutes. The total time these muffins should be in the oven is around 20-22 minutes. This is like a dessert version of classic banana bread.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "cinnamon swirl banana bread", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/cinnamon-swirl-banana-bread-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/cinnamon-swirl-banana-bread-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/cinnamon-swirl-banana-bread-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/cinnamon-swirl-banana-bread.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cinnamon-swirl-banana-bread/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 cups (250g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 teaspoon baking soda", "1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "2/3 cup (135g) granulated sugar (or use packed brown sugar)", "4 Tablespoons (56g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "2 large eggs, at room temperature", "1 and 1/2 cups (345g) mashed bananas (about 4 medium or 3 large ripe bananas)", "1/3 cup (80g) plain Greek yogurt (or sour cream)", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1/4 cup (50g) granulated sugar", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons ground cinnamon", "1/2 cup (60g) confectioners&#8217; sugar, sifted", "1 Tablespoon (15ml) heavy cream or milk", "1/4 teaspoon pure vanilla extract"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Adjust the oven rack to the lower third position and preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Lowering the oven rack prevents the top of your bread from browning too much, too soon. Grease a metal 9&#215;5-inch loaf pan with nonstick spray. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cinnamon-swirl-banana-bread/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, baking soda, cinnamon, and salt together in a medium bowl. Set aside.", "name": "Make the banana bread batter", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cinnamon-swirl-banana-bread/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on high speed until smooth and creamy, about 3 minutes. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) With the mixer running on medium speed, add the eggs one at a time, beating well after each addition. Then beat in the mashed bananas, yogurt, and vanilla extract until combined. With the mixer running on low speed, slowly beat the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients until no flour pockets remain. Do not over-mix. You&#8217;ll have around 3 and 1/2 cups of batter.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cinnamon-swirl-banana-bread/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Mix the sugar and cinnamon together. Spoon half of the banana bread batter into prepared loaf pan. Sprinkle with cinnamon-sugar mixture. Pour and spread remaining batter on top. The top layer of batter will want to stick to the cinnamon-sugar filling, making spreading a little tougher to do, but use a spoon to carefully spread it out as best you can. Using a knife, swirl the batter down the center of the loaf pan. Avoid over-swirling, which will mix the layers together too much.", "name": "Cinnamon Sugar Swirl", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cinnamon-swirl-banana-bread/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 55\u201365 minutes, making sure to loosely cover the bread with aluminum foil halfway through to prevent the top from getting too brown. The bread is done when a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean with only a few small moist crumbs. All ovens vary, so begin checking every 5 minutes around the 55-minute mark.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cinnamon-swirl-banana-bread/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove bread from the oven and allow the bread to cool in the pan set on a wire rack for 1 hour. 1 for bottom 1 for top)*", "3 large apples, cored, peeled, and sliced into 1/4-inch slices (about 6\u20137 cups of slices, or 750\u2013875g)", "1 and 1/2\u00a0cups (187g) fresh or frozen cranberries", "3/4 cup (150g) granulated sugar", "2 Tablespoons (14g) cornstarch", "1 teaspoon fresh orange zest", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons ground cinnamon", "1/4 teaspoon ground cloves", "1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg", "2 Tablespoons (30g) unsalted butter, cold and cubed", "egg wash: 1 large egg beaten with 1 Tablespoon (15ml) milk"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Prepare my pie crust recipe through step 5.", "name": "The crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cranberry-pie/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Stir the apples, cranberries, granulated sugar, cornstarch, orange zest, cinnamon, cloves, and nutmeg together in a large bowl. Turn the dough about a quarter turn after every few rolls until you have a circle 12 inches in diameter. Carefully place the dough into a 9-inch pie dish. Tuck it in with your fingers, making sure it is smooth. Spoon the filling into the crust, leaving any excess liquid in the bowl (you don&#8217;t want that in the filling\u2014discard it). Dot the pieces of butter on top of the filling. Stick in the refrigerator until ready to cut the lattice.", "name": "Roll out the chilled pie dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cranberry-pie/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Remove the other disc\u00a0of chilled pie dough from the refrigerator. Roll the dough into a circle that is 12 inches diameter. Using a pastry wheel, sharp knife, pizza cutter, or this fun ribbon cutter, cut strips 1 or 2 inches wide. Remove the pie from the refrigerator and carefully thread the pie dough strips over and under one another, pulling back strips as necessary to weave. Press the edges of the strips into the bottom pie crust edges to seal. Use a small knife to trim off excess dough. Crimp or flute the pie crust edges. See recipe notes for making the braid or apple shapes! (Alternatively, you can simply cover the filling with the 12-inch pie dough circle. Cut slits in the top to form steam vents. Trim and crimp the edges. Or crumble topping (from apple crumble pie) or streusel topping (from peach pecan crisp) would be great as well.)", "name": "Arrange\u00a0the lattice", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cranberry-pie/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly brush the top of the pie crust with the egg wash mixture.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cranberry-pie/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the pie onto a large baking sheet and bake for 20 minutes. Since the apple pie filling is pretty much cooked during the canning process, would this change the baking time at all?"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "KP"}, "datePublished": "2023-11-26", "reviewBody": "Yummm absolutely delicious! Hav ebeen making regular apple pie for some time and my 4 yr old begged me to buy fresh cranberries because \"she loves them\". Turns out fresh cranberries aren't as sweet as they look lol. Wanted to utilize the leftovers and came across this recipe after some looking around... BEST. Recipe. Ever! Gives the pie an acidic note that plays off the apple's sweetness well. The cinnamon and clove added a nice winter warmth and depth of flavor. I made this recipe, and used the crumble topping recipe that was mentioned as an alternate.  The flavor was wonderful.  Despite having a huge mound of filling, I was very pleased that it did not bubble over at all while baking.  I used my pie-crust guards and the crust edges were just the right level of brown.  The reason I reduced the rating is that there was a deep pool of liquid in the bottom of the pie when I cut it to serve it.  When I filled the pie crust, I used a slotted spoon to transfer the mixed filling into the crust to make sure I kept as much liquid out of the crust as possible.  I also let it sit at room temperature to cool for the alloted number of hours after it was baked, but the bottom of the pie ended up as a giant soggy pool of liquid so I was glad that I wasn't serving it to guests. Stir in the graham cracker crumbs. The mixture will resemble wet sand. Spoon a generous spoonful into each jar, about 2 Tablespoons into the 8-ounce jars and 1 and 1/2 Tablespoons into the 6-ounce jars. If there&#8217;s any crust leftover, sprinkle into the jars to use up or discard. If there are lumps, keep beating until smooth.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/no-bake-cheesecake-jars/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using your mixer on low speed or a silicone spatula, fold the whipped cream into the cheesecake filling until combined. Add the granulated sugar and beat until mixture is fluffy and combined, about 1 minute. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Add the egg, vanilla extract, and almond extract (if using), and beat on high speed until combined, about 1 minute. Line large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. Carefully remove the top dough piece from the refrigerator. If it\u2019s sticking to the parchment, run your hand under it to help remove it. Using a cookie cutter, cut the dough into shapes. (I like these heart cookie cutters.) Re-roll the remaining dough and continue cutting until all is used. Repeat with second piece of dough. Note: It doesn\u2019t seem like a lot of dough, but you get a lot of cookies from the dough scraps you re-roll.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Arrange cookies on baking sheets 3 inches apart. Dip cooled cookies in the melted chocolate and/or drizzle with melted chocolate, then place back onto the lined baking sheets. I dipped the pictured cookies in melted semi-sweet chocolate and then drizzled melted white chocolate on top. If desired, sprinkle with extra freeze-dried raspberry powder (or sprinkles). For best success, use the caramel candies suggested in the recipe and don't skip the chilling step.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "Nutella, hazelnuts, caramel, cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/caramel-nutella-cookies-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/caramel-nutella-cookies-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/caramel-nutella-cookies-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/caramel-nutella-cookies.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/caramel-stuffed-nutella-cookies/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 and 1/2 cups (313g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "2 Tablespoons (10g) unsweetened natural cocoa powder", "1 teaspoon baking soda", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "3/4 cup (150g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar", "1 large egg, at room temperature", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "3/4 cup\u00a0(225g)\u00a0Nutella", "1 heaping cup (130g) chopped hazelnuts", "28 soft caramel candies\u00a0(see recipe note)", "optional: coarse salt or sea salt for topping"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, cocoa powder, baking soda, and salt together in a large bowl. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/caramel-stuffed-nutella-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with paddle attachment, cream the softened butter and both sugars together on medium speed until smooth, about 2 minutes. Add the egg and mix on high until combined, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed. Add the vanilla and Nutella and beat on high until completely combined.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/caramel-stuffed-nutella-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients and beat on low speed until combined. Beat in the hazelnuts. Dough will be thick, yet airy and sticky. Cover and chill the dough for at least 3 hours in the refrigerator. If chilling for longer (up to 3 days), allow dough to sit at room temperature for at least 30 minutes before scooping and baking.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/caramel-stuffed-nutella-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line two large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/caramel-stuffed-nutella-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cookie dough will be firm after chilling, but will come together with the warmth of your hands. Measure 1 scant Tablespoon of cookie dough and roll into a ball. Indent your thumb into it. Place caramel candy inside. (See recipe note.) Take another 1 scant Tablespoon of cookie dough and use it to completely cover the caramel candy on top. Roll the caramel-stuffed dough into an even ball. Make sure the caramel is completely wrapped inside. Sprinkle with coarse salt. Repeat with remaining cookie dough and caramels. Arrange cookie dough balls 3 inches apart on baking sheets. Place any remaining cookie dough balls in the refrigerator as you bake the other batches. (Best to keep those dough balls cold.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/caramel-stuffed-nutella-cookies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake the cookies for 13-14 minutes until the edges appear set. Caramel may have oozed out a little. (That&#8217;s ok!) The centers will look very soft and under-baked. Remove from the oven and let cool on baking sheet for 5 minutes. The cookies will continue to \u201cset\u201d on the baking sheet during this time. Transfer cookies to a wire rack to cool completely. Hazelnuts are so underused in N. America;  not so in Europe.\r\nThe chocolate flavor is intense but the nuts, Nutella and flavoring hold their own.  Wonderful chewy texture.  I made one addition.  I added 1 t of hazelnut flavoring (from Beanilla) and that ramped up the hazelnut part of this cookie.  Of course, be sure to use TOASTED hazelnuts.  I wish there was an easier way to chop hazelnuts.  If the food processor, they become powder.  On a cutting board, they jump all over and fly on the floor. Sally\u2019s work has been featured on TODAY, Good Morning America, Taste of Home, People, and more.", "sameAs": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"]}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Homemade Fudge Chocolate Pop Tarts", "description": "Follow these thorough instructions to make a homemade version of store-bought chocolate pop tarts. These fudge chocolate pastry pies hold shape if they chill before baking (step 6) and taste best if they cool before you dig in!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "chocolate pastry tarts, chocolate pop tarts", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/01/chocolate-pop-tarts-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/01/chocolate-pop-tarts-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/01/chocolate-pop-tarts-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/01/chocolate-pop-tarts.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-pastry-pop-tarts/", "recipeIngredient": ["2\u00a0and 1/4 cups (281g)\u00a0all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1/4 cup\u00a0(21g) unsweetened natural or dutch-process\u00a0cocoa powder, plus more as needed for rolling", "2 Tablespoons\u00a0(24g)\u00a0granulated sugar", "1/2 teaspoon\u00a0salt", "1 cup (16 Tbsp; 226g)\u00a0unsalted butter, very cold and cubed", "1/2 cup (120ml) cold whole milk*", "egg wash: 1 egg beaten with 1 Tablespoon (15ml) milk", "4 ounce\u00a0(113g)\u00a0semi-sweet chocolate bar, coarsely chopped*", "1/4 cup (60ml) whole milk*", "2 Tablespoons (25g) granulated sugar", "1 Tablespoon (14g) unsalted butter, cold and cubed", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1 Tablespoon (14g) unsalted butter", "2 Tablespoons (30ml) water", "1 cup (120g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "2 Tablespoons (10g) unsweetened natural or dutch-process cocoa powder", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "optional: sprinkles for garnish"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the flour, cocoa powder, sugar, and salt into a large 8-cup capacity or higher food processor or, if you don&#8217;t have a food processor, in a large bowl. Pulse or whisk until combined. Add butter and pulse or use a pastry cutter to manually cut in until coarse pea-sized crumbs form. See photo above for a visual. In 3 additions, pour in the milk and pulse or stir after each addition. After all the milk is added, pulse or stir more until the dough clumps up and comes together. If it&#8217;s too dry, add 1 Tablespoon (15ml) of cold milk. Try not to overwork the dough. Pour onto a work surface lightly dusted with cocoa powder or all-purpose flour. Use your hands to form dough into a ball. Divide the dough in half and flatten each into 1-inch thick discs. Wrap each disc tightly in plastic wrap and refrigerate for 2 hours and up to 5 days.", "name": "Make the dough first", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-pastry-pop-tarts/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "The fudge filling needs to cool and thicken, so that is why I recommend making it soon after you put the pastry dough in the refrigerator. Place chocolate, milk, and sugar in a medium saucepan over medium heat. Stir frequently as chocolate melts and mixture combines. Once melted, remove from heat and stir in the butter and vanilla extract. Pour into a heatproof bowl, cover, and set aside at room temperature to cool and thicken. You want the consistency slightly thinner than peanut butter. Note: You can refrigerate the filling to thicken it, but it may become too thick and cold. If it&#8217;s too thick, reheat in the microwave for a few seconds.", "name": "Make the fudge filling soon after you prepare the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-pastry-pop-tarts/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Line 1 large baking sheet with parchment paper or a silicone baking mat. Make sure there is enough room in your refrigerator for the baking sheet because the shaped pastry pop tarts must chill for 15 minutes before baking.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-pastry-pop-tarts/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove 1 of the dough discs from the refrigerator and let it sit at room temperature for 10 minutes to slightly warm up because it will be quite solid. (Keep the other in the refrigerator until step 5.) Lightly dust a work surface, rolling pin, and your hands with cocoa powder or all-purpose flour. Using a rolling pin, roll the dough into a 9&#215;12-inch rectangle. Use gentle force with your rolling pin and use your hands to help keep the edges straight. You can watch me roll out the dough in the video below if you need a visual (2:23 mark). Visible specks of butter and fat in the dough are perfectly normal and expected. Trim the edges of the rectangle to straighten if needed. Cut rectangle into 3 equal strips and cut those into thirds for a total of 9 3&#215;4-inch rectangles. Use a ruler to help make this process easier and more accurate. Arrange the dough rectangles 2 inches apart on the prepared baking sheet and chill in the refrigerator as you roll out 2nd half of dough in the next step.", "name": "Roll out the chilled pie dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-pastry-pop-tarts/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Roll out the 2nd half of dough and cut into 9 3&#215;4-inch rectangles like you did with the 1st half of dough in step 4.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-pastry-pop-tarts/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove 1st set of dough rectangles from the refrigerator. Using a pastry brush, brush edges of each of these 9 rectangles with egg wash. Spoon a heaping Tablespoon of filling into center of each. Lay the other set of pie dough rectangles on top of each and press your finger around the edges to slightly seal. Poke holes in the top pie crust with a fork or toothpick and then crimp with a fork to ensure no filling spills out (if it does, it&#8217;s not a big deal). Refrigerate the shaped pastries uncovered for at least 15 minutes and up to 3 hours. This firms up the pastry and helps set its shape. (After chilling, feel free to carefully transfer the pastries to a new lined baking sheet if you don&#8217;t want to bake them on the cold baking sheet.)", "name": "Assemble the pastry tarts:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-pastry-pop-tarts/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Meanwhile, preheat oven to 375\u00b0F (191\u00b0C). And look ahead to step 9\u2014you can make the icing as the pastries bake in step 8.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-pastry-pop-tarts/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Brush pastry tarts with egg wash and bake for 25-26 minutes or until edges appear set. Remove from the oven and allow pastries to cool for 5 minutes before transferring to a wire rack to cool completely. Pastries taste best after completely cooling\u2014they are very soft and rich when warm.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-pastry-pop-tarts/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium saucepan over low heat or in a medium heatproof bowl using the microwave, warm butter and water together until butter has melted. Whisk mixture with the remaining icing ingredients. Cool icing for 15 minutes before spooning onto pastries. You can add the icing when the pastries are still warm, but again, they taste best after completely cooling. Immediately top with sprinkles, if using. Note: The longer the icing cools, the thicker it gets. If you let it cool too long before spooning on the pastries, the surface will stiffen up\u2014whisking will bring it back together though. You can also reheat on the stove or in the microwave to thin out if needed.", "name": "Make the icing", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-pastry-pop-tarts/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover and store pastries at room temperature for up to 1 day or in the refrigerator for up to 1 week.", "url": When lifting the whisk up off the icing, the icing should drizzle down and smooth out within 5\u201310 seconds. If it&#8217;s too thick, whip in more water, 1 Tablespoon at a time. I usually need 10 Tablespoons, but on particularly dry days, I use up to 12\u201314 Tablespoons. Keep in mind that the longer you whip the royal icing, the thicker it becomes. If your royal icing is too thin, just keep whipping it to introduce more air, or you can add more sifted confectioners&#8217; sugar.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/royal-icing/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If you&#8217;d like to tint the icing, divide it into separate bowls for each color, or tint the entire batch one color. A little gel food coloring goes a long way, so use a toothpick to dot the gel into the icing. Stir it in and then add more to deepen the color if desired. Keep in mind that the more you stir, the thicker the icing becomes. If needed, stir in a few drops of water to maintain the target consistency.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/royal-icing/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "When applied to cookies or confections in a thin layer, icing completely dries in about 2 hours at room temperature. If you&#8217;re layering royal icing onto cookies for specific designs and need it to set quickly, place cookies in the refrigerator to help speed up the setting. These soft-centered, crispy-edged cookies get their incredible texture from a blend of all-purpose and cake flour, plus a touch of molasses for warm, old-fashioned flavor. A cozy, ultra-thick cookie perfect for year-round baking. Do not skip the dough chilling and see recipe Notes for questions and answers regarding various ingredients.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally McKenney", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "dark chocolate cranberry oatmeal cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/big-fat-dark-chocolate-cranberry-oatmeal-cookies-3-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/big-fat-dark-chocolate-cranberry-oatmeal-cookies-3-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/big-fat-dark-chocolate-cranberry-oatmeal-cookies-3-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/big-fat-dark-chocolate-cranberry-oatmeal-cookies-3.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/dark-chocolate-cranberry-oatmeal-cookies/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 cups (170g) old-fashioned whole rolled oats", "1 and 1/2 cups (188g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 cup (118g) cake flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 teaspoon cornstarch", "3/4 teaspoon baking powder", "1/2 teaspoon baking soda", "1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "1 cup (16 Tbsp; 226g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 cup (200g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar", "2 large eggs, at room temperature", "1 Tablespoon (21g) unsulphured or dark molasses\u00a0", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "6 ounces (170g) chopped bittersweet or dark chocolate\u00a0", "1 cup (150g) dried cranberries\u00a0", "3/4 cup (90g) chopped walnuts\u00a0"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl, whisk together the oats, all-purpose flour, cake flour, cornstarch, baking powder, baking soda, cinnamon, and salt. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Add the eggs, molasses, and vanilla, and beat on high speed until combined, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl and beat again as needed.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/dark-chocolate-cranberry-oatmeal-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the flour mixture to the wet ingredients, plus the chopped chocolate, dried cranberries, and walnuts. Beat on low speed until combined. This is a thick, heavy, and sticky dough, so you may need to start and stop your mixer a couple times.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/dark-chocolate-cranberry-oatmeal-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover and refrigerate the dough for at least 1 hour (and up to 4 days). If chilling longer than 1 day, let the dough sit at room temperature for at least 30 minutes before rolling, as it will be very firm.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/dark-chocolate-cranberry-oatmeal-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Line large baking sheets with\u00a0parchment paper\u00a0or\u00a0silicone baking mats. They\u2019re easy to prep, extra tender, and seasoned just right. To really lock in the flavor and moisture, I recommend quickly pan-searing the meatballs on the stove before finishing them in the slow cooker. These saucy turkey meatballs are so versatile\u2014enjoy them in meatball sandwiches, on their own alongside a salad and cheese breadsticks, or, naturally, on top of spaghetti.\n\nGet the full recipe: https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/crockpot-turkey-meatballs/\n\n\u2022 Ask your recipe question or leave a review over on the recipe page.\n\n#baking #recipes #turkeymeatballs #turkeymeatballrecipe \n\n\u2022 More of Sally's baking recipes: https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/", "duration": "PT1M", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/1svVWXs529g?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1svVWXs529g", "thumbnailUrl": ["https://i.ytimg.com/vi/1svVWXs529g/hqdefault.jpg"], "uploadDate": "2025-02-04T14:00:02+00:00"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Beth"}, "datePublished": "2021-10-09", "reviewBody": "I love this recipe! Everything can be prepared in advance, see my make ahead tip after the recipe instructions. House structure must completely set for at least 4-6 hours before decorating.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "gingerbread house", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/homemade-gingerbread-house-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/homemade-gingerbread-house-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/homemade-gingerbread-house-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/homemade-gingerbread-house.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-house/", "recipeIngredient": ["3 cups (375g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "1/4 teaspoon baking soda", "2 teaspoons ground ginger", "2 teaspoons ground cinnamon", "1/2 teaspoon ground allspice", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "6 Tablespoons (85g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "3/4 cup (150g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1 large egg, at room temperature", "1/2 cup (120ml) unsulphured or dark molasses (do not use blackstrap; I prefer Grandma&#8217;s brand)", "1 Tablespoon (15ml) water", "royal icing (the &#8220;glue&#8221;)", "assorted candies (see post for suggestions)", "1/2 cup (95g) shortening, at room temperature", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "4 cups (480g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "2 Tablespoons (30ml) milk", "1/4 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1/8 teaspoon salt"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Print out my\u00a0Sally&#8217;s Baking Recipes Gingerbread House Template and cut out the shapes. Set aside for step 6.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-house/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, baking soda, ginger, cinnamon, allspice, and salt together in a large bowl. Set aside.", "name": "Make the cookie dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-house/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld mixer or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and brown sugar together on medium speed until completely smooth and creamy, about 2 minutes. Beat in the egg, molasses, and water on high speed. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl and beat again as needed to combine. On low speed, slowly mix the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients until combined. Cookie dough will be very thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-house/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Divide cookie dough in half, flatten into discs (about 4-5 inches in diameter), and wrap each tightly in plastic wrap. Chill in the refrigerator for 2 hours or up to 3 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-house/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to\u00a0350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line 2-3 large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-house/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove each disc from the refrigerator and roll each out in between two pieces of parchment paper. Watch me do this in the video above\u2014gingerbread cookie dough will stick to your counter no matter how much you flour it. Parchment is best. Roll out to about 1/4 inch thick. You want thick pieces for your gingerbread house. Lightly flour the underside of gingerbread house template shapes. (The dough is sticky and the paper may stick to it otherwise.) Using a pizza cutter or small knife, carefully cut the dough into the gingerbread house template shapes. You will need TWO of each shape. Re-roll dough scraps so you have enough dough for the whole house. Use any extra dough to create fun shapes using cookie cutters. I made a few gingerbread stars!", "name": "Cut into shapes", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-house/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Carefully arrange gingerbread house shapes onto prepared baking sheets, about 3 inches apart. If they lost some of their shape transferring to the baking sheet, straighten out the edges (see my video above).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-house/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake house pieces for about 18-20 minutes or until edges are lightly browned. Bake chimney pieces for about 12-13 minutes or until edges are lightly browned. Remove from the oven and allow shapes to cool completely on the baking sheets or on the counter. A flat surface is KEY for cooling\u2014the gingerbread house edges very slightly curl up otherwise. Cooled gingerbread house pieces can be made up to 1 week in advance, cover tightly and store at room temperature or in the refrigerator. They can also be frozen for up to 3 months, thaw at room temperature before using.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-house/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Select a base for your gingerbread house. I used a wooden cake server. Watch my video above to guide you through constructing the house. Start with two pieces: the front of the house and 1 side. Using a squeeze bottle, run a thick line of royal icing on one long edge and one short edge of the side of the house piece. Stick it to your base. Use whatever you have around the house to help it stand up. You can see in my video that I use snack bag clips. You can also prop it up with soda cans, a tall cup, water bottle, etc. Run a line of royal icing along the bottom of the front of the house piece. Stick it to your base, adhering it to the side of the house piece. Hold the two in place for a few minutes until the icing is partially set, propping them up as necessary. Repeat with the 2nd side of the house piece and back of the house piece. Pipe royal icing inside any seams, inside and outside of the house, to fill any voids. Don&#8217;t be afraid to go heavy on the royal icing &#8220;glue&#8221;\u2014when it dries, it looks like snow! Allow it to set at room temperature for at least 1 hour before adding the roof pieces.", "name": "Construct the base of the house", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-house/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0The roof pieces will be placed on top of the house base. Run a thick line of royal icing on the inside edges of one of the roof pieces and adhere it to the base. Hold in place for a few minutes. Repeat with 2nd roof piece. Run a thick line of royal icing where the two roof pieces meet at the top of the house. Hold in place for a few minutes.", "name": "Add the roof", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-house/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0The chimney is optional, but it&#8217;s a lot of fun. I recommend putting together the chimney separately, then adhering to the roof. It&#8217;s easiest to glue the chimney pieces together upside-down. Use thick lines of royal icing to assemble the chimney in the same way you put together the base of the house. (Except you&#8217;re not adhering it to a base because it&#8217;s going on the roof!) Allow icing to set by propping it up as necessary. Once set, adhere onto the roof. The chimney may not fit to the exact angle of the roof because both puffed up or lost some shape during baking and cooling, so use as much royal icing as necessary and you can cover any bare spots with buttercream during decoration.", "name": "Optional Chimney", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-house/#instruction-step-11"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Before decorating, the icing on the entire house must completely set. Allow the entire house to set at room temperature for at least 3 hours, preferably 4-6 hours or even overnight before decorating. Cover and store leftover royal icing at room temperature or in the refrigerator during this time. It will be the glue for adhering candies to the house.", "name": "House must set", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-house/#instruction-step-12"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Buttercream can be prepared up to 1 day in advance\u2014cover tightly and store in the refrigerator overnight. Bring to room temperature before piping/decorating. With a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the shortening and butter together on medium speed until creamy, about 2 minutes. Add confectioners&#8217; sugar, milk, and vanilla extract. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, then increase to high speed and beat for 3 full minutes. Frosting will be very thick, which is what you want. If much too thick, add another splash of milk. Add a pinch of salt if frosting is too sweet. (I add 1/8 teaspoon salt.)", "name": "Prepare the buttercream:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-house/#instruction-step-13"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Use buttercream, leftover royal icing, and candies for decorating. See my candy suggestions in the blog post above. I only used 1 piping tip for the entire house: Ateco piping tip #32. This is a small open star piping tip and you can watch me use it in the video above. Makes a lovely design.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-house/#instruction-step-14"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Don&#8217;t forget to chow down on your beautiful creation if you&#8217;re in the mood for eating it. Use your best judgment here, obviously the food will taste old after a few days!", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/gingerbread-house/#instruction-step-15"}], "prepTime": "PT24H", "cookTime": "PT18M", "totalTime": "PT24H", "recipeYield": ["1", "1 house"], "recipeCategory": "Dessert", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "102", "ratingValue": "4.4"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Gingerbread House | Sally's Baking Addiction", "description": "Here\u2019s my completely homemade gingerbread house recipe including how to bake, construct, and decorate with royal icing and buttercream. Grease two 9-inch cake pans, line with parchment paper rounds, then grease the parchment paper. Parchment paper helps the cakes seamlessly release from the pans. (If it&#8217;s helpful, see this parchment paper rounds for cakes video &amp; post.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/triple-chocolate-layer-cake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, cocoa powder, sugar, baking soda, baking powder, salt, and espresso powder (if using) together in a large bowl. Set aside. Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment (or you can use a whisk) mix the oil, eggs, and vanilla together on medium-high speed until combined. Add the buttermilk and mix until combined. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients, add the hot water/coffee, and whisk or beat on low speed until the batter is completely combined. Batter is thin.", "name": "Make the cake:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/triple-chocolate-layer-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Divide batter evenly between pans. Bake for 23-26 minutes or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. Baking times vary, so keep an eye on yours. The cakes are done when a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. (Note: Even if they&#8217;re completely done, the cooled cakes may *slightly* sink in the center. Cocoa powder is simply not as structurally strong as all-purpose flour and can&#8217;t hold up to all the moisture necessary to make a moist tasting chocolate cake. It&#8217;s normal!)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/triple-chocolate-layer-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove the cakes from the oven and set on a wire rack.\u00a0Allow to cool completely in the pan.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/triple-chocolate-layer-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "With a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter on medium speed until creamy\u2014about 2 minutes. Add confectioners\u2019 sugar, cocoa powder, 3 Tablespoons heavy cream, salt, and vanilla extract. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, then increase to high speed and beat for 1 full minute. Do not over-whip. Add 1/4 cup more confectioners\u2019 sugar or cocoa powder if frosting is too thin or 1-2 more Tablespoons of cream if frosting is too thick. (I usually add 1 more.) Taste. Add another pinch of salt if desired.", "name": "Make the buttercream", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/triple-chocolate-layer-cake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If cooled cakes are domed on top, use a large serrated knife to slice a thin layer off the tops to create a flat surface. This is called &#8220;leveling&#8221; the cakes. Discard or crumble over finished cake. Place 1 cake layer on your cake stand or serving plate. Evenly cover the top with frosting. Top with 2nd layer and spread remaining frosting all over the top and sides. I always use an icing spatula\u00a0and\u00a0bench scraper for the frosting. Add the sugar and beat on high speed for 2 minutes until creamed together. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a rubber spatula as needed. Add the egg whites and vanilla extract. Beat on medium-high speed until combined, then beat in the sour cream. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. With the mixer on low speed, add the dry ingredients until just incorporated. With the mixer still running on low, slowly pour in the champagne until combined. Do not overmix. You may need to whisk it all by hand to make sure there are no lumps at the bottom of the bowl. The batter will be slightly thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wedding-cupcakes-with-champagne-frosting/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour/spoon the batter into the liners\u2014fill only 2/3 full to avoid spilling over the sides. Once creamy and combined, beat in 3 Tablespoons of the reduced champagne and the vanilla extract. Taste. Spray a 12-count muffin pan with nonstick spray or line with cupcake liners. This recipe yields about 10 muffins.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cream-cheese-zucchini-muffins/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, cinnamon and nutmeg together in a large bowl. Set aside. In a medium bowl, whisk the oil, brown sugar, granulated sugar, egg, and vanilla extract together. Whisk in the zucchini. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and whisk or stir until just combined. Avoid over-mixing.", "name": "Make the zucchini batter", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cream-cheese-zucchini-muffins/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the cream cheese in a medium bowl on medium-high speed until smooth and creamy. Beat in the egg yolk, vanilla extract, and sugar until combined.", "name": "Make the cream cheese filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cream-cheese-zucchini-muffins/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon 1 heaping Tablespoon of zucchini muffin batter into the muffin cups. Layer with 1 Tablespoon of cream cheese filling, then another heaping Tablespoon of muffin batter\u2014or however much batter is needed to fill the cups all the way to the top. Some cream cheese filling can poke out of the top or on the sides. Sprinkle with coarse sugar, if desired.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cream-cheese-zucchini-muffins/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 5 minutes 425\u00b0F (218\u00b0C) then, keeping the muffins in the oven, reduce heat to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C)* and continue baking for another 15\u201317 minutes. The total time these muffins should be in the oven is around 20-22 minutes. Sally\u2019s work has been featured on TODAY, Good Morning America, Taste of Home, People, and more.", "sameAs": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"]}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Toasted Hazelnut Slice 'n' Bake Cookies with Milk Chocolate", "description": "These cookies turned me into a slice and bake cookies enthusiast. With brown sugar, cinnamon, and vanilla they are a true winner! A floured surface is key to help you handle the cookie dough when rolling into logs. The logs of cookie dough must be chilled in the refrigerator for at least 4 hours or even up to a few days (or even frozen!) so it's really easy to just take them out when you need them, slice, and bake them.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "hazelnut slice & bake cookies, chocolate hazelnut cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/hazelnut-slice-and-bake-cookies-with-milk-chocolate-5-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/hazelnut-slice-and-bake-cookies-with-milk-chocolate-5-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/hazelnut-slice-and-bake-cookies-with-milk-chocolate-5-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/hazelnut-slice-and-bake-cookies-with-milk-chocolate-5.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/toasted-hazelnut-slice-n-bake-cookies-with-milk-chocolate/", "recipeIngredient": ["3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "2/3 cup (133g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1 large egg, at room temperature", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "2 cups (250g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "1 cup (120g) toasted and finely chopped hazelnuts, divided*", "optional: coarse sugar for rolling", "8 ounces (226g) milk chocolate, coarsely chopped*"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld mixer or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter for 1 minute on medium speed until completely smooth and creamy. Add the brown sugar and beat on medium high speed until fluffy and creamy. Beat in egg and vanilla extract on high speed. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed, and continue to beat until fully combined.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/toasted-hazelnut-slice-n-bake-cookies-with-milk-chocolate/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a separate bowl,\u00a0whisk the flour, cinnamon, and salt together until combined. On low speed, slowly mix into the wet ingredients until combined. The cookie dough will be thick and slightly sticky. Switch to high speed and beat in 3/4 cup chopped\u00a0hazelnuts. Turn the dough out onto a floured work surface and, with floured hands, divide into two. Shape each half into an 8-inch log, about 2.5 inches in diameter. The measurements don&#8217;t have to be exact. Tightly wrap the logs in plastic wrap and chill in the refrigerator for at least 4 hours and up to 5 days. Chilling is mandatory for this cookie dough.\u00a0I always chill mine overnight.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/toasted-hazelnut-slice-n-bake-cookies-with-milk-chocolate/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).\u00a0Line two\u00a0large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats.\u00a0(Always recommended\u00a0for cookies.)\u00a0Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/toasted-hazelnut-slice-n-bake-cookies-with-milk-chocolate/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove logs from the refrigerator and roll into coarse sugar, if desired. It&#8217;s really only for added crunch and a little sparkle! Slice each log into 12\u00a0equally thick cookies and place cookies on baking sheets about 2 inches apart.\u00a0Bake the cookies for 12-14 minutes or until brown around the edges. Allow to cool for 5 minutes on the cookie sheet, then transfer to cooling rack to cool completely.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/toasted-hazelnut-slice-n-bake-cookies-with-milk-chocolate/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Melt the chopped milk\u00a0chocolate in a double boiler or (carefully!) use the microwave. For the microwave, place the chocolate in a medium heat-proof bowl.\u00a0Melt in 15 second increments, stirring after each increment until completely melted and smooth. Dip each completely cooled cookie halfway into the chocolate and place onto a parchment or silicone baking mat-lined baking sheet. Sprinkle with remaining chopped hazelnuts. Place the baking sheet into the refrigerator to help the chocolate set. Once set, enjoy!", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/toasted-hazelnut-slice-n-bake-cookies-with-milk-chocolate/#instruction-step-5"}], "prepTime": "PT30M", "cookTime": "PT14M", "totalTime": "PT4H50M", "recipeYield": ["24", "24 cookies"], "recipeCategory": "Cookies", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "6", "ratingValue": "4.2"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sarah"}, "datePublished": "2020-05-23", "reviewBody": "Hi Sally! I am absolutely amazed at how balanced the flavors are, and that even with the chocolate and toffee they aren't overly sweet at all (and I'm a veggie monster who eats very little sugar ). Refrigerate the shaped scones for at least 15 minutes before baking, to help prevent the scones from over-spreading.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "apple cinnamon scones", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/apple-cinnamon-scones-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/apple-cinnamon-scones-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/apple-cinnamon-scones-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/apple-cinnamon-scones-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/caramel-apple-cinnamon-scones/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 cups (250g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled), plus more for hands and work surface", "2 and 1/2 teaspoons\u00a0baking powder", "1 and 1/4 teaspoons ground cinnamon", "\u00bd teaspoon\u00a0salt", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, frozen", "1/2 cup (120ml) heavy cream, plus 2 Tbsp for brushing", "1 large egg, cold", "1/2 cup (100g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1 heaping cup (125g) peeled and chopped apple*", "coarse sugar", "1/2 cup (145g) store-bought or homemade caramel sauce*"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk flour, baking powder, cinnamon, and salt together in a large bowl. Grate the frozen butter using a box grater. Add it to the flour mixture and combine with a pastry cutter, two forks, or your fingers until the mixture comes together in pea-sized crumbs. Place in the refrigerator or freezer as you mix the wet ingredients together.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/caramel-apple-cinnamon-scones/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk 1/2 cup heavy cream, the egg, brown sugar, and vanilla extract together in a small bowl. Drizzle over the flour mixture, add the apples, then mix together until everything appears moistened.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/caramel-apple-cinnamon-scones/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly dust a work surface with flour. Pour the dough mixture on top and, with floured hands, work dough into a ball as best you can. Dough will be sticky. If it&#8217;s too sticky, add a little more flour. If it seems too dry, add 1 more Tablespoon of heavy cream. Press into an 8-inch disc and, with a sharp knife or bench scraper, cut into 8 wedges.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/caramel-apple-cinnamon-scones/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Brush scones with remaining heavy cream and if desired for extra crunch, sprinkle with coarse sugar. (You can do this before or after refrigerating in the next step.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/caramel-apple-cinnamon-scones/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place scones on a plate or lined baking sheet (if your refrigerator has space!) and refrigerate the shaped scones for at least 15 minutes and up to 1 day.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/caramel-apple-cinnamon-scones/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Meanwhile, preheat the oven to 400\u00b0F (204\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/caramel-apple-cinnamon-scones/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Line a large baking sheet with parchment paper or silicone baking mat. Remove from the oven and cool for a few minutes before topping with optional caramel sauce.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/caramel-apple-cinnamon-scones/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Leftover scones keep well at room temperature for up to 2 days or in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/caramel-apple-cinnamon-scones/#instruction-step-9"}], "prepTime": "PT30M", "cookTime": "PT25M", "totalTime": "PT1H", "recipeYield": ["8", "8 scones"], "recipeCategory": "Breakfast", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "40", "ratingValue": "4.8"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Cheryl from Niagara Falls"}, "datePublished": "2025-01-11", "reviewBody": "These were really good. Add the sugar and beat on high speed for 2 minutes until creamed together. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a silicone spatula as needed. Add the egg whites and vanilla extract. Beat on medium-high speed until combined, then beat in the sour cream. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. With the mixer on low speed, add the dry ingredients until just incorporated. With the mixer still running on low, slowly pour in the coffee then the Baileys. Beat just until combined. Do not over-mix. You may need to whisk it all by hand to make sure there are no lumps in the bottom of the bowl.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/baileys-coffee-cupcakes/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour/spoon the batter into the liners\u2014fill only 2/3 full to avoid spilling over the sides. One of my favorites!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "soft white chocolate chip cookies, white chocolate chip molasses cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/Soft-Baked-White-Chocolate-Chip-Molasses-Cookies-4-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/Soft-Baked-White-Chocolate-Chip-Molasses-Cookies-4-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/Soft-Baked-White-Chocolate-Chip-Molasses-Cookies-4-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/Soft-Baked-White-Chocolate-Chip-Molasses-Cookies-4.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-baked-white-chocolate-chip-molasses-cookies/", "recipeIngredient": ["3 cups (375g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 teaspoon baking soda", "2 teaspoons ground ginger", "1 and 1/4 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "1/4 teaspoon ground cloves", "1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "3/4 cup (150g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1/3 cup (80ml) unsulphured or dark molasses (do not use blackstrap; I prefer Grandma&#8217;s brand)", "1 egg, at room temperature", "2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1 and 1/2 cups white chocolate chips", "1/3 cup (67g) granulated sugar, for rolling"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl, mix the flour, baking soda, ginger, cinnamon, cloves, nutmeg, and salt. Set aside. In the bowl of a handheld mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, cream the softened butter for about 1 minute on medium speed. Add the brown sugar and beat on high speed until light and fluffy, about 2 full minutes. Scrape down the sides as needed. Add the molasses, egg, and vanilla. Beat well on high, scraping down the sides as needed again.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-baked-white-chocolate-chip-molasses-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Slowly add the dry ingredients to the wet on low speed. Once mixed, beat in the white chocolate chips on low speed until dispersed. Try to avoid overmixing. Cover dough tightly and chill for at least 2 hours and up to 3 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-baked-white-chocolate-chip-molasses-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove cookie dough from the refrigerator. If you let it chill for longer than 6 hours, allow to sit out at room temperature for at least 30 minutes. Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line a large baking sheet with parchment paper or a silicone mat. Pour the granulated sugar into a bowl. Take 2 Tablespoons of dough and roll into a ball, then roll into the sugar. Bake for 10-11 minutes, or until edges appear set. Remove from the oven and gently press the top of the cookie down with the back of a utensil or even use your fingers. You&#8217;re trying to obtain a crinkly top. Place back into the oven for 1 more minute. Cookies will be puffy and still appear very soft in the middle. That&#8217;s ok. Remove from the oven and allow to cool on the baking sheet for ten minutes. Transfer to a wire rack to cool completely.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-baked-white-chocolate-chip-molasses-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}], "prepTime": "PT2H15M", "cookTime":
