113g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature and cut into 4 pieces", "2 large eggs, at room temperature", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "4 and 1/2 cups (563g) all-purpose flour\u00a0or\u00a0bread flour (spooned &amp; leveled), plus more for dusting/rolling", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1/4 cup (60ml) pure maple syrup", "1/4 cup (50g) granulated sugar", "1 Tablespoon ground cinnamon", "1 and 1/2 cups (180g)\u00a0confectioners&#8217; sugar", "2 Tablespoons (30ml) pure maple syrup", "2 Tablespoons (30ml) whole milk"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the warm milk, 2 Tablespoons sugar, and the yeast together in the bowl of your stand mixer fitted with a dough hook or paddle attachment. Cover and allow mixture to sit for about 5 minutes or until foamy on top. *If you do not own a mixer, you can do this in a large mixing bowl and in the next step, mix the dough together with a large wooden spoon/silicone spatula. It will take a bit of arm muscle. A hand mixer works, but the sticky dough repeatedly gets stuck in the beaters. Mixing by hand with a wooden spoon or silicone spatula is a better choice.*", "name": "Prepare the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/melt-in-your-mouth-maple-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "On medium speed, beat in the remaining sugar (which should be 1/2 cup/100g) and the softened butter until it is slightly broken up. Add the eggs and salt and beat on medium speed until combined. The butter won&#8217;t really be mixing into the mixture, so don&#8217;t be alarmed if it stays in pieces. Switch the mixer down to low speed and with it running, add 1 cup of flour at a time, making sure it&#8217;s fully incorporated before adding the next. After 4 cups have been added, add the last 1/2 cup and beat until the dough comes together and pulls away from the sides of the bowl, about 3 minutes. Dough will be soft.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/melt-in-your-mouth-maple-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Keep the dough in the mixer and beat for an additional 5 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 5 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/melt-in-your-mouth-maple-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly grease a large bowl with oil or use nonstick spray. Place the dough in the bowl, turning it to coat all sides in the oil. Cover the bowl with aluminum foil, plastic wrap, or a clean kitchen towel. Allow the dough to rise in a relatively warm environment for 2 hours or until double in size. (I always let it rise on the counter and it takes about 2 hours. For a tiny reduction in rise time, see my answer to Where Should Dough Rise? in my Baking with Yeast Guide.)", "name": "1st Rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/melt-in-your-mouth-maple-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Grease the bottom and sides of a 9&#215;13 baking dish or line with parchment paper.\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/melt-in-your-mouth-maple-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Punch down the dough to release the air. Place dough on a lightly floured work surface and using a lightly floured rolling pin, roll dough into a 12\u00d718-inch rectangle. Make sure the dough is smooth and evenly thick. If the dough keeps shrinking as you roll it out, stop what you\u2019re doing, cover it lightly, and let it rest for 10 minutes to relax the gluten. When you return to the dough, it should stretch out much easier.", "name": "Roll out the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/melt-in-your-mouth-maple-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the butter and maple syrup together on medium-high speed until combined and creamy. Add the sugar and cinnamon, beating until combined. Spread the maple mixture all over the dough. Tightly roll up the dough to form an 18-inch-long log. Cut into 12 even rolls, about 1.5 inches each. Arrange in the prepared baking pan.", "name": "For the filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/melt-in-your-mouth-maple-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover the rolls tightly and allow to rise until puffy, about 90 minutes. (Or use the overnight option in the Notes below.)", "name": "2nd Rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/melt-in-your-mouth-maple-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 375\u00b0F (191\u00b0C).\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/melt-in-your-mouth-maple-cinnamon-rolls/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for about 25 minutes, until they are lightly browned on top. About halfway through the bake time, tent a piece of aluminum foil over the pan to prevent the tops from browning too quickly. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a rubber spatula as needed.\u00a0Beat in the egg whites on high speed until combined, about 2 minutes. Beat in the sour cream and vanilla extract. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed.\u00a0With the mixer on low speed, add the dry ingredients until just incorporated. With the mixer still running on low, slowly pour and mix in the chai milk *just* until combined. Do not overmix. Allow the cupcakes to cool completely before frosting.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chai-latte-cupcakes/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "With a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter on medium speed until creamy, about 2 minutes. Stop the mixer and add 5 and 1/2 cups (660g) confectioners&#8217; sugar, the heavy cream, 1 and 3/4 teaspoons chai spice mix, the vanilla extract, and a pinch of salt. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, then increase to high speed and beat for 2 minutes. If frosting looks curdled or greasy, it&#8217;s best to beat in more confectioners&#8217; sugar to smooth it out. Beat in up to 1/2 cup (60g) more confectioners&#8217; sugar to smooth out if needed. If frosting seems too thick to pipe or spread, beat in another Tablespoon (15ml) of cream. Do not over-beat. Fold in the chopped coconut, making sure the coconut is evenly moistened.", "name": "Make the macaroons", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/coconut-macaroons/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a medium cookie scoop or a spoon, scoop 1.5 Tablespoons (about 30g) of the mixture and arrange on prepared baking sheets at least 2 inches apart. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-cup-oatmeal-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl, whisk the melted butter, granulated sugar, and brown sugar together until no brown sugar lumps remain. Whisk in the egg, then the peanut butter until combined. Finally, whisk in the vanilla. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients and mix together with a large spoon or rubber spatula. The dough will be very soft and slick. Fold in the oats and the 1 and 1/4 cups chopped peanut butter cups, reserving the remaining 1/4 cup for later.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-cup-oatmeal-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Roll the dough into balls, about 3 Tablespoons of dough each. The cookies will look very soft and underbaked. They will continue to bake on the cookie sheet. Remove from the oven and lightly press down on each cookie to slightly flatten, since the cookies will not spread all the way in the oven. Press a piece or two of the remaining chopped peanut butter cups into each cookie. Allow to cool on the cookie sheet for 10 minutes before moving to a wire rack to cool completely.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-cup-oatmeal-cookies/#instruction-step-5"}], "prepTime": "PT10M", "cookTime": "PT12M", "totalTime": "PT45M", "recipeYield": ["16", "16 cookies"], "recipeCategory": "Cookies", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "5", "ratingValue": "5"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "SP"}, "datePublished": "2022-12-02", "reviewBody": "Soo a late night oatmeal cookie craving struck me and when I looked through my pantry I thought I had everything on hand\u2026 except when I looked at my PB jar. Baked until golden brown and served pull-apart style, this snack is truly irresistible. It's flaky, salty, savory, garlicky, and cheesy-- plus it's fun to eat &amp; share.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "everything bagel pull apart bread", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/everything-bagel-pull-apart-bread-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/everything-bagel-pull-apart-bread-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/everything-bagel-pull-apart-bread-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/everything-bagel-pull-apart-bread-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/everything-bagel-pull-apart-bread/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 teaspoons Platinum Yeast from Red Star instant yeast*", "1 Tablespoon granulated sugar", "3/4 cup (180ml)\u00a0whole milk", "3 Tablespoons (43g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 large egg", "2 and 1/3 cups (291g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled), plus more as needed", "1 teaspoon salt", "8 ounces (226g) full-fat brick cream cheese, softened to room temperature", "3 Tablespoons (43g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1-2 teaspoons Italian seasoning*", "1/2 teaspoon garlic powder", "3/4 cup (70g)\u00a0shredded mozzarella cheese", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "1 Tablespoon poppy seeds*", "1 Tablespoon sesame seeds*", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons dried minced onion*", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons dried garlic flakes*", "1 teaspoons coarse sea salt or flaky sea salt", "2 Tablespoons (28g) unsalted butter, melted"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Place the yeast and sugar in the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with a dough hook or paddle attachment. Or, if you do not own a stand mixer, a regular large mixing bowl. Heat the milk on the stove or in the microwave until warm to touch, about 110\u00b0F (43\u00b0C). Pour warm milk on top of yeast/sugar. Whisk gently to combine, then loosely cover with a clean kitchen towel and allow to sit for 5-10 minutes. The mixture will be frothy after 5-10 minutes.", "name": "Make the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/everything-bagel-pull-apart-bread/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Add the butter, egg, flour, and salt. Beat on low speed for 3 minutes. Dough will be soft.", "name": "If you do not have a mixer, you can mix by hand in this step", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/everything-bagel-pull-apart-bread/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Keep the dough in the mixer and beat for an additional 5 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 5 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/everything-bagel-pull-apart-bread/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the dough in a greased bowl (I use nonstick spray to grease) and cover with plastic wrap or aluminum foil. Place in a slightly warm environment to rise until doubled in size, around 60-90 minutes.\u00a0(If desired, use my warm oven trick for rising. See my answer to\u00a0Where Should Dough Rise?\u00a0in my\u00a0Baking with Yeast Guide.)", "name": "1st rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/everything-bagel-pull-apart-bread/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0As the dough rises, prepare the filling and topping in the next steps and grease a 9&#215;5-inch loaf pan.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/everything-bagel-pull-apart-bread/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat all of the filling ingredients together until combined. Cover tightly and set aside until ready to use. (Don&#8217;t refrigerate unless making well in advance. It&#8217;s easiest to spread on the dough when at room temperature. If refrigerated, let it come to room temperature before spreading on dough in step 7.)", "name": "Make the cream cheese filling:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/everything-bagel-pull-apart-bread/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Combine the poppy seeds, sesame seeds, dried minced onion, dried garlic flakes, and coarse salt together in a small bowl. Set aside.", "name": "Make the topping", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/everything-bagel-pull-apart-bread/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Punch down the dough to release the air. Place dough on a lightly floured work surface and with a floured rolling pin, roll out until the dough is about 1/4 inch thick. The dough can be any shape, just as long as it&#8217;s around 1/4 inch thick. Spread cream cheese filling on top. Using a\u00a03.5 &#8211; 4 inch circle cookie cutter, cut into circles. I get about 12 circles. Fold circles in half and line in prepared baking pan, round side up. See photos above for a visual.", "name": "Assemble the bread:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/everything-bagel-pull-apart-bread/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover\u00a0with plastic wrap or aluminum foil and allow to rise once again in a slightly warm environment until puffy, about 45 minutes.", "name": "2nd rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/everything-bagel-pull-apart-bread/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Adjust the oven rack to the lower third position then preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/everything-bagel-pull-apart-bread/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Brush dough with the 2 Tablespoons of melted butter and sprinkle everything bagel seasoning on top. (Use as much of the seasoning as you want; extras can be used for any of the suggestions listed in the post above.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/everything-bagel-pull-apart-bread/#instruction-step-11"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake until golden brown, about 40-45 minutes. If you find the top of the loaf is browning too quickly, tent with aluminum foil. Remove from the oven and place on a wire rack. Cool for 10 minutes in the pan, then remove from the pan and serve warm.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/everything-bagel-pull-apart-bread/#instruction-step-12"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover and store leftovers in the refrigerator for up to 1 week.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/everything-bagel-pull-apart-bread/#instruction-step-13"}], "prepTime": "PT3H", "cookTime": "PT45M", "totalTime": "PT3H55M", "recipeYield": ["1", "1 loaf"], "recipeCategory": "Bread", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "41", "ratingValue": "4.8"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "4"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "SNL"}, "datePublished": "2021-11-20", "reviewBody": "Just wanted to share I made this recipe again with fresh yeast and milk (turns out I really didn't read the recipe well). I loved the bread wih my changes outlined below. My only changes to the bread portion was to use half the sugar, 50/50 flour and replaced the butter for extra virgin olive oil as I'm an Italian at heart. Oh and I kneaded the bread a lot longer, until I could pull it thin without breaking (windowpane test) so I knew the bread would have a better texture. For the filling portion, I rounded the recipe down to a 180g UK pot and that was a perfect ration of cheese to bread IMO. I used  light cream cheese (same flavour, slightly healthier. In the UK we can only get a Philadelphia spredable and that works no problem), replaced butter for olive oil again, half the garlic granules and 1 1/2tsp herby blend called za'atar (oregano, thyme, sumac (lemon like spice) and salt) which I prefer here over Italian seasoning. Lastly I topped my bread with sesame seeds, I tried the everything bagel seasoning and it was WAY too strong in both onion, garlic and salt even after doubling the seed portion so now I have a spice jar full of the stuff which is a shame."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Pamela"}, "datePublished": "2021-11-23", "reviewBody": "I love this recipe! Pour wet ingredients into the dry ingredients, then whisk until just combined. Avoid over-mixing. Batter is thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mini-cinnamon-sugar-pumpkin-muffins/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a small spoon, spoon the batter into the muffin tins, filling each about 2/3 full.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mini-cinnamon-sugar-pumpkin-muffins/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 12-14 or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean or when lightly poked, the muffin bounces back. Use a spoon to help remove the warm muffins from the pan. Lightly dunk a muffin (they can still be a bit warm) in the melted butter. Submerge in the cinnamon-sugar to coat the surface generously. This recipe is also in my New York Times best-selling cookbook, Sally's Baking 101.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "stromboli", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/stromboli-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/stromboli-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/stromboli-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/stromboli.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-stromboli/", "recipeIngredient": ["1\u00a0and 1/3 cups (320ml)\u00a0warm water\u00a0(between 100-110\u00b0F, 38-43\u00b0C)", "2\u00a0and 1/4 teaspoons (7g)\u00a0instant or active-dry yeast\u00a0(1 standard packet)", "1 Tablespoon\u00a0(13g)\u00a0granulated sugar", "2 Tablespoons (30ml)\u00a0olive oil", "1 teaspoon\u00a0salt", "3\u00a0and 1/2 cups (about\u00a0450g)\u00a0all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled), plus more for hands and work surface", "3 Tablespoons (43g) unsalted butter, melted", "2 garlic cloves, minced (or 1/2 teaspoon garlic powder)", "2 teaspoons chopped fresh parsley (or 1 teaspoon dried)", "1\u00a0pound thinly sliced meats such as Italian cold cuts, deli ham, or large pepperoni slices*", "3/4\u20131 pound (340\u2013454g) cheese (about 3 cups shredded or about 16\u201320 slices deli cheese)*", "egg wash: 1 large egg beaten with 1 Tablespoon water", "optional: fresh or dried parsley, flaky sea salt, and/or grated Parmesan"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the warm water, yeast, and granulated sugar together in the bowl of your stand mixer fitted with a dough hook or paddle attachment. Cover and allow to rest for 5 minutes. *If you don\u2019t have a stand mixer, simply use a large mixing bowl and mix the dough with a wooden spoon or silicone spatula in the next step.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-stromboli/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the olive oil, salt, and flour. Beat on low speed for 2 minutes.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-stromboli/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Keep the dough in the mixer (and switch to the dough hook if using the paddle) and beat for an additional 5 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 5 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-stromboli/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToSection", "name": "Rise", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly grease a large bowl with oil or nonstick spray\u2014just use the same bowl you used for the dough. Place the dough in the bowl, turning it to coat all sides in the oil. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap or a clean kitchen towel. Allow the dough to rise at room temperature for 60\u201390 minutes or until doubled in size. For a tiny reduction in rise time, see my answer to Where Should Dough Rise?\u00a0in my\u00a0Baking with Yeast Guide.)", "name": "Rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-stromboli/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 400\u00b0F (204\u00b0). Line 2 large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-stromboli/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "When the dough is risen, punch it down to release the air and divide it in half. (If you aren&#8217;t making 2 strombolis, freeze the other half of the dough. See freezing instructions below.) On a lightly floured work surface using a lightly floured rolling pin, roll each portion of dough into a 10&#215;16-inch rectangle. Use your hands to square off the edges, as shown in the video. If the dough keeps shrinking as you try to shape it, cover it lightly and let the dough rest for 10 minutes before trying again. (The gluten just needs to relax.)", "name": "Shape the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-stromboli/#instruction-step-3"}]}, {"@type": "HowToSection", "name": "tion-step-7\">Add fillings", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Mix the melted butter and garlic together. Using a pastry brush or the back of a spoon, spread the garlic butter evenly over each rectangle. Sprinkle each with parsley. When you start layering on meats and cheeses, leave a 1-inch border on the bottom and sides and a 3-inch border on top. (Basically you&#8217;ll have an empty 3&#215;16-inch gap on top that only has butter/garlic on it. This is because when rolling, the fillings will be pushed forward. See photos and video if you need a visual.) Arrange a layer of sliced meats onto each dough rectangle, usually about 8\u201310 overlapping slices on each, depending on the size of your slices. Add a layer of cheese. Repeat with more meat and cheese until all is used\u2014about 1/2 pound meat and 1/2 pound cheese per stromboli.", "name": "Add fillings", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-stromboli/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Brush the edges with egg wash, including the 3-inch border at the top. Slowly roll each into a tight 16-inch log, folding in the two ends as you roll. Dust your hands or the dough with flour if things become too sticky.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-stromboli/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Carefully transfer each stromboli to a prepared baking sheet. Pinch or tuck in the ends to seal. Brush the top of each stromboli with egg wash and, if using, sprinkle on the optional toppings. Using a sharp knife, cut 3\u20134 slits into the tops of each, which helps steam escape. At this point, you can either bake or cover the shaped stromboli tightly and refrigerate for up to 8 hours.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-stromboli/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for about 25 minutes or until the crust is golden brown\u2014if you have an instant-read thermometer, the center of the stromboli should be at least 200\u00baF (93\u00baC). If meats are particularly greasy (like pepperoni), some grease will spill out the sides. Cheese may bubble out the sides or top slits, too. If baking both at the same time, rotate pans halfway through baking and extend bake time (if needed) by 2\u20133 minutes. Remove from the oven and let cool on the baking sheets for 5 minutes before transferring to a cutting board and slicing.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-stromboli/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Serve plain or with warm pizza/marinara sauce for dipping.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-stromboli/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover and store leftover stromboli (slices or whole) in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-stromboli/#instruction-step-10"}]}], "prepTime": "PT2H", "cookTime": "PT25M", "totalTime": "PT2H30M", "recipeYield": ["16", "two 16 inch strombolis (about 10-12 slices each)"], "recipeCategory": "Dinner", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "Italian", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "769", "ratingValue": "4.9"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Homemade Stromboli | Sally's Baking Addiction", "description": "Here's how to make homemade stromboli using my 6 ingredient pizza dough. Line a large baking sheet with parchment paper or a silicone baking mat. Spread the chopped pecans on top and toast for 7-8 minutes or until fragrant and lightly browned. Set aside. 1 cup will be used inside the toffee and the rest are sprinkled on top.", "name": "Toast the pecans", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-spice-toffee/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "While stirring with a wooden spoon, melt the butter over medium heat in a 3-quart heavy-duty saucepan. Once melted, add the water, 1 cup (200g) granulated sugar, salt, and corn syrup. Stir constantly until the sugar dissolves, then brush down the sides of the pan with a water-moistened pastry brush. Attach a candy thermometer to the pan, making sure the bulb is not touching the bottom of the pan (as you&#8217;ll get an inaccurate reading).", "name": "Make the toffee", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-spice-toffee/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Stir the mixture every minute as it begins to boil. Rapid bubbles, a thicker consistency, and a slightly darker color form around 240\u00b0F (116\u00b0C). Continue to stir every minute until it reaches 290\u00b0F (143\u00b0C; soft crack stage). Be watchful\u2014the temperature slowly rises in the beginning, but then skyrockets quickly. If you notice it&#8217;s rising very fast, you can even turn off the heat when the toffee reaches 285\u00b0F (141\u00b0C), as it will continue to cook in the few seconds after.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-spice-toffee/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Immediately remove the pan from heat and stir in 1 teaspoon pumpkin pie spice and 1 cup toasted pecans. Pour the toffee out onto a silicone baking mat lined baking sheet. Smooth into an even layer. The toffee should be thick and not spread all the way to the edges of the pan. Cool the toffee for 5 minutes.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-spice-toffee/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Meanwhile, get the toppings ready. Mix the remaining 1 Tablespoon of granulated sugar with the remaining 1/4 teaspoon of pumpkin pie spice. Melt the white chocolate. You can melt it in a double boiler or use the microwave. I melt it in the microwave in 20 second increments, stopping and stirring after each.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-spice-toffee/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread the melted white chocolate on top of the toffee, then sprinkle with remaining pecans and sugar/pumpkin pie spice mix.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-spice-toffee/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Refrigerate toffee for 20 minutes or until white chocolate has set. Peel off the silicone baking mat and break toffee into pieces.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-spice-toffee/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Store toffee in an airtight container at room temperature in a cool dry place for up to 2 weeks.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-spice-toffee/#instruction-step-8"}], "prepTime": "PT40M", "cookTime": "PT30M", "totalTime": "PT1H15M", "recipeYield": ["1", "1 pound"], "recipeCategory": "Candy", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "4", "ratingValue": "5"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Pumpkin Spice Toffee | Sally's Baking Addiction", "description": "Make chewy, buttery, and crunchy pumpkin spice toffee on the stove with only 8 ingredients. This creates a creamy base for the frosting. Turn speed to LOW and slowly add 3 cups of confectioners&#8217; sugar, the cocoa powder, and salt. Beat until sugar/cocoa are absorbed into the butter, about 2 minutes. Turn mixer to medium speed and add the vanilla and cream. Once added, turn the mixer to high speed and beat for 1 minute. Add the last 1/2 cup of confectioners&#8217; sugar if you&#8217;d like to increase the frosting&#8217;s thickness. Pipe or spread the frosting onto the cooled cupcakes. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Add the egg yolk, vanilla extract, and peppermint extract and beat on high speed until combined. To thicken the buttercream, beat in more confectioners&#8217; sugar. To thin out the buttercream, beat in more milk. Roll out first pie dough, fill, and bake then roll out the 2nd pie dough, fill, and bake.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mini-quiche-recipe/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Working with 1 chilled pie dough at a time, place the dough onto a floured work surface. Roll into a large 12-inch circle. Use your warm hands to mold any cracking edges back together as you see me doing in the video tutorial above. From the circle, cut rounds using a 2.5 inch cookie cutter. (Sometimes I use my 1/3 cup measuring cup, which is 2.5 inches in diameter.) You\u2019ll have to re-roll the dough scraps a few times. Work quickly, as the dough becomes much more delicate the longer it&#8217;s at room temperature. You&#8217;ll get about 24 rounds per pie crust. Using melted butter, more brown sugar than white sugar, and a touch of cornstarch guarantee the absolute softest, chewiest M&amp;M cookie bar texture.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "M&M cookie bars", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/mm-cookie-bars-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/mm-cookie-bars-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/mm-cookie-bars-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/mm-cookie-bars-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mm-cookie-bars/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 and 3/4 cups (343g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned and leveled)", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons cornstarch", "1 teaspoon baking soda", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "1 cup (16 Tbsp; 226g) unsalted butter, melted &amp; cooled for just 5 minutes*", "1 cup (200g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar", "2 large eggs, at room temperature", "2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1 and 1/4 cups (about 260g) mini or regular-size M&amp;Ms", "3/4 cup (135) semi-sweet chocolate chips"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mm-cookie-bars/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, cornstarch, baking soda, and salt together in a large bowl. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mm-cookie-bars/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl, whisk the melted butter, brown sugar, and granulated sugar together until no brown sugar lumps remain. Whisk in the eggs and vanilla extract. Pour this into the flour mixture and mix together  with a large spoon or silicone spatula. The dough will be very soft, slick, and thick. Fold in the M&amp;Ms and chocolate chips. The M&amp;Ms and chips may not stick to the dough because of the melted butter, but do your best to combine them.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mm-cookie-bars/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Transfer dough to the prepared baking pan and press/smooth into an even layer. Bake for 26\u201330 minutes or until lightly browned on the sides and top and a toothpick inserted in the center comes out mostly clean with a few moist (not wet) crumbs. Do not over-bake. If you notice the bars browning too much before 25 minutes, tent the pan with foil. Bars puff up in the oven, but settle as they cool.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mm-cookie-bars/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Allow the bars to cool in the pan set on a wire rack for at least an hour. These French pastries take a little time to prepare and assemble, so I encourage you to read through the recipe before beginning. You have many options for the filling, including traditional pastry cream, or any of the suggestions in the Notes or above the recipe.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "Homemade Eclairs", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/eclairs-pastry-cream-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/eclairs-pastry-cream-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/eclairs-pastry-cream-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/eclairs-pastry-cream.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-eclairs/", "recipeIngredient": ["4 large egg yolks, cold or room temperature", "3 Tablespoons (23g) cornstarch", "2 cups (480ml) whole milk (do not use low-fat or nondairy)", "1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar", "1 Tablespoon (14g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "seeds scraped from 1/2 vanilla bean (or extra 1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract)", "small pinch salt", "1 batch choux pastry", "egg wash: 1 egg beaten with 1 Tablespoon milk or water", "1/2 cup (120ml) heavy cream", "4 ounces (113g) semi-sweet chocolate, finely chopped"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": ", as it needs at least 3 hours (or up to 24 hours) to chill in the refrigerator before using. In a large heatproof bowl (preferably with a pour spout), whisk the egg yolks and cornstarch together with a fork. It may not look like it will all come together (it will be dry at first), but keep mixing until the mixture is thick and combined. If it&#8217;s not coming together at all, add a few drops of the milk you need in step 3 to bring together. Set aside at room temperature. Combine the milk and sugar in a medium saucepan over medium heat. Whisk until the sugar has dissolved, then bring to a gentle simmer. Remove from heat. Pour the warm milk and sugar mixture in a slow and steady stream into the egg yolk and cornstarch mixture, whisking the entire time. Keep those egg yolks moving so they don\u2019t scramble. Pour the mixture back into the saucepan through a sieve, to strain out any egg yolk solids that may have formed during tempering. Return the saucepan to medium heat, and whisk constantly. The mixture will be frothy on the surface at first, and then it will begin to thicken quickly and large bubbles will begin to burst on the surface. This usually takes about 1\u20132 minutes. Stand back and use caution. Let the bubbles burst for about 20 seconds, or until the mixture has thickened into a custard- or pudding-like consistency. (For a more accurate test, the custard is done when the temperature reaches 185\u2013190\u00b0F (85\u201388\u00b0C).) Remove from heat. Whisk in butter, vanilla extract, vanilla bean seeds, and a pinch of salt. Refrigerate for at least 3 hours, and up to 24 hours. Makes 2\u20132.5 cups, or about 580\u2013610g.", "name": "Make the pastry cream filling first", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-eclairs/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Prepare the choux pastry dough recipe through step 4. You can use the choux pastry dough immediately for the eclairs or cover and refrigerate for up to 3 days.", "name": "Meanwhile, prepare the dough:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-eclairs/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 400\u00b0F (204\u00b0C). Line two baking sheets with parchment paper. Lightly brush the parchment with water, which creates a humid environment for the pastry shells, allowing them to puff up without drying out or burning.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-eclairs/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Transfer choux pastry dough to a piping bag (reusable or disposable) fitted with a large piping tip (I use Ateco #809 piping tip). Pipe 4-inch logs 3 inches apart on the prepared baking sheets. You can also use a zip-top bag and cut off the corner for easy piping. Using a water-moistened finger, smooth down any peaks or ends. Lightly brush each log with egg wash.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-eclairs/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 20 minutes, and then, keeping the pastries in the oven, reduce oven temperature to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C) and continue to bake for 8\u201312 more minutes until golden brown. Do not open the oven as the pastries cook, as cool air will prevent them from properly puffing up. Remove from the oven and transfer to a cooling rack. Allow to cool completely before filling.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-eclairs/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place chopped chocolate in a bowl. Heat the cream in a small saucepan until it begins to gently simmer. (Do not let it come to a rapid boil\u2014that&#8217;s too hot!) Pour over chocolate and let it sit for 2\u20133 minutes to soften the chocolate. Slowly stir until chocolate has melted and combined completely with the cream. Cool for 15 minutes, so it reaches the perfect consistency for dipping/coating. Chocolate ganache will be thin at first, but will thicken up as it cools.", "name": "Make the chocolate ganache:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-eclairs/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToSection", "name": "tion-step-7\">Fill the eclairs", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Transfer chilled pastry cream to a piping bag (reusable or disposable) fitted with a small-ish round or open star piping tip. I suggest Wilton piping round tip 12, which is wide enough for the filling to pipe out, but you can still nudge it inside the eclair. Use a toothpick to prick a hole in 1 end of each eclair shell. Gently nudge the piping tip into the hole. Carefully pipe pastry cream into each eclair shell, stopping when it feels full. Pipe the cream from both ends of the eclair if you notice it&#8217;s not reaching the other end. (Don&#8217;t have a piping tip for this? Slice the eclair in half horizontally, then sandwich filling inside.)", "name": "Fill the eclairs", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-eclairs/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Dip the top of each eclair into chocolate ganache and place on a serving plate or cooling rack until ready to serve. Chocolate ganache topping sets in about an hour at room temperature or in about 30 minutes in the refrigerator.", "name": "Top the eclairs", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-eclairs/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover and store leftover filled pastries in the refrigerator for up to 3 days. Cover and store unfilled pastry shells at room temperature for 1 day, in the refrigerator for 5 days, or freeze for up to 3 months. Thaw in the refrigerator before filling and serving.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-eclairs/#instruction-step-9"}]}], "prepTime": "PT30M", "cookTime": "PT35M", "totalTime": "PT1H45M", "recipeYield": ["16", "16 eclairs"], "recipeCategory": "Dessert", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "French", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "33", "ratingValue": "4.9"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Homemade Eclairs with Peanut Butter Mousse Filling | Sally's Baking Recipes", "description": "Homemade choux pastry has never been easier! See recipe notes for freezing and overnight instructions.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "apple cinnamon babka, apple bread", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/apple-cinnamon-babka-3-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/apple-cinnamon-babka-3-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/apple-cinnamon-babka-3-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/apple-cinnamon-babka-3.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cinnamon-babka/", "recipeIngredient": ["2/3 cup (160ml) whole milk, warmed to about 110\u00b0F (43\u00b0C)", "2\u00a0and 1/4 teaspoons (7g)\u00a0Platinum Yeast from Red Star\u00a0(1 standard packet)*", "1/3 cup (62g) granulated sugar, divided", "5 Tablespoons (71g) unsalted butter, sliced into 1 Tbsp-size pieces and softened to room temperature", "2 large egg yolks (reserve 2 egg whites for filling and topping)", "1 teaspoon salt", "2 and 2/3 cups (334g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled), plus more as needed and extra for work surface and hands", "3 Tablespoons (43g) unsalted butter, divided", "2 large apples, peeled and thinly sliced into bite-size pieces (2\u20132.5 cups, or 250\u2013313g)*", "1 teaspoon lemon juice", "1 cup (200g) packed light or dark brown sugar (or a mix of both)", "1/4 cup (31g) all-purpose flour", "2 and 1/2 teaspoons ground cinnamon", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1 large egg white (reserved from dough)", "2 Tablespoons (25g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "2 Tablespoons (15g) all-purpose flour", "1/4 teaspoon\u00a0ground cinnamon", "2 Tablespoons (28g) unsalted butter, cold and cubed", "1 egg white (reserved from dough)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the warm milk, yeast, and 1 Tablespoon of sugar together in the bowl of your stand mixer fitted with a dough hook or paddle attachment. Cover and allow to sit for 5 minutes. *If you don&#8217;t have a stand mixer, use a handheld mixer or mix the dough by hand using a silicone spatula or wooden spoon.*", "name": "Prepare the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cinnamon-babka/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the remaining sugar, the butter, egg yolks, salt, and 1 cup (125g) flour. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, scrape down the sides of the bowl with a silicone spatula, then add another 1 cup of flour. Beat on medium speed until relatively incorporated (there may still be chunks of butter). Scrape down the sides of the bowl with a silicone spatula. Add 1/2 cup of flour and beat on medium speed until the dough begins to come together. As the mixer runs, add another 2\u20134 Tablespoons of flour depending on how wet the dough looks. (I usually add another 2 Tbsp, which makes it about 2 and 2/3 cups of flour total.) This should be a very soft and almost creamy-feeling dough. Do not add more flour than you need.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cinnamon-babka/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Keep the dough in the mixer (and switch to the dough hook if using the paddle) and beat for an additional 6-8 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 6-8 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise.", "name": "Knead the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cinnamon-babka/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly grease a large bowl with nonstick spray. Place the dough in the bowl, turning it to coat all sides. Cover the bowl with aluminum foil, plastic wrap, or a clean kitchen towel. Allow the dough to rise in a relatively warm environment for 3\u20134 hours or until nearly double in size. This dough is rich with fat, so it takes longer than other doughs to rise. (If desired, use my warm oven trick for rising. See my answer to Where Should Dough Rise?\u00a0in my\u00a0Baking with Yeast Guide.)", "name": "1st Rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cinnamon-babka/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Melt 1 Tablespoon of butter in a large skillet on the stove over medium heat. Add the apples. Stir and cook until the apples are slightly softened, about 3 minutes. Remove from heat and stir in lemon juice to help prevent browning. Set aside. For the rest of the filling in this step, make sure you don&#8217;t prepare it too far in advance because the butter will solidify and spreading onto the dough will be difficult. Melt remaining 2 Tablespoons of butter in a medium heatproof bowl in the microwave (or use the stove). Stir in brown sugar, flour, cinnamon, salt, and vanilla extract until crumbly and combined. Stir in the egg white. Set aside.", "name": "Towards the end of rise time, you can prepare the filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cinnamon-babka/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Grease a 9\u00d75-inch loaf pan.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cinnamon-babka/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "When the dough is ready, punch it down to release the air. Flour a work surface, your hands, and a rolling pin. Roll the dough out into a 12&#215;16-inch rectangle. Carefully and slowly spread the cinnamon filling mixture on top. (The dough is quite soft underneath and you don&#8217;t want to tear it.) Add the apples in a single layer. Using floured hands, tightly roll up the dough to form a 16-inch long log. If any parts of the dough feel soft as you roll it up, add a sprinkle of flour as I do in the video above. Place the log on its seam. Fold in half, then twist it to form a figure 8. Pinch the ends together. Use the video tutorial and photos above as a visual. Place in prepared loaf pan.", "name": "Shape the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cinnamon-babka/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover shaped babka with aluminum foil, plastic wrap, or a clean kitchen towel. Allow to rise until it&#8217;s puffy and nearly reaches the top of the loaf pan, about 1\u20131.5 hours.", "name": "2nd Rise:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cinnamon-babka/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Mix the brown sugar, flour, and cinnamon together. Add the cold butter and using a pastry cutter or a fork, cut butter into the brown sugar mixture until pea-size crumbles form. Refrigerate until ready to use.", "name": "Towards the end of rise time, you can prepare the crumble topping:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cinnamon-babka/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Place a baking sheet on a lower oven rack to catch any juices or crumbles that may drip/drop down. (Has only happened to me once!)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cinnamon-babka/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Carefully brush the surface of the babka with last remaining egg white. Using a toothpick, poke 10\u201312 holes all over the top of the loaf. This allows steam to escape from inside the loaf so the layers don&#8217;t separate. Sprinkle with crumble topping.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cinnamon-babka/#instruction-step-11"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 60\u201365 minutes or until golden brown on top. If you gently tap on the loaf, it should sound hollow. If you notice the top browning too quickly, loosely tent the pan with aluminum foil. (I usually add aluminum foil over the loaf around the 25-minute mark.) Remove from the oven and allow bread to cool in the pan for at least 30 minutes before slicing and serving. For neat slices as pictured above, I recommend cooling completely before slicing. A serrated knife is best for slicing.", "name": "Bake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cinnamon-babka/#instruction-step-12"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftover babka tightly and store at room temperature for 2 days or in the refrigerator for up to 1 week.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-cinnamon-babka/#instruction-step-13"}], "prepTime": "PT5H", "cookTime": "PT1H", "totalTime": "PT6H30M", "recipeYield": ["1", "1 loaf"], "recipeCategory": "Bread", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "Jewish", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "113", "ratingValue": "4.7"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Apple Cinnamon Babka  | Sally's Baking Addiction", "description": "This apple cinnamon babka features sweet apples and a thick cinnamon filling twisted inside a rich and buttery yeasted dough. Line a large baking sheet with parchment paper or a silicone baking mat. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/crispy-baked-buffalo-chicken-fingers/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the corn flakes, salt, pepper, garlic powder, and smoked paprika into a food processor (you can do this in stages if the processor isn&#8217;t large enough). Pulse 4-5 times until\u00a0the cereal\u00a0is broken down. Not completely crushed; some larger pieces can remain. Pour into a large bowl. Place the flour into a separate bowl. Then in a third bowl,\u00a0whisk the eggs and milk together.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/crispy-baked-buffalo-chicken-fingers/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Coat each chicken strip in flour, shaking off any excess. Then, dip in egg mixture and let any excess drip off. Then generously roll in the corn flakes, shaking off any excess.\u00a0Place the chicken strips on the prepared baking sheet.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/crispy-baked-buffalo-chicken-fingers/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 10 minutes. Turn each piece over and continue baking until the outside is crisp and the centers are cooked through, about more 10 minutes. Baking times may vary, just make sure the chicken is\u00a0cooked through by cutting into a thick piece. If you like them browner, bake a couple minutes longer. Careful, you don&#8217;t want to dry out the chicken inside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/crispy-baked-buffalo-chicken-fingers/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Allow to cool for 5 minutes on the baking sheet (we usually make the blue cheese sauce during this time), then carefully place the chicken fingers into a large bowl. Roll it into a ball. The cookies are rather large, but if you&#8217;d like them smaller, make each dough ball only 1 Tablespoon. Drop dough ball onto a baking sheet lined with a silicone baking mat or parchment paper. Make sure the balls of dough are tall. Do not flatten them. Bake for 10-11 minutes or until edges are slightly browned. The centers should appear soft and puffy. Allow to cool on the baking sheet for 5 minutes before moving to a cooking rack. Set aside.", "name": "Make the cookies", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-ricotta-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "With a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on high speed until creamy, about 2 minutes. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. With the mixer running on low speed, add the eggs one at a time, then add the ricotta cheese, vanilla extract, almond extract (if using), lemon zest, and lemon juice. Beat on medium-high speed until combined. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. Add the dry ingredients. On low speed, beat everything just until incorporated. Do not overmix. Dough will be very creamy, sticky, and thick. Discard or crumble and use as cake garnish or enjoy over ice cream! Place 1 cake layer on your cake stand, cake turntable, or serving plate. Evenly cover the top with 1/2 of the vanilla frosting. Top with 2nd layer and evenly cover the top with the rest of the vanilla frosting. Top with the third cake layer. Spread the strawberry frosting into a thick layer all over the top and sides. Garnish with sprinkles, if desired. Refrigerate for at least 30 minutes before slicing. Pack those apples into the pan\u2014this cake can hold a lot and you won't regret those extra slices!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "apples, caramel, upside down cake", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/apple-upside-down-cake-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/apple-upside-down-cake-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/apple-upside-down-cake-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/apple-upside-down-cake-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/buttery-caramel-apple-upside-down-cake/", "recipeIngredient": ["6 Tablespoons (85g)\u00a0unsalted butter", "1/2 cup (100g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1/4 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "1/4 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "2 medium apples, peeled and sliced into 1/4-inch slices (1.5\u20132 cups, or 188\u2013250g, apple slices)*", "1 and 1/2 cups (188g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons baking powder", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons ground cinnamon", "1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar", "1/2 cup (100g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "2 large eggs, at room temperature", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "6 Tablespoons (90ml) whole milk, at room temperature*"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/buttery-caramel-apple-upside-down-cake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Combine butter and brown sugar together in a small saucepan over medium heat. Whisk occasionally until butter has melted. Cook, whisking constantly, for 1 minute as mixture thickens. Remove from heat and whisk in the cinnamon and vanilla extract. Pour into an ungreased 9&#215;2 inch pie dish or round cake pan. (Make sure the pan is 2 inches deep. I recommend this pie dish, which is 1.8 inches deep but I never have an overflow issue.) Arrange the apple slices neatly on top, overlapping where necessary. See photo above. Place pan in the refrigerator for a few minutes as you prepare the cake batter. This helps solidify or &#8220;set&#8221; the topping&#8217;s arrangement.", "name": "Prepare topping first:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/buttery-caramel-apple-upside-down-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, baking powder, cinnamon, nutmeg, and salt together. Set aside.", "name": "Make the cake batter:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/buttery-caramel-apple-upside-down-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the butter on high speed until smooth and creamy, about 1 minute. Add both sugars and beat on high speed until creamed together, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a rubber spatula as needed. On high speed, beat in the eggs and vanilla extract until combined. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. Pour the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients. Turn the mixer onto low speed and as the mixer runs, slowly pour in the milk. Beat on low speed just until all of the ingredients are combined. Do not over-mix. You may need to whisk it all by hand to make sure there are no lumps at the bottom of the bowl. The batter will be slightly thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/buttery-caramel-apple-upside-down-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove topping from the refrigerator. Pour and spread cake batter evenly over topping.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/buttery-caramel-apple-upside-down-cake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 40\u201346 minutes, tenting foil on top of the cake halfway through bake time to prevent the top from over-browning before the center has a chance to fully cook. The cake is done when a toothpick inserted into the center of the cake comes out mostly clean\u2014a couple moist crumbs are OK. Don&#8217;t be alarmed if your cake takes longer or if the cake rises up and sticks to the foil. (We serve the cake upside down anyway!)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/buttery-caramel-apple-upside-down-cake/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove cake from the oven and cool on a wire rack for just 15 minutes. Invert the slightly cooled cake onto a cake stand or serving plate. Some of the juices from the topping will seep over the sides\u2014that&#8217;s ok. You can slice and serve the cake warm, but the slices will be messy. I find it&#8217;s best to cool the cake completely at room temperature before slicing and serving. Do not refrigerate the cake to speed up the cooling process because it could end up tasting overly dense.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/buttery-caramel-apple-upside-down-cake/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftover slices and store for up to 3 days in the refrigerator or 3 months in the freezer. Thaw at room temperature. I don&#8217;t recommend freezing the cake as a whole because the topping arrangement doesn&#8217;t thaw very nicely. See make ahead instructions below.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/buttery-caramel-apple-upside-down-cake/#instruction-step-8"}], "prepTime": "PT25M", "cookTime": "PT45M", "totalTime": "PT1H30M", "recipeYield": ["8", "serves 8-10"], "recipeCategory": "Dessert", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "168", "ratingValue": "4.8"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Caramel Apple Upside Down Cake | Sally's Baking Recipes", "description": "This caramel apple upside down cake combines a soft cinnamon-spiced cake with buttery caramelized apples\u2014two desserts in one. You can make the raspberry sweet rolls within a few hours, or get started the night before using the overnight option in the Note below.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "raspberry sweet rolls", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/raspberry-sweet-rolls-cream-cheese-icing-4-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/raspberry-sweet-rolls-cream-cheese-icing-4-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/raspberry-sweet-rolls-cream-cheese-icing-4-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/raspberry-sweet-rolls-cream-cheese-icing-4.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-swirl-sweet-rolls/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup (240ml) whole milk, warmed to about 100\u00b0F (38\u00b0C)", "2/3 cup (135g) granulated sugar, divided", "1 and 1/2 Tablespoons (14g) Platinum Yeast from Red Star\u00a0(2 standard-size packets)*", "1/2 cup (113g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature and cut into 4 pieces", "2 large eggs, at room temperature", "1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract or vanilla bean paste", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "4 and 1/2 cups (563g) all-purpose flour or bread flour (spooned &amp; leveled), plus more as needed", "2 teaspoons canola, vegetable, or olive oil for bowl (or use nonstick spray)", "one 10-oz. package (about 2.5 cups or 300g) frozen raspberries (do not thaw)", "1/3 cup (67g) granulated sugar", "1 teaspoon cornstarch", "4 ounces (113g) full-fat brick cream cheese, softened to room temperature", "1 cup (120g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1 Tablespoon (30ml) whole milk or heavy cream", "1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract or vanilla bean paste"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the warm milk, 2 Tablespoons sugar, and the yeast together in the bowl of your stand mixer fitted with a dough hook or paddle attachment. Cover and allow mixture to sit for about 5 minutes or until foamy on top. *If you do not own a mixer, you can do this in a large mixing bowl and in the next step, mix the dough together with a large wooden spoon/silicone spatula. It will take a bit of arm muscle. A hand mixer works, but the sticky dough repeatedly gets stuck in the beaters. Mixing by hand with a wooden spoon or silicone spatula is a better choice.*", "name": "Prepare the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-swirl-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "On medium speed, beat in the remaining sugar (which should be 1/2 cup/100g) and the softened butter until it is slightly broken up. Add the eggs, vanilla, and salt and beat on medium speed until combined. The butter won&#8217;t really be mixing into the mixture, so don&#8217;t be alarmed if it stays in pieces. Switch the mixer down to low speed and with it running, add 1 cup of flour at a time, making sure it&#8217;s fully incorporated before adding the next. After 4 cups have been added, add the last 1/2 cup and beat until the dough comes together and pulls away from the sides of the bowl, about 3 minutes. Dough will be soft.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-swirl-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Keep the dough in the mixer (and switch to the dough hook if you used the paddle) and beat for an additional 5 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 5 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-swirl-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly grease a large bowl with oil or use nonstick spray. Place the dough in the bowl, turning it to coat all sides in the oil. Cover the bowl with aluminum foil, plastic wrap, or a clean kitchen towel. Allow the dough to rise in a relatively warm environment for 2 hours or until double in size. (I always let it rise on the counter and it takes about 2 hours. For a tiny reduction in rise time, see my answer to Where Should Dough Rise?\u00a0in my\u00a0Baking with Yeast Guide.)", "name": "1st Rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-swirl-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Grease the bottom and sides of a metal or glass 9&#215;13-inch baking dish or line with parchment paper.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-swirl-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Punch down the dough to release the air. Place dough on a lightly floured work surface and using a lightly floured rolling pin, roll dough into a 12&#215;18-inch rectangle. Make sure the dough is smooth and evenly thick. If the dough keeps shrinking as you roll it out, stop what you&#8217;re doing, cover it lightly, and let it rest for 10 minutes to relax the gluten. When you return to the dough, it should stretch out much easier.", "name": "Roll out the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-swirl-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl, toss the frozen raspberries with the sugar and cornstarch. Spread the cold sugared raspberries evenly over the dough. Tightly roll up the dough to form an 18-inch-long log. With an extra sharp knife, cut into 12 even rolls, about 1.5 inches each. Arrange in the prepared baking pan.", "name": "Make the filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-swirl-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover the rolls tightly and allow to rise until puffy, about 90 minutes. (Or use the overnight option in the Notes below.) The berries will release their juice at the bottom of the pan\u2014this is OK.", "name": "2nd Rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-swirl-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-swirl-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for about 28\u201332 minutes or until they are lightly browned on top. About halfway through baking time, tent a piece of aluminum foil over the pan to prevent the tops from browning too quickly. Remove pan from the oven and place pan on a wire rack for about 10 minutes as you make the icing.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-swirl-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the cream cheese on medium speed until smooth and creamy. Add the confectioners&#8217; sugar, cream/milk, and vanilla. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, then switch to high speed and beat for 1 minute. Spread the icing over the warm rolls and serve immediately.", "name": "Make the icing", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-swirl-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-11"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftover frosted or unfrosted rolls tightly and store at room temperature for up to 2 days or in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-swirl-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-12"}], "prepTime": "PT4H", "cookTime": "PT28M", "totalTime": "PT4H40M", "recipeYield": ["12", "12 rolls"], "recipeCategory": "Breakfast", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "40", "ratingValue": "4.9"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Raspberry Swirl Sweet Rolls | Sally's Baking Recipes", "description": "In this recipe, buttery dough spirals around a juicy, sweet-tart raspberry filling made from frozen raspberries. You can make the sweet rolls within a few hours, or get started the night before using the overnight option. Top with vanilla or cream cheese icing for an unforgettable breakfast experience. \n\nGet the full recipe: https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-swirl-sweet-rolls/\n\n\u2022 Ask your recipe question or leave a review over on the recipe page.\n\n#baking #recipes #raspberryrolls\n\n\u2022 More of Sally's baking recipes: https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/", "duration": "PT4M", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/6a00pKsO8pQ?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6a00pKsO8pQ", "thumbnailUrl": ["https://i.ytimg.com/vi/6a00pKsO8pQ/hqdefault.jpg"], "uploadDate": "2023-08-09T10:02:17+00:00"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Desiree"}, "datePublished": "2024-11-28", "reviewBody": "Loved this recipe. Wasn\u2019t as sweet as I thought it would be.   The texture was really nice. I\u2019m gonna make it again.  Thank you"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Steph"}, "datePublished": "2024-12-04", "reviewBody": "LOVE this recipe. It turned out so well. I want to make it again but I have 2 questions. Is there any gluten free alternative? And for the first rise would I be able to leave it to rise overnight or will that be too long?"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "3"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Tamera"}, "datePublished": "2024-12-23", "reviewBody": "The flavor is great and tart as expected with Raspberries. It is not as sweet as other rolls like this, even with the frosting on the top. The tartness definitely stands out which I absolutely love. However, I am not sure I am a fan of the seeds in the raspberries. There is so many seeds in it that it takes away from texture of the bread. I also found that they do not rise as good in the center as they do on the edges because of the frozen raspberries (as you mentioned in the instructions). My recommendation would be to make a jam/filling out of the raspberries that has the seeds removed and, once cooled, spread it over the dough. I will make this again and try the jam idea and see how it works. I don't think all the seeds work unless you just happen to like raspberry seeds."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "4"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Tiffany"}, "datePublished": "2025-02-18", "reviewBody": "The flavor of these was great. Cold crumbs hold their shape in the oven.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "apple crumb cake", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/glazed-apple-crumb-cake-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/glazed-apple-crumb-cake-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/glazed-apple-crumb-cake-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/glazed-apple-crumb-cake.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-crumb-cake/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup (200g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar", "1 Tablespoon ground cinnamon", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "1 cup (16 Tbsp; 226g) unsalted butter, melted", "2 and 1/2 cups (313g) all purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "2 and 1/2 cups (313g) all purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 teaspoon baking soda", "1/2 teaspoon baking powder", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 and 1/4 cups (250g) granulated sugar", "3 large eggs, at room temperature", "1 cup (240g) full-fat sour cream, at room temperature*", "2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "3 cups (375g) peeled chopped apples (about 2-3 large apples, see Note)", "1/4 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "optional: maple icing,\u00a0vanilla icing, or caramel icing from apple cinnamon rolls"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C) and grease a glass or metal 9&#215;13-inch baking pan or line with parchment paper. Add the butter and beat until combined, scraping down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. Add granulated sugar and beat on medium-high speed until smooth and creamy, about 2 minutes. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Add the egg, lemon zest, vanilla extract, and almond extract and beat on high speed until combined, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl and beat again as needed to combine.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apricot-cream-cheese-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the flour mixture to the wet ingredients and beat on low until combined. Dough gets sticky as you roll, so feel free to lightly dust your hands with all-purpose flour or confectioners&#8217; sugar as you work. Roll each ball into sliced almonds. Arrange 3 inches apart on the baking sheets. Indent your thumb or the bottom end of a silicone spatula or wooden spoon into the center of each dough ball to make a crevice. Spoon a heaping 1/2 teaspoon jam/preserves into each indent. *These cookies do have the tendency to spread especially if the dough has been sitting out and handled long enough before baking. Placing the shaped thumbprints in the refrigerator for 10 minutes before baking helps. You can place the entire baking sheet in the refrigerator, then place in the oven to bake.*", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apricot-cream-cheese-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 14-15 minutes or until lightly browned on the sides.
