A generous drizzle of orange icing over the warm rolls seals the deal: citrus lovers may never go back to regular cinnamon rolls! You can make the rolls within a few hours or get started the night before using the overnight preparation option.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally McKenney", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "orange sweet rolls", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/iced-orange-sweet-rolls-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/iced-orange-sweet-rolls-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/iced-orange-sweet-rolls-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/iced-orange-sweet-rolls.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/orange-sweet-rolls/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup\u00a0(240ml)\u00a0whole milk, warmed to about 100\u00b0F (38\u00b0C)", "6 Tablespoons (75g) granulated sugar, divided", "1 Tablespoon (9g) active dry or instant yeast", "5 Tablespoons (71g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "2 Tablespoons (30ml) freshly squeezed orange juice", "1 Tablespoon fresh orange zest (about 1 orange)", "2 large eggs, at room temperature", "1 teaspoon salt", "4 cups (530g) bread flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled), plus more as needed for hands/work surface", "6 Tablespoons (85g) unsalted butter, extra softened", "1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar (or brown sugar)", "1 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "1 Tablespoon fresh orange zest (about 1 orange)", "1 and 1/4 cups (150g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "3 Tablespoons (45ml) freshly squeezed orange juice", "1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the warm milk, 2 Tablespoons sugar, and the yeast together in the bowl of your stand mixer fitted with a dough hook attachment. Cover and allow mixture to sit for about 5 minutes or until foamy on top. *If you do not own a mixer, you can do this in a large mixing bowl and in the next step, mix the dough together with a large wooden spoon/silicone spatula. It will take a bit of arm muscle. A hand mixer works, but the sticky dough repeatedly gets stuck in the beaters. Mixing by hand with a wooden spoon or silicone spatula is a better choice.*", "name": "Prepare the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/orange-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the remaining sugar, the butter, orange juice, orange zest, eggs, salt, and 1 cup (about 130g) of flour and beat on medium speed for 1 minute. Stop and scrape down the sides of the bowl. Add 3 more cups (about 400g) flour and beat on low speed until a soft dough forms and pulls away from the sides of the bowl. Dough will be very soft, but should not feel overly sticky. If dough seems too soft and sticky to knead by hand, beat in a little more flour, 1 Tablespoon at a time, until dough pulls away from the sides of the bowl and wraps itself around the dough hook.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/orange-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Keep the dough in the mixer and beat on low speed for an additional 6\u20138 full minutes; or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 6\u20138 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/orange-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly grease a large bowl with oil or nonstick spray. Place the dough in the bowl, turning it to coat all sides in the oil. Cover the bowl with aluminum foil, plastic wrap, or a clean kitchen towel. Allow the dough to rise in a relatively warm environment for 1.5\u20132 hours or until about double in size. (I always let it rise on the counter and it takes about 2 hours. For a tiny reduction in rise time, see my answer to Where Should Dough Rise?\u00a0in my\u00a0Baking with Yeast Guide.)", "name": "1st rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/orange-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Grease the bottom and sides of a metal or glass 9\u00d713-inch baking dish, or line with parchment paper.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/orange-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Punch down the dough to release the air. Place dough on a lightly floured work surface and with a lightly floured rolling pin, roll dough into a 10\u00d716-inch rectangle. Make sure the dough is smooth and evenly thick. If the dough keeps shrinking as you roll it out, stop what you\u2019re doing, cover it lightly, and let it rest for 10 minutes to relax the gluten. When you return to the dough, it should stretch out much easier.", "name": "Roll out the dough:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/orange-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread the softened butter all over the dough. The softer the butter is, the easier it is to spread. Mix the remaining filling ingredients together until the zest has moistened it (use your fingers if needed), then sprinkle evenly on top of the butter. Tightly roll up the dough to form a 16-inch-long log. With an extra sharp knife, cut into 12 even rolls, between 1\u20131.5 inches wide each. Arrange in the prepared baking pan.", "name": "For the filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/orange-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover the rolls tightly and allow to rise until puffy, about 30\u201345 minutes. (Or use the overnight option in the Notes below.)", "name": "2nd rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/orange-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to\u00a0350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Bake rolls for about 25\u201328 minutes or until they are lightly browned on top. After about 15 minutes, loosely tent a piece of aluminum foil over the top of the pan to prevent the tops from browning too quickly. If you have an instant-read thermometer, the rolls&#8217; internal temperature should reach 190\u00b0F (88\u00b0C). Remove pan from the oven and place on a cooling rack to cool slightly (about 10 minutes) while you make the icing.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/orange-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a small bowl or liquid measuring cup, whisk confectioners&#8217; sugar, orange juice, and vanilla extract together until combined and smooth. Drizzle over the warm rolls and serve immediately.", "name": "Make the icing", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/orange-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftover sweet rolls tightly and store at room temperature for up to 2 days, or in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/orange-sweet-rolls/#instruction-step-11"}], "prepTime": "PT1H", "cookTime": "PT25M", "totalTime": "PT4H30M", "recipeYield": ["12", "12 rolls"], "recipeCategory": "Breakfast", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "51", "ratingValue": "4.8"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Terry"}, "datePublished": "2025-05-28", "reviewBody": "This recipe was so easy to follow. I\u2019d definitely make this again!"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Emmarie S"}, "datePublished": "2025-05-31", "reviewBody": "This was a fun recipe to make. When you're ready to serve, torch the marshmallow topping\u2014campfire style!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "no bake s'mores cake", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/smores-icebox-cake-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/smores-icebox-cake-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/smores-icebox-cake-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/smores-icebox-cake.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/no-bake-smores-cake/", "recipeIngredient": ["three 4-ounce bars (339g) semi-sweet or milk chocolate, finely chopped*", "1 and 1/2 cups (360ml) heavy cream", "6 egg whites, at room temperature", "1 and 1/2 cups (300g) granulated sugar", "3/4 teaspoon cream of tartar", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "30-36 full-sheet graham crackers (a little over 1 standard box)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Line an 8-inch square baking pan or 9-inch square baking pan with parchment paper, leaving an overhang on the sides to lift the cake out (makes cutting and serving possible!). Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/no-bake-smores-cake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place chopped chocolate in a bowl. Heat the cream in a small saucepan until it begins to gently simmer. (Do not let it come to a rapid boil\u2014that&#8217;s too hot!) Pour over chocolate and let it sit for 2-3 minutes to gently soften the chocolate. Slowly stir until completely combined and chocolate has melted. Cover and refrigerate as you make the meringue. Ganache can be prepared, covered, and refrigerated for up to 3 days before using.", "name": "Make the ganache", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/no-bake-smores-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place egg whites, sugar, and cream of tartar in a heatproof bowl. Set bowl over a saucepan filled with two inches of simmering water. Do not let it touch the water. (You can use a double boiler if you have one.) Whisk constantly until sugar is dissolved and mixture has thinned out, about 4 minutes. Add the vanilla extract, then using a\u00a0handheld or stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, beat on high speed for 5-6 minutes until stiff glossy peaks form. Remove 1 heaping cup (just eyeball it), cover tightly, and refrigerate for up to 2 days. This will be the topping.", "name": "Make the marshmallow meringue", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/no-bake-smores-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If the marshmallow meringue and ganache are still slightly warm as you assemble the cake, that&#8217;s ok. Spread a super thin layer of marshmallow meringue on the bottom of the pan. Doesn&#8217;t need to be even or perfect; it&#8217;s just so the graham cracker base has something to stick to. Do the best you can with the marshmallow meringue because it&#8217;s sticky. Spread it slowly. Top with a layer of graham crackers. You&#8217;ll need to break them apart to evenly arrange them; see my video below for a visual. Top with a layer of marshmallow meringue, then another layer of graham crackers, then a layer of chocolate ganache, then a layer of graham crackers, then another layer of marshmallow meringue. Repeat for a total of 6 layers of graham crackers, 4 layers of marshmallow meringue (including the thin bottom layer), and 3 layers of chocolate ganache. The top layer will be chocolate for now. Layers listed out: super thin marshmallow meringue, graham crackers, marshmallow meringue, graham crackers, chocolate, graham crackers, marshmallow meringue, graham crackers, chocolate, graham crackers, marshmallow meringue, graham crackers, chocolate.", "name": "Assemble the cake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/no-bake-smores-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover tightly and refrigerate for at least 12 hours and up to 2 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/no-bake-smores-cake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove reserved marshmallow meringue from the refrigerator. Spread marshmallow meringue on top. Use a spoon to create peaks and swirls. (Parchment is used so you can easily remove the shortbread and not cut it while it&#8217;s in the pan.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/salted-chocolate-pistachio-shortbread/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with paddle attachment, beat the butter on high speed until completely smooth, about 1 minute. Add the vanilla, salt, and flour and\u00a0beat on low speed, gradually increasing to high speed as the mixture combines. Add 2/3 cup of the finely chopped pistachios, reserving the rest for sprinkling on top of the chocolate. Dough will be very crumbly.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/salted-chocolate-pistachio-shortbread/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Press 1/2 of the dough into each of the prepared cake pans. You want to make sure you cut the shortbread while it&#8217;s still warm. 56g) unsalted butter, cold and cubed", "3 large eggs", "1 Tablespoon (15ml) canola or vegetable oil\u00a0(or melted coconut oil)", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "3/4 cup (75g) pistachios", "3/4 cup (120g) dried cranberries", "egg wash:\u00a01 large egg beaten\u00a0with 1 Tablespoon (15ml) milk", "8 &#8211; 10 (226g &#8211; 282g) ounces white chocolate, coarsely chopped*"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).\u00a0Line two\u00a0large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats.\u00a0(Always recommended\u00a0for cookies.)\u00a0Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/white-chocolate-cranberry-pistachio-biscotti/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, brown sugar, baking powder, cinnamon, and salt together in a large bowl until combined. Using a pastry cutter or 2 forks, cut in the butter until the mixture is crumbly. Set aside. In a medium bowl, whisk the eggs, oil, and vanilla together. Pour into the flour/butter mixture and gently mix together until everything is just barely moistened. Fold in the pistachios and dried cranberries.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/white-chocolate-cranberry-pistachio-biscotti/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Turn dough out onto a lightly floured surface and with floured hands, knead lightly until the dough is soft and slightly sticky, about 8-10 times. If it&#8217;s uncontrollably sticky, knead\u00a01-2 more Tablespoon(s) of flour into the dough. Divide the dough in two and place each half onto a baking sheet. Shape each half\u00a0into an 8-9 inch long roll, patting down until each is about 1/2 inch thick. Using a pastry brush, lightly brush the top and sides of each biscotti slab with egg wash.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/white-chocolate-cranberry-pistachio-biscotti/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake in batches (or together)\u00a0for 25-26 minutes, or until the top and sides of the biscotti slabs are lightly browned.\u00a0Remove from the oven, but do not turn off the heat. Allow\u00a0to cool for 10 minutes. Once the slabs are cool enough to handle, cut each\u00a0into\u00a01 inch\u00a0thick slices. Set\u00a0slices cut sides upright, \u00bc inch apart, on the\u00a0baking\u00a0sheets.\u00a0Return to the oven to continue baking for 8 minutes.\u00a0Turn biscotti\u00a0over and bake other side for 8 minutes. The cookies will be slightly soft in the centers with harder edges. Remove from the oven and allow to cool for 5 minutes on the baking sheet. Transfer to a wire rack to cool completely before dipping in white chocolate. The biscotti becomes crunchy as it cools.\u00a0Save the baking sheets for the next step.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/white-chocolate-cranberry-pistachio-biscotti/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Melt the chopped white chocolate in a double boiler or (carefully!) use the microwave. For the microwave, place the white chocolate in a medium heat-proof bowl.\u00a0Melt in 15 second increments, stirring after each increment until completely melted and smooth. Dip each biscotti cookie in the melted chocolate and place back onto the baking sheets. Allow chocolate to set in the refrigerator or at room temperature.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/white-chocolate-cranberry-pistachio-biscotti/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Biscotti will stay fresh covered at room temperature or in the refrigerator for 1-2 weeks.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/white-chocolate-cranberry-pistachio-biscotti/#instruction-step-6"}], "prepTime": "PT40M", "cookTime": "PT45M", "totalTime": "PT1H25M", "recipeYield": ["18", "18 cookies"], "recipeCategory": "Cookies", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "Italian", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "19", "ratingValue": "5"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sherry McLean"}, "datePublished": "2024-02-06", "reviewBody": "This one that really worked first time. Absolutely delicious-crunchy but not tooth-breaking and exceptionally good taste. I think the brown sugar really added to the taste. Only two minor tweaks - I roughly chopped the nuts to avoid potential slicing problems and also added two minutes on each side to the final baking as they still seemed fairly soft. Note that they do firm up after leaving the oven, but mine were perfect. I used the white chocolate but they are just as delicious without it. This will definitely be my \u201cgo to\u201d biscotti recipe."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Gayle"}, "datePublished": "2024-08-19", "reviewBody": "Thanks Lexi for your message and reply to my previous post. Given that the dough was very sticky, I did add 2 extra tablespoons of flour and I refrigerated the dough for 45 minutes prior to forming and baking the biscotti logs. Also, as recommended by another person, I cut the biscotti with a pizza cutter and that prevented breakage of the biscotti. Add the granulated sugar and brown sugar and beat on medium-high speed until creamed, about 2 minutes.\u00a0Add the eggs, peanut butter, and vanilla and beat on high speed until combined, about 1 minute.\u00a0Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl and beat again as needed to combine.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-oatmeal-chocolate-chip-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and mix on low until combined. The filling and chocolate topping are no-bake, but the crust requires time in the oven in order to properly set.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "peanut butter tart, peanut butter cup, chocolate", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/peanut-butter-cup-tart-slice-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/peanut-butter-cup-tart-slice-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/peanut-butter-cup-tart-slice-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/peanut-butter-cup-tart-slice-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-cup-tart/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 and 1/3 cups (160g) graham cracker crumbs (about 10\u201311 full sheet graham crackers)", "1/4 cup (4 Tbsp; 56g)\u00a0unsalted butter, melted", "2 Tablespoons (25g) granulated sugar", "6 Tablespoons (85g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 cup (120g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1/8 teaspoon salt", "1 and 1/4 cups (315g) creamy peanut butter*", "6 ounces (170g) semi-sweet, bittersweet, or milk chocolate (see Note)", "3 Tablespoons (45g) creamy peanut butter"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-cup-tart/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Stir the graham cracker crust ingredients together. Pour into a 9-inch tart pan and pack in very tightly. The tighter it\u2019s packed, the less likely it will fall apart. I recommend using the bottom of a flat-bottomed measuring cup to pack it into the bottom and around the sides. Bake for 13\u201315 minutes or until very lightly browned around the edges. Remove from the oven and allow to cool for 15 minutes before adding the filling. It&#8217;s best if the crust is still slightly warm so the filling can properly adhere.", "name": "Make the crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-cup-tart/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with paddle attachment, beat the softened butter on medium-high speed until completely smooth and creamy, about 2 minutes. (For the pictured tart, I saved 1\u20132 Tablespoons of the topping and drizzled it on top after the topping set.)", "name": "Make the topping", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peanut-butter-cup-tart/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Chill in the refrigerator, uncovered, for 4\u20136 hours (or up to 2 days) before slicing. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed, and continue to beat until fully combined.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/dark-chocolate-orange-slice-bake-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a separate bowl,\u00a0whisk the flour, cinnamon, and salt together until combined. On low speed, slowly mix into the wet ingredients until combined. The cookie dough will be thick and slightly sticky. Switch to high speed and beat in the zest, fresh orange juice, and walnuts (if using). Turn the dough out onto a floured work surface and, with floured hands, divide into two. Shape each half into an 8-inch log, about 2.5 inches in diameter. The measurements don&#8217;t have to be exact. Tightly wrap the logs in plastic wrap and chill in the refrigerator for at least 4 hours and up to 5 days. Chilling is mandatory for this cookie dough.\u00a0I always chill mine overnight.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/dark-chocolate-orange-slice-bake-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).\u00a0Line two\u00a0large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats.\u00a0(Always recommended\u00a0for cookies.)\u00a0Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/dark-chocolate-orange-slice-bake-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove logs from the refrigerator and roll into coarse sugar, if desired. Dip each completely cooled cookie halfway into the chocolate and place onto a parchment or silicone baking mat-lined baking sheet. (Or use the DIY double boiler method listed in the notes.) Place on high heat. Once the water begins to boil, reduce to low heat to keep the water at a simmer.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/how-to-make-lemon-curd/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place egg yolks, granulated sugar, lemon zest, lemon juice, and salt into the top pot of your double boiler. Using a silicone whisk, whisk until completely blended, then continue to whisk as the curd cooks. Constant whisking prevents the egg yolks from curdling. Whisk and cook until the mixture becomes thick, resembling the texture of hollandaise sauce, about 10 minutes. If you\u2019d like to be precise and use a candy or instant-read thermometer, the temperature will rise to about 170\u00b0F (77\u00b0C). If curd isn&#8217;t thickening, turn up the heat and constantly whisk.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/how-to-make-lemon-curd/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove pan from heat. Whisk the sliced butter into the curd. The butter will melt from the heat of the curd as you whisk. Pour curd into a jar or bowl and place a piece of plastic wrap directly on top so it is touching the top of the curd. (This prevents a skin from forming on top.) The curd will continue to thicken as it cools. Once cool, the plastic wrap can be removed.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/how-to-make-lemon-curd/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Refrigerate the curd for up to about 10 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/how-to-make-lemon-curd/#instruction-step-4"}], "prepTime": "PT5M", "cookTime": "PT10M", "totalTime": "PT1H15M", "recipeYield": ["1", "1 - 1.5 cups"], "recipeCategory": "Dessert", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "311", "ratingValue": "4.8"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Lemon Curd | Sally's Baking Recipes", "description": "This from-scratch lemon curd is deliciously tangy, creamy, and sweet. Feel free to use store-bought dough if needed. Yields one 12-inch pizza or you can make two pizzas from the whole dough recipe. If doing so, double the string cheese and the topping ingredients.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "stuffed crust pizza", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/stuffed-crust-pizza-3-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/stuffed-crust-pizza-3-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/stuffed-crust-pizza-3-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/stuffed-crust-pizza-3.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/how-to-make-stuffed-crust-pizza/", "recipeIngredient": ["1/2 recipe homemade pizza dough (or 1 lb. store-bought pizza dough)", "1 Tablespoon (15ml) olive oil, divided", "1 Tablespoon (8g) cornmeal", "7 string cheeses, unwrapped*", "1/2 cup (127g) homemade or store-bought pizza sauce", "1 and 1/2 cups (6oz or 168g)\u00a0shredded mozzarella cheese", "big handful pepperoni (or any other toppings you like)", "optional: sprinkle of dried herbs such as basil, oregano, or an Italian seasoning blend"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Prepare pizza dough through step 3. If using store-bought frozen pizza dough, make sure it\u2019s thawed.", "name": "Dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/how-to-make-stuffed-crust-pizza/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 475\u00b0F (246\u00b0C). Allow it to heat for at least 15\u201320 minutes as you shape the pizza in the next step. If using a pizza stone, place it in the oven to preheat as well. Lightly grease a large baking sheet or pizza pan with 1/2 Tablespoon of olive oil. Sprinkle lightly with cornmeal, which gives the crust extra crunch and flavor.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/how-to-make-stuffed-crust-pizza/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "When the homemade dough is ready, punch it down to release any air bubbles. Divide the dough in half and freeze half the dough for another time\u2014see freezing instructions in the pizza dough recipe. On a lightly floured work surface using lightly floured hands or rolling pin, gently flatten the dough into a disc. Place on prepared pan (if using a pizza stone, place the dough directly on a baker\u2019s peel dusted with cornmeal) and, using lightly floured hands, stretch and flatten the disc into a 12-inch circle, about 1/2-inch thick. If the dough keeps shrinking back as you try to stretch it, stop what you&#8217;re doing, cover it lightly and let it rest for 5\u201310 minutes, then try again. Once shaped into a 12-inch circle, lift the edge of the dough up to create a lip around the edges. I simply pinch the edges up to create the rim.", "name": "Shape the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/how-to-make-stuffed-crust-pizza/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Arrange the string cheese around the edges of the crust, leaving a 3/4-inch space. Fold the edges of the dough over the string cheese, pinching down to seal. Do your best to completely seal the string cheeses inside. Let the dough rest for a couple minutes if you&#8217;re having trouble sealing it completely.\u00a0", "name": "Add cheese filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/how-to-make-stuffed-crust-pizza/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover dough lightly with plastic wrap or a clean kitchen towel and allow to rest for a few minutes as you gather the pizza toppings.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/how-to-make-stuffed-crust-pizza/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using your fingers, push dents into the surface of the dough to prevent bubbling. Brush remaining olive oil all over the dough. Top with pizza sauce, the mozzarella cheese, then the pepperoni. Sprinkle lightly with dried herbs, if desired.", "name": "Top &amp; bake the pizza", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/how-to-make-stuffed-crust-pizza/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 14\u201316 minutes or until the crust is golden brown. There's more compact surface area, which means there's more room for toppings such as cinnamon sugar, garlic parmesan, or jalape\u00f1o cheddar. Review recipe notes and watch the video tutorial before starting.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "soft pretzel knots", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/soft-pretzel-knots-with-different-toppings-parmesan-garlic-cinnamon-sugar-cheddar-jalapeno-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/soft-pretzel-knots-with-different-toppings-parmesan-garlic-cinnamon-sugar-cheddar-jalapeno-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/soft-pretzel-knots-with-different-toppings-parmesan-garlic-cinnamon-sugar-cheddar-jalapeno-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/soft-pretzel-knots-with-different-toppings-parmesan-garlic-cinnamon-sugar-cheddar-jalapeno.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-pretzel-knots/", "recipeIngredient": ["1\u00a0and 1/2 cups (360ml)\u00a0warm water (lukewarm around 100\u00b0F (38\u00b0C))", "2\u00a0and 1/4 teaspoons (7g)\u00a0instant\u00a0or\u00a0active dry yeast\u00a0(1\u00a0standard packet)", "1 Tablespoon brown sugar or\u00a0granulated sugar", "1 teaspoon\u00a0salt", "1 Tablespoon (14g)\u00a0unsalted butter, melted and slightly cooled", "3 and 3/4 &#8211; 4 cups (469-500g)\u00a0all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled), plus more for hands and work surface", "toppings: coarse salt/coarse sea salt or toppings described in notes", "1/2 cup\u00a0(120g)\u00a0baking soda", "9 cups (2.13L) water"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk warm water, yeast, and sugar together in the bowl of your stand mixer fitted with a paddle or dough hook attachment. (If you do not have a stand mixer, just use a regular large mixing bowl and a wooden spoon or silicone spatula.) Cover yeast mixture and allow to sit for 5 minutes or until foamy on top. Add salt, melted butter, and 3 cups (375g) of flour. Beat on low speed for 1 minute, scrape down the sides of the bowl with a rubber spatula if needed, then add 3/4 cup (95g) of flour. Beat on low speed until the dough comes together and pulls away from the sides of the bowl, about 2 minutes. If dough is extremely sticky after 1 minute of mixing, add remaining 1/4 cup of flour and continue to beat for 1 more minute. (You can see in the video that I add the remaining flour.)", "name": "Make the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-pretzel-knots/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Keep the dough in the mixer (and switch to the dough hook if using the paddle) and beat for an additional 5 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 5 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-pretzel-knots/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover lightly with a towel and allow to rest for 10-30 minutes. (Meanwhile, I like to get the water + baking soda boiling as instructed in step 5.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-pretzel-knots/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 400\u00b0F (204\u00b0C). Line 2 baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. Silicone baking mats are highly recommended over parchment paper. If using parchment paper, lightly spray with nonstick spray or grease with butter. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-pretzel-knots/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "With a sharp knife, pizza cutter, or bench scraper, cut dough into 14-15 pieces, which is about 1/4 cup (2 ounces) of dough each. Sprinkle work surface very lightly with flour. (Tip: The heavier you flour the work surface, the harder it is to roll the dough. A little stickiness actually helps. You only need *a very light* dusting of flour.) Roll each piece of dough into a 14-inch rope. Tie the ropes into a knot, then tuck the ends underneath. The ends are quite long so rather than tucking the ends straight underneath, I curve them around the pretzel before tucking under. You can see that in the video below.", "name": "Shape", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-pretzel-knots/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Mix water and baking soda together in a large pot. Bring to a boil. Place 2-3 pretzels into the boiling water for 20-30 seconds, flipping halfway through. (Any longer than 30 seconds and your pretzels could take on a metallic taste.) The knot shape makes the dough heavy, so if the pretzel knots are sinking, use a spatula to get them off the bottom of the pot. Using a slotted spatula or spoon, lift the pretzel knots out of the water and allow as much of the excess water to drip off. Place pretzel knots onto prepared baking sheets. Sprinkle each with coarse sea salt while each are still wet or leave plain if using other toppings detailed in the notes below (you still need to salt them if doing the jalape\u00f1o cheddar pretzels). Repeat baking soda bath with remaining pretzel knots. If needed, you can cover and refrigerate the boiled/unbaked pretzels for up to 24 hours before baking.", "name": "Baking Soda Bath", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-pretzel-knots/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 20-24 minutes or until golden brown. I usually bake mine for the full 24 minutes to obtain a very deep color as pictured.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-pretzel-knots/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove from the oven and serve warm.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-pretzel-knots/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover and store leftover pretzels at room temperature for up to 3 days. They lose a little softness over time. To reheat, microwave for a few seconds or bake at 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C) for 5 minutes.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-pretzel-knots/#instruction-step-9"}], "prepTime": "PT35M", "cookTime": "PT22M", "totalTime": "PT1H", "recipeYield": ["14", "14-15 knots"], "recipeCategory": "Snack", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "192", "ratingValue": "4.9"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Soft Pretzel Knots | Sally's Baking Addiction", "description": "These soft pretzel knots are exactly like regular homemade soft pretzels, but shaped and tied like garlic knots. There\u2019s more surface area, which means there\u2019s more room for toppings. It's much easier than you think! Be sure to read all of the instructions before baking.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "caramel monkey bread", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/Caramel-Monkey-Bread-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/Caramel-Monkey-Bread-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/Caramel-Monkey-Bread-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/Caramel-Monkey-Bread.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-monkey-bread-with-caramel-sauce/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 standard package (2 and 1/4 teaspoons) active dry yeast (such as\u00a0Red Star Platinum)", "1/4 cup warm water (110\u00b0F (43\u00b0C)-115\u00b0F (46\u00b0C))", "1 and 1/4 cups warm 2% or whole milk (110\u00b0F (43\u00b0C)-115\u00b0F (46\u00b0C))", "1/3 cup (5 Tbsp; 71g) unsalted butter, melted", "1/4 cup granulated sugar", "2 large eggs", "1 teaspoon salt", "5 cups all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter", "1 cup packed dark brown sugar", "3 Tablespoons heavy cream (no substitutions)", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, melted", "1 cup granulated sugar", "1 Tablespoon ground cinnamon", "optional: 3/4 cup chopped pecans"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large mixing bowl, dissolve yeast in warm water. Stir it around a bit and let it sit for about 2 minutes. Add the milk, melted butter, sugar, eggs, salt, and 3 cups of flour. Beat on medium speed for 3 minutes. By hand, stir in enough remaining flour to form a firm dough. About 5 cups total.", "name": "Make the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-monkey-bread-with-caramel-sauce/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Knead the dough: Keep the dough in the mixer and beat for an additional 5-7 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 5-7 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-monkey-bread-with-caramel-sauce/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Form dough into a smooth ball and place into a greased bowl, turning once to grease the top. I greased the bowl with cooking spray. Cover and refrigerate for 8 hours or overnight.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-monkey-bread-with-caramel-sauce/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "The caramel sauce can\u00a0be made ahead of time (up to 1 week) and heated in the microwave for 30 seconds before using. To make the caramel, melt the butter in a small saucepan. Once melted, add brown sugar and heavy cream. Stir constantly over medium heat until sugar is dissolved. Allow to bubble for 3-4 full minutes, no more. Set aside.", "name": "Make the caramel sauce", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-monkey-bread-with-caramel-sauce/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a shallow bowl, combine cinnamon and sugar. In a separate small bowl, melt the butter. Set aside. Spray a 10- to 12-cup Bundt pan with cooking spray. Set aside. Punch the cold dough down very gently to allow the air bubbles to release. Pull apart pieces and roll into balls, about 1.25 inches in diameter. You will need 40-45 balls total, so be modest with their size. Dip each ball, one by one, in the melted butter and then generously roll in the cinnamon-sugar mixture to coat them well. You may need more cinnamon-sugar depending how heavy you coat each ball.", "name": "Make the cinnamon-sugar topping", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-monkey-bread-with-caramel-sauce/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Arrange 20 dough balls into the Bundt pan. Sprinkle with 1/2 of the pecans. Top with remaining dough balls and pecans. *If you did not use Red Star Platinum yeast, cover the pan and allow dough balls to rise again for about 45 minutes at room temperature. If you did use Red Star Platinum yeast, move ahead to the next step and bake right away.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-monkey-bread-with-caramel-sauce/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350F. When you are ready to bake, warm the caramel sauce up for about 30 seconds. Stir, and top the dough balls with 1/2 of the caramel sauce. Reserve the rest to pour on top after it is baked.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-monkey-bread-with-caramel-sauce/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 30-35 minutes or until golden brown on top. Cover loosely with foil if the top browns too quickly.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-monkey-bread-with-caramel-sauce/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cool for 5-10 minutes, then invert onto a large serving plate. Warm up the caramel sauce again and drizzle over the bread before serving. You\u00a0can\u00a0either cut the bread into generous slices or let everyone pick off the gooey pieces themselves.\u00a0Monkey bread tastes best served on the same day, but will stay fresh for 3 days if stored covered at room temperature or in the refrigerator.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-monkey-bread-with-caramel-sauce/#instruction-step-9"}], "prepTime": "PT9H", "cookTime": "PT35M", "totalTime": "PT10H", "recipeYield": ["14", "serves 14"], "recipeCategory": "Breakfast", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "2", "ratingValue": "5"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Cate"}, "datePublished": "2025-06-15", "reviewBody": "made this for Father\u2019s Day. Add the vanilla and molasses and mix on high until combined. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-chewy-oatmeal-raisin-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a separate bowl, whisk the flour, baking soda, cinnamon, and salt together. Add to the wet ingredients and mix on low until combined. Beat in the oats, raisins, and walnuts (if using) on low speed. Dough will be thick, yet very sticky. Chill the dough for 30-60 minutes in the refrigerator (do the full hour if you&#8217;re afraid of the cookies spreading too much). If chilling for longer (up to 2 days), allow to sit at room temperature for at least 30 minutes before rolling and baking.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-chewy-oatmeal-raisin-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). I recommend using a cookie scoop since the dough can be sticky. Bake for 12-14 minutes until lightly browned on the sides. The centers will look very soft and under-baked. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-berry-trifle/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, beat the heavy cream, granulated sugar, and vanilla extract together on high speed into stiff peaks, about 3 minutes. Cover and store in the refrigerator until ready to use in step 3.", "name": "Make the whipped cream", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-berry-trifle/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a hand mixer or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the cream cheese on medium-high speed until creamy. Add the vanilla extract and lemon curd and beat on medium-high speed until combined. Lastly, beat in half of whipped cream (about 2 cups) that you prepared in step 2.", "name": "Make the lemon cheesecake layer", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-berry-trifle/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "This trifle has 3 layers of pound cake, 3 layers of berries, and 2 layers of the lemon cheesecake mixture. Begin with a base of lemon pound cake cubes. Top with an even layer of fresh berries, then half of the lemon cheesecake mixture. Repeat. Finish with final layer of lemon pound cake cubes followed by a final layer of berries. Spread or pipe remaining whipped cream on top of the trifle. I used Wilton 1M piping tip to pipe the whipped cream on top.", "name": "Assemble", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/lemon-berry-trifle/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Refrigerate for at least 2 hours and up to 6 hours (see make ahead tip if you wish to store longer). You can refrigerate uncovered for 2-4 hours, but I recommend loosely covering if storing longer than that. Then half of the buttermilk. Gently stir\u2014about 5 stirs. Repeat with the remaining wet ingredients and buttermilk. Stir until *just* combined; do not overmix. The batter won&#8217;t be very thick.", "name": "Make the cupcakes:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-cupcakes-creamy-raspberry-frosting/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour/spoon the batter into the liners\u2014fill only halfway to avoid spilling over the sides. Add the\u00a0confectioners&#8217; sugar,\u00a0cream, vanilla extract, and salt with the mixer running. Increase to high speed and beat for 1\u00a0minute. Add the raspberry preserves and beat until thick and creamy, about 2 full minutes. You should have about 2 cups (packed) crumbs, or 250g. Pour crumbs into a large bowl. Add the melted butter and stir to combine. The mixture will be thick and quite wet. Try to smash/break up any large chunks. Pour the mixture into an ungreased 9-inch pie dish. With medium pressure using your hand, pat the crumbs down into the bottom and up the sides to make a compact, thick crust. (See this Oreo crust page for more success tips if needed.) Bake for 10 minutes. Allow to cool completely.", "name": "Bake the crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-cream-pie/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place chopped chocolate in a medium heatproof bowl. Set aside at room temperature and allow to slightly cool and thicken.", "name": "Make the ganache", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-cream-pie/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, beat the heavy cream on medium-high speed until stiff peaks form, about 3\u20134 minutes. Spoon the whipped cream into a bowl and set aside. If using a stand mixer, switch to the paddle attachment. Using the same mixing bowl (no need to rinse it out), beat the cream cheese on medium-high speed until completely smooth and no lumps remain. Scrape down the sides of the bowl with a spatula and beat again as needed. Add the Nutella, confectioners&#8217; sugar, and vanilla extract, and beat until combined. Mixture will be thick and may look separated; that&#8217;s ok. (Salmon is considered done when an instant read thermometer reads the center of the thickest part as at least 145\u00b0F (63\u00b0C).) Keep a close eye on it because it can quickly burn. It will bubble up a lot as it reduces. Parchment paper helps the cakes seamlessly release from the pans. (If it&#8217;s helpful, see this parchment paper rounds for cakes video &amp; post.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-cookie-layer-cake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk\u00a0the flour, cornstarch, baking soda, and salt together in a medium bowl. Set aside.", "name": "Make the cookie cake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-cookie-layer-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter, brown sugar, and granulated sugar together on medium-high speed until smooth and creamed, about 2 minutes.\u00a0Add the eggs and vanilla extract and beat on high speed until combined, about 1 minute.\u00a0Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl and beat again as needed to combine.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-cookie-layer-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and mix on low until combined. Dough will be thick and sticky.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-cookie-layer-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Divide cookie dough between however many cake pans you&#8217;re using. Press evenly into each. I only have 3 6-inch cake pans, so I baked in batches.\u00a0If baking in batches, cover any cookie dough that isn&#8217;t being used and set aside at room temperature.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-cookie-layer-cake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 20-22 minutes or until the cake layers are lightly brown on top and a toothpick inserted in the center comes out mostly clean.\u00a0Allow cakes to cool for 10 minutes in the pans. Run a sharp knife around the edges, then carefully invert the pan so the warm cookie cake slides out. (At this point you can clean out pans, grease, line with parchment, grease parchment, then bake remaining cakes if needed.)\u00a0Set the baked cakes on a wire rack to cool completely. The cakes must be completely cool before frosting and assembling.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-cookie-layer-cake/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "With a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the butter and peanut butter together on medium speed until creamy and smooth, about 2 minutes. Add confectioners&#8217; sugar, cocoa powder, vanilla extract, and 1 Tablespoon milk. Mix on low speed for 30 seconds, then increase to high speed and beat for 2 minutes. Add another Tablespoon or 2 of milk if frosting is too thick. Taste and add a pinch of salt if needed. (I always add a pinch!)", "name": "Make the frosting:\u00a0\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-cookie-layer-cake/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place 1 cake layer on your cake stand, cake turntable, or serving plate. Bake as directed.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/ciabatta-bread-recipe/#faq-question-1735815247945", "position": 3, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/ciabatta-bread-recipe/#faq-question-1735815247945", "name": "Can I use this dough to make focaccia?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Yes. Generously grease a 9x13-inch baking pan with olive oil. After completing step 5 below, pour the dough into the greased pan. Flip to coat all sides in the oil. Stretch and flatten the dough to fit the pan. Don't tear the dough. If it's shrinking, cover it with a clean towel and let it rest for 5\u201310 minutes before continuing. This lets the gluten settle and it's much easier to shape after that. Continue with step 7 in my <a href=\"https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/garlic-rosemary-herb-focaccia/\">focaccia recipe</a>.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/ciabatta-bread-recipe/#faq-question-1735815906677", "position": 4, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/ciabatta-bread-recipe/#faq-question-1735815906677", "name": "Can I use a sourdough starter for this dough?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "To rely only on a sourdough starter and not yeast, I recommend looking for a sourdough ciabatta bread recipe. To combine your active sourdough starter with yeast, however, you can simply replace some flour and water with sourdough starter. Prepare the biga below as instructed, then on day 2/in step 2 below, replace 50g each water and flour with 100g of sourdough starter. Proceed with the recipe.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Homemade Ciabatta Bread", "description": "Rustic-looking and flavorful, with a flour-streaked crusty exterior and extra-chewy interior pockmarked by air bubbles, this classic Italian-style bread is made from just 4 ingredients. Making these ciabatta rolls is a 2-day process. For best success, I strongly recommend reading through the recipe before you get started. Do not be shy with the flour when flouring the work surface and your hands. Use as much as you need to handle the dough. If you have one, use a kitchen scale to measure your ingredients by weight (in grams). With this sticky dough, a bench scraper is basically an extension of your hands. It helps you shape and neatly straighten the dough.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "ciabatta bread", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/homemade-ciabatta-bread-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/homemade-ciabatta-bread-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/homemade-ciabatta-bread-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/homemade-ciabatta-bread.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/ciabatta-bread-recipe/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup (130g) bread flour (I use this),\u00a0spooned &amp; leveled", "1/8 teaspoon active-dry or instant yeast", "1/2 cup (120g/ml) room-temperature water (about 70\u00b0F (21\u00b0C))", "1 teaspoon (3g) active-dry or instant yeast", "1 cup (240g/ml) warm water (about 100\u2013110\u00b0F (38\u00b0\u201343\u00b0C))", "2 and 1/2 cups (325g) bread flour (spooned &amp; leveled), plus more as needed", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons (8g) table salt", "olive oil, as needed for coating hands and spatula"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large mixing bowl, whisk together the bread flour and yeast. Add the water and mix with a silicone spatula until combined. Cover the bowl tightly with plastic wrap and let rest at room temperature for 8\u201324 hours.", "name": "Day 1: Make the biga/preferment", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/ciabatta-bread-recipe/#instruction-step-1", "image": {"@type": "ImageObject", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/biga.jpg", "height": "800", "width": "1200"}}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Uncover the bowl with the biga. In a separate large mixing bowl, or the bowl of your stand mixer fitted with a dough hook attachment (do not use a handheld mixer for this), whisk together the yeast and warm water. Cover and let sit for 5 to 10 minutes until the yeast has dissolved. Add the biga, flour, and salt. Gently mix together with a silicone spatula or wooden spoon, or using the dough hook on medium speed. The dough will seem dry and shaggy at first, but keep working it until all the flour is moistened and the dough is uniform in texture (no dry pockets). If needed, lightly grease your hands with olive oil and gently knead the ingredients together in the bowl. The dough will be wet and sticky; that&#8217;s normal, expected, and encouraged.", "name": "Day 2: Make the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/ciabatta-bread-recipe/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover the bowl and let the dough rest for 30 minutes at room temperature.\u00a0", "name": "1st rest", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/ciabatta-bread-recipe/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Visualize a clock on top of your dough. You&#8217;ll be folding it at the 12 o&#8217;clock mark. With an olive oil-greased spatula or lightly oiled hands, lift up the dough at 12 o&#8217;clock and gently stretch it up and pull it toward the opposite side of the bowl (6 o&#8217;clock), folding it down over the dough. Turn the bowl 90 degrees and repeat. Do this until you&#8217;ve gone around the bowl twice, for a total of 8 folds. Cover the bowl and let rest for 30 minutes at room temperature.\u00a0", "name": "1st stretch-and-fold", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/ciabatta-bread-recipe/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Repeat step 4 three more times, allowing the dough to rest for 30 minutes between each. After the 4th stretch-and-fold, cover the bowl and place it in the refrigerator for at least 1 hour and up to 24 hours.", "name": "Remaining stretch-and-folds", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/ciabatta-bread-recipe/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Very generously flour your counter or work surface. Using lightly oiled hands or a lightly oiled spatula, gently scrape the dough out of the bowl and onto the floured surface. Generously sprinkle flour on top of the dough. Using floured hands, gently stretch and shape the dough into a rough rectangle shape, about 10&#215;7 inches in size. For 8 rolls: With a floured bench scraper, cut the dough into 8 pieces roughly equal in size, each around 2.5&#215;3.5 inches (doesn&#8217;t need to be perfect). For 2 loaves: With a floured bench scraper, cut the dough in half to make two 5&#215;7-inch (or 10&#215;3.5-inch) rectangles.", "name": "Shape the rolls/bread", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/ciabatta-bread-recipe/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly flour a piece of parchment paper. With floured hands, and using the floured bench scraper to help, lift the sticky dough pieces up and transfer them to the floured parchment, arranging them at least 2 inches apart to make room for expanding. Take care to be extra gentle because you don&#8217;t want to deflate the dough. If the pieces of dough lost shape during the transfer, gently reshape into rectangles. (It&#8217;s fine if they aren&#8217;t perfect\u2014ciabatta bread is meant to look rustic!)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/ciabatta-bread-recipe/#instruction-step-7", "image": {"@type": "ImageObject", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/shaped-ciabatta-rolls.jpg", "height": "917", "width": "1200"}}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly sprinkle flour over the rolls, and then gently cover them with a clean kitchen towel or piece of parchment paper. Let rest at room temperature for 1 hour.", "name": "Proof Before Baking", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/ciabatta-bread-recipe/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Meanwhile,\u00a0position one oven rack in the very bottom position and another rack in the center/middle position. Place a flat cookie sheet or a rimmed baking sheet on the center rack. Preheat the oven to 450\u00b0F (232\u00b0C). You want your oven and baking surface to be heating for about an hour before the bread goes in.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/ciabatta-bread-recipe/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "When ready to bake, scatter several cups of ice cubes in a large shallow metal roasting pan, cast-iron skillet, or rimmed baking sheet (do not use glass). Uncover the rolls and lightly spray or flick them with a little water. (This is optional, but it helps create even more steam, which promises a crispier crust.) Working quickly, carefully remove the preheated baking sheet from the oven and slide the parchment paper and proofed bread onto it. Place back in the oven. Slide the pan with the ice cubes onto the bottom oven rack and quickly close the oven door, trapping the steam from the melting ice inside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/ciabatta-bread-recipe/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 20\u201322 minutes, or until the bread/rolls are golden brown. I usually extend this time to 25 minutes, for a deeper golden color. Gently tap the bread\u2014if they sound hollow, they&#8217;re done. For a more accurate test of doneness, the bread is done when an instant-read thermometer inserted in the bread reads 205\u00b0F (96\u00b0C) to 210\u00b0F (99\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/ciabatta-bread-recipe/#instruction-step-11", "image": {"@type": "ImageObject", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/01/homemade-ciabatta-bread-rolls-2.jpg", "height": "800", "width": "1200"}}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove the rolls from the oven and allow to cool for at least 45 minutes before slicing and serving. "Super creamy pineapple bars made with protein-packed Greek yogurt &amp; sweet pineapple juice. Line the bottom and sides of an 8-inch square baking pan with parchment paper, leaving an overhang on 2 sides to easily lift the bars out of the pan before cutting. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/healthy-dessert-treat-recipes/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl, whisk the graham cracker crumbs and sugar together. Add the melted butter and stir until combined. Press evenly into the prepared baking pan. Bake for 8 minutes. Remove from the oven and set aside to cool slightly.", "name": "Make the crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/healthy-dessert-treat-recipes/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, beat the cream cheese on high speed until completely smooth, about 1 minute. On medium-high speed, beat in yogurt until completely combined. Then beat in the eggs and egg yolk until combined. Finally, beat in the sugar, pineapple juice, and vanilla extract until everything is combined and no lumps remain. Filling is thin. Pour filling into the crust\u2014it&#8217;s ok if the crust is still slightly warm.", "name": "Make the filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/healthy-dessert-treat-recipes/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 34\u201336 minutes or until the middle is no longer wobbly. A little jiggle is ok\u2014the bars will continue to set up as they chill in the refrigerator, so you don&#8217;t need to bake them until the center is perfectly solidified. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Once chilled, the dough will be slightly crumbly, but will come together when you work the dough with your hands. The cookies will look extremely soft when you remove them from the oven. Cool for 5 minutes on the baking sheet. If the cookies are too puffy, try gently pressing down on them with the back of a spoon. They will slightly deflate as you let them cool. If desired, while the cookies are still warm, press a few extra chocolate chips into the tops. This is optional, just for looks.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-chip-cookies/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Transfer cookies to a cooling rack to cool completely. Each bite is packed with moist texture and irresistible flavor. Review the recipe notes before beginning. To save time, feel free to make the pineapple curd first. It must cool completely before you use it in the cake's assembly.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "pineapple coconut cake", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/pineapple-coconut-cake-3-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/pineapple-coconut-cake-3-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/pineapple-coconut-cake-3-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/pineapple-coconut-cake-3.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pineapple-coconut-cake/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 and 1/2 cups (285g) cake flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "2 teaspoons\u00a0baking powder", "1/2 teaspoon\u00a0baking soda", "1 teaspoon\u00a0salt", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g)\u00a0unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 and 1/2 cups (300g) granulated sugar", "4\u00a0large\u00a0egg whites, at room temperature", "1/2 cup\u00a0(120g)\u00a0sour cream, at room temperature", "2 teaspoons\u00a0pure vanilla extract", "1 teaspoon\u00a0coconut extract", "3/4 cup (180ml) canned coconut milk, at room temperature*", "2 Tablespoons (30ml) pineapple juice (canned or fresh)", "1 cup\u00a0(80g)\u00a0sweetened shredded coconut", "1 cup (225g) pineapple chunks (canned and drained or use fresh), plus extra for garnish", "1 large egg", "2 large egg yolks", "1/3 cup (65g) granulated sugar", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons cornstarch", "1/3 cup (80ml) canned pineapple juice (must be canned)", "1/8 teaspoon salt", "1/4 cup (4 Tbsp; 56g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature and cut into 4 pieces", "8 ounces\u00a0(226g) full-fat brick cream cheese, softened to room temperature", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g)\u00a0unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "3 cups\u00a0(360g)\u00a0confectioners\u2019 sugar, plus an extra 1/4 cup (30g) if needed", "2 Tablespoons canned coconut milk or pineapple juice (your choice)", "1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1/8 teaspoon salt", "optional for garnish: fresh or canned pineapple chunks and/or 1 cup (80g) sweetened shredded coconut"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Grease three 8-inch cake pans, line with parchment paper rounds, then grease the parchment paper. Parchment paper helps the cakes seamlessly release from the pans. (If it&#8217;s helpful, see this parchment paper rounds for cakes video &amp; post.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pineapple-coconut-cake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the cake flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt together. Set aside. (Note that the video shows sifting the flour, but you do not have to.)", "name": "Make the cake:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pineapple-coconut-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on medium-high speed until smooth and creamy, about 3 minutes. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a silicone spatula as needed. Beat in the egg whites until combined, then add the sour cream, vanilla extract, and coconut extract. Beat until combined. Mixture will look curdled as a result of the varying textures and solid butter combining. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. With the mixer on low speed, slowly add the dry ingredients, coconut milk, and pineapple juice. Beat on low speed until combined, then beat in the shredded coconut and pineapple chunks just until combined. Whisk it all by hand to make sure there are no butter lumps at the bottom of the bowl. The batter will be slightly thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pineapple-coconut-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour batter evenly into cake pans. Bake for around 22-24 minutes or until the cakes are baked through. To test for doneness, insert a toothpick into the center of the cake. If it comes out clean, it\u2019s done. Allow cakes to cool completely in the pans set on a wire rack. (Make the curd as the cakes cool.) The cakes must be completely cool before frosting and assembling.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pineapple-coconut-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Fill the bottom pot of a double boiler with 1-2 inches of water. (Or use the DIY double boiler method listed in the notes.) Place on high heat. Once the water begins to boil, reduce to low heat to keep the water at a simmer. Whisk the egg, egg yolks, granulated sugar, cornstarch, pineapple juice, and salt together the top pot of your double boiler. Continue to whisk as the curd cooks because constant whisking prevents the egg yolks from curdling. Whisk and cook until the mixture becomes slightly thick, resembling the texture of hollandaise sauce, about 10 minutes. If curd isn\u2019t thickening, turn up the heat and keep whisking. Remove pan from heat. Whisk in the butter. The butter will melt from the heat of the curd. Pour curd into a jar or bowl and place a piece of plastic wrap directly on top so it is touching the top of the curd. (This prevents a skin from forming on top.) Cool completely. The curd will continue to thicken as it cools. Once cool, the plastic wrap can be removed. Makes 1 cup. You will have leftover curd after using in the cake. Cover and refrigerate leftovers for up to 1 week. (Great on sourdough, biscuits, or toast!)", "name": "Make the pineapple curd", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pineapple-coconut-cake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a hand-held mixer or stand mixer fitted with a whisk or paddle attachment, beat the cream cheese and butter together on medium speed until creamy and smooth, about 2 minutes. Add confectioners\u2019 sugar, coconut milk or pineapple juice, vanilla extract, and salt with the mixer running on low. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, then switch to high speed and beat for 2 minutes. If you want the frosting a little thicker, add the extra 1/4 cup of confectioners sugar (I usually add it).", "name": "Make the frosting:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pineapple-coconut-cake/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If your cakes are domed on top, use a large serrated knife to slice a thin layer off the tops to create a flat surface. Discard (or crumble over ice cream!). Place 1 cake layer on your cake stand, cake turntable, or serving plate. I use and recommend an icing spatula to apply the frosting &amp; curd. Evenly spread a scant 1/2 cup of frosting on top. Spread 1/4 cup of pineapple curd on top of the frosting. Top with 2nd cake layer and evenly cover the top with 1/2 cup of frosting, then 1/4 cup of curd. Carefully place the third cake layer on top. The cake is very slippery due to the frosting and curd, so be careful with it. I highly recommend a crumb coat for this cake, so spread a very very thin layer of frosting on top and all around the exterior of the cake. A\u00a0bench scraper is helpful to smooth the sides. Refrigerate crumb-coated cake for 30-60 minutes\u2014again, this is a slippery cake so refrigeration is very helpful. Remove cake from the refrigerator and spread the remaining frosting all over the cake. (Which should only be a small amount at this point.) Decorate with pineapple chunks on top of the cake and/or press coconut gently into the sides of the cake.", "name": "Assemble and decorate", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pineapple-coconut-cake/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Refrigerate cake for at least 20 minutes before slicing. This helps the cake hold its shape when cutting, though it\u2019s still a pretty fluffy cake.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pineapple-coconut-cake/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftover cake\u00a0tightly and store in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pineapple-coconut-cake/#instruction-step-9"}], "prepTime": "PT1H30M", "cookTime": "PT23M", "totalTime": "PT5H", "recipeYield": ["12", "12 servings"], "recipeCategory": "Dessert", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "63", "ratingValue": "4.6"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Pineapple Coconut Cake | Sally's Baking Addiction", "description": "This pineapple coconut cake is supremely moist and pillow soft with extra coconut packed in each bite. Stir twice during this time. Turn oven off and set pecans aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/butter-pecan-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld mixer or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter for 1 minute on medium speed until completely smooth and creamy. Add the granulated sugar and brown sugar and beat on medium high speed until fluffy and light in color. Beat in eggs and vanilla on high speed. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/butter-pecan-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a separate bowl,\u00a0whisk the\u00a0flour, cornstarch, baking soda and salt together until combined. On low speed, slowly mix into the wet ingredients until combined. The cookie dough will be quite thick. Add the toasted chopped pecans, mix on low for about 5-10 seconds until evenly distributed. Cover dough tightly with aluminum foil or plastic wrap and chill for at least 3 hours and up to 3 days. Chilling is mandatory for this cookie dough.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/butter-pecan-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove cookie dough from the refrigerator and allow to sit at room temperature for 20 minutes\u2014if the cookie dough chilled longer than 3 hours, let it sit at room temperature for about 30 minutes. This makes the cookie dough easier to scoop and roll.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/butter-pecan-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/butter-pecan-cookies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Once chilled, the dough might be slightly crumbly, but will come together if you work the dough with your hands as you roll into individual balls. Scoop and roll balls of dough, about 1 Tablespoon of dough each, into balls. You may roll the cookie dough balls into the 1/3 cup of granulated sugar listed under the &#8220;optional&#8221; ingredients. It&#8217;s optional because I merely did this for looks\u2014the sugar gives them a pretty sparkle. Or you can bake the cookies without the sugar rolling and sprinkle with a little sea salt when they come out of the oven. If you love salty/sweet, do the sea salt.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/butter-pecan-cookies/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake the cookies for 11-12 minutes (13 minutes for crispier cookies), until slightly golden brown around the edges. My oven has hot spots and yours may too- so be sure to rotate the pan once during bake time. The baked cookies will look extremely soft in the centers when you remove them from the oven. Allow to cool for 5 minutes on the cookie sheet. If the cookies are too puffy, try gently pressing down on them with the back of a spoon. They will slightly deflate as you let them cool. Transfer to cooling rack to cool completely.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/butter-pecan-cookies/#instruction-step-7"}], "prepTime": "PT3H10M", "cookTime": "PT12M", "totalTime": "PT3H30M", "recipeYield": ["30", "30 cookies"], "recipeCategory": "Cookies", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "40", "ratingValue": "4.6"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Julie"}, "datePublished": "2023-01-19", "reviewBody": "Perfection in a cookie.
