Throw in some raspberries and this cake will surely be a show-stopper!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "raspberry chocolate chip cake, raspberry chocolate chip layer cake", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Raspberry-Chocolate-Chip-Layer-Cake-by-sallysbakingaddiction.com-11-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Raspberry-Chocolate-Chip-Layer-Cake-by-sallysbakingaddiction.com-11-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Raspberry-Chocolate-Chip-Layer-Cake-by-sallysbakingaddiction.com-11-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Raspberry-Chocolate-Chip-Layer-Cake-by-sallysbakingaddiction.com-11.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-chocolate-chip-layer-cake/", "recipeIngredient": ["3 and 1/4 cups (406g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 teaspoon baking powder", "1/2 teaspoon baking soda", "3/4 teaspoon salt", "1 cup (16 Tbsp; 226g) unsalted butter, melted", "1 and 3/4 cups (350g) granulated sugar", "2 large eggs, room temperature", "2 cups (480ml) buttermilk, at room temperature", "2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1 and 1/4 cups (155g) raspberries, fresh or frozen (not thawed)", "3/4 cup (135g) mini or regular semi-sweet chocolate chips", "1 cup (16 Tbsp; 226g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "3-4 cups (360-480g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "3/4 cup (62g) unsweetened cocoa powder", "3 &#8211; 5 Tablespoons (45-75ml) heavy cream or half-and-half", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "salt, to taste", "optional: chocolate chips and raspberries for decoration"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Grease three 9-inch round baking pans, line with parchment paper rounds, then grease the parchment paper. Parchment paper helps the cakes seamlessly release from the pans. (If it&#8217;s helpful, see this parchment paper rounds for cakes video &amp; post.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-chocolate-chip-layer-cake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt together in a large bowl. Set aside. In a large bowl, melt the butter in the microwave. Vigorously whisk in the granulated sugar, then the eggs, milk, and vanilla extract. Slowly whisk the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients until hardly any lumps remain. The batter will be very thick &#8211; try not to overmix. Fold in the raspberries and chocolate chips &#8211; be gentle; you don&#8217;t want to break the raspberries and have them bleed into the batter.", "name": "Make the cake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-chocolate-chip-layer-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Divide batter evenly between prepared cake pans. Bake for 22-24 minutes, making sure to loosely cover the cakes with aluminum foil halfway through to prevent the tops from getting too brown. Cakes are done when a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. Allow to cool completely in the pans on a wire rack.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-chocolate-chip-layer-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Cream the butter with a hand or stand mixer on medium speed for 3-4 minutes. This will create a nice creamy base for the frosting. Add 3 cups of confectioners&#8217; sugar\u00a0and 3/4 cup of cocoa powder. Mix on low. Add 3 Tablespoons of heavy cream and 1 teaspoon of vanilla extract. If your frosting is too thin, add up to 1 more cup of confectioners&#8217; sugar. If your frosting is too thick, add up to 2 more Tablespoons of heavy cream. Taste and add salt if you prefer &#8211; I usually add about 1/4 teaspoon. Add more cocoa powder if the frosting is not chocolate-y enough. (This frosting recipe is forgiving. Add more/less of each ingredient to obtain the consistency and taste you desire.)", "name": "Make the frosting", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-chocolate-chip-layer-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "First, using a large serrated knife, trim the tops off the cake layers to create a flat surface. On the table in 45 minutes!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "creamy garlic chicken and vegetables", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/creamy-garlic-chicken-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/creamy-garlic-chicken-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/creamy-garlic-chicken-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/creamy-garlic-chicken-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/creamy-garlic-chicken-vegetables/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 cups (150g) fresh broccoli florets*", "2 cups (300g) cubed butternut squash*", "2 Tablespoons olive oil, divided", "1.5 pounds (24 ounces/680g) boneless, skinless chicken thighs or breasts", "1 Tablespoon (14g) unsalted butter", "1/4 teaspoon EACH salt &amp; ground black pepper, plus more for vegetables &amp; chicken", "1/4 cup (33g) diced onion", "7\u20138 garlic cloves, minced", "2 teaspoons dried parsley", "1 and 1/4 cups (300ml) chicken broth (low-sodium is fine)", "3/4 cup (180ml) half-and-half or whole milk", "1 Tablespoon (8g) cornstarch", "optional: chopped fresh parsley, for garnish"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 400\u00b0F (204\u00b0C). Line a large baking sheet with parchment paper. Spread the vegetables out in a single layer on the baking sheet. Drizzle with 1 Tablespoon olive oil, and stir to coat. Sprinkle with salt and pepper. Bake the vegetables for 20 minutes.", "name": "Roast the vegetables", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/creamy-garlic-chicken-vegetables/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Heat the remaining 1 Tablespoon of olive oil in a large 12-inch skillet over medium heat, and swirl to coat. I usually use a cast iron skillet, but any skillet this size works. You can also use a Dutch oven. Place the chicken thighs in the skillet, sprinkle with salt and pepper, and cook for 4 minutes on each side. You want the chicken lightly browned on the outside, but not fully cooked in the centers because they will finish cooking in the oven. Transfer chicken to a plate and loosely cover with foil. You&#8217;ll add it back to the pan in step 4.", "name": "Meanwhile, brown the chicken", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/creamy-garlic-chicken-vegetables/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the butter to the hot pan (no need to wipe it out first), and gently swirl to coat as it melts. Add the salt, pepper, onion, garlic, parsley, and chicken broth. Cook and stir, scraping up any browned bits from the bottom of the skillet. Let the sauce simmer for 5 minutes, stirring/scraping occasionally. With a fork, whisk together the half-and-half and cornstarch. Slowly pour the half-and-half/cornstarch mixture into the skillet, stirring or whisking to combine. Cook, stirring, for 1 minute. Taste and adjust seasoning if needed.", "name": "Make the pan sauce", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/creamy-garlic-chicken-vegetables/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the chicken and roasted vegetables to the skillet, stirring to coat everything in the sauce. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/glazed-orange-poppy-seed-bars/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the granulated sugar into the cooled butter mixture. Gently fold the dry ingredients into the\u00a0wet ingredients.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/glazed-orange-poppy-seed-bars/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour batter into the prepared baking pan and bake for 35-40 minutes or until the bars\u00a0are lightly browned around the sides and on top. If you find they are browning too quickly on top, loosely cover the bars with aluminum foil.\u00a0A toothpick inserted into the center of the bars should come out with very few moist crumbs when the bars\u00a0are done. All ovens are different, so keep an eye on them after 30 minutes and use the toothpick test to see when yours are finished. It's a family favorite recipe! Baking times vary, so keep an eye on yours. The cakes are done when a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. Cool the cakes in the pans set on a cooling rack for 1 hour. Run a knife around the edges to help loosen the sides, remove the cakes from the pans, peel off the parchment, and place on the rack to finish cooling. The cakes may slightly sink in the middle as they cool\u2014that&#8217;s expected.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/dark-chocolate-mousse-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a small bowl, whisk the hot water and cocoa powder together until smooth. Melt the chopped chocolate in a double boiler or use the microwave. If using the microwave: place the chopped chocolate in a medium heat-proof bowl. Microwave for 20-second increments, stirring after each increment until completely melted and smooth. Pour hot water/cocoa mixture into the melted chocolate and stir until thick and smooth. Set aside. In a large bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, whip the heavy cream, confectioners&#8217; sugar, and vanilla extract together on medium-high speed until medium peaks form, about 3 minutes. Medium peaks are between soft/loose peaks and stiff peaks. Pour in the chocolate mixture and gently fold together with a spatula. Do not overmix, as this could deflate it. Cover the mousse and refrigerate for at least 2 hours or up to 2 days. Makes about 4.5 cups (about 900g).", "name": "Make the chocolate mousse", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/dark-chocolate-mousse-cake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "First, level the cakes (if needed): using a large serrated knife, slice a thin layer off the tops of the cakes to create a flat surface. Place 1 cake layer on your cake stand, cake turntable, or serving plate. Using a large icing spatula, evenly cover the top with about 1.5 cups (200g) of chocolate mousse. Top with the second layer, upside down, and evenly cover the top with the same amount of chocolate mousse. Top with the third cake layer, right side up, and again cover with the same amount of mousse. Top with final cake layer. Spread the remaining mousse on top and around the sides of the cake as a crumb coat. Run a bench scraper around the cake to smooth out the sides. Refrigerate for at least 1 hour and up to 4 hours. Prepare the ganache while the cake is chilling.\u00a0", "name": "Assemble the cake before preparing chocolate ganache", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/dark-chocolate-mousse-cake/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the chocolate in a medium heat-proof bowl. In a small saucepan, heat the cream over medium heat just until it begins to gently simmer. (Do not let it come to a rapid boil\u2014that\u2019s too hot!) Pour the warm cream over the chocolate and let it sit for 2\u20133 minutes to gently soften the chocolate. With a metal spoon or small spatula, slowly stir until the chocolate has melted and the mixture is smooth. The finer you chopped the chocolate, the quicker it will melt with the cream. If it\u2019s not melting, do not microwave it. If needed, see Troubleshooting Chocolate Ganache. Refrigerate the ganache for at least 30 minutes or up to 1 hour to thicken.", "name": "Make the chocolate ganache", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/dark-chocolate-mousse-cake/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour/spoon the thickened ganache on the chilled cake. You have a few options for toppings. The recipe below includes a simple cream cheese icing, but we also love these with the coffee icing or vanilla icing that's included in the recipe Notes below.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "easy cinnamon rolls from scratch", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/05/easy-soft-cinnamon-rolls-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/05/easy-soft-cinnamon-rolls-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/05/easy-soft-cinnamon-rolls-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/05/easy-soft-cinnamon-rolls-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-cinnamon-rolls-from-scratch/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 and 3/4 cups (344g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled), plus more as needed", "1/4 cup (50g) granulated sugar", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "3/4 cup (180ml) whole milk", "3 Tablespoons (43g) unsalted butter", "2 and 1/4 teaspoons Platinum Yeast from Red Star or any instant yeast (1 standard packet)", "1 large egg, at room temperature", "3 Tablespoons (43g) unsalted butter, extra softened", "1/3 cup (67g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1 Tablespoon ground cinnamon", "4 ounces (113g) full-fat block cream cheese, softened to room temperature", "2 Tablespoons (28g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "2/3 cup (80g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, sugar, and salt together in a large bowl. Set aside.", "name": "Make the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-cinnamon-rolls-from-scratch/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Combine the milk and butter together in a heatproof bowl. Microwave or use the stove and heat until the butter has melted and the mixture is warm to the touch (about 110\u00b0F/43\u00b0C, no higher). Whisk in the yeast until it has dissolved. Pour mixture into the dry ingredients, add the egg, and stir with a sturdy rubber spatula or wooden spoon OR use a stand mixer with a paddle attachment on medium speed. Mix until a soft dough forms.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-cinnamon-rolls-from-scratch/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Transfer dough to a lightly floured surface. Using floured hands, knead the dough for 3-5 minutes. You should have a smooth ball of dough. If the dough is super soft or sticky, you can add a little more flour. Place in a lightly greased bowl (I use non-stick spray), cover loosely, and let the dough rest for about 10 minutes as you get the filling ingredients ready.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-cinnamon-rolls-from-scratch/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "After 10 minutes, roll the dough out in a 14&#215;8-inch (36&#215;20-cm) rectangle. Spread the softened butter on top. Mix together the cinnamon and brown sugar. Sprinkle it all over the dough. Roll up the dough to make a 14-inch log. Cut into 10\u201312 even rolls and arrange in a lightly greased 9- or 10-inch round cake pan, pie dish, or square baking pan.", "name": "Fill the rolls:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-cinnamon-rolls-from-scratch/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover the pan with aluminum foil, plastic wrap, or a clean kitchen towel. Allow the rolls to rise in a relatively warm environment for 60\u201390 minutes or until double in size. (For a tiny reduction in rise time, see my answer to Where Should Dough Rise?\u00a0in my\u00a0Baking with Yeast Guide.)", "name": "Rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-cinnamon-rolls-from-scratch/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "After the rolls have doubled in size, preheat the oven to 375\u00b0F (190\u00b0C).\u00a0Bake for 24\u201327 minutes, or until lightly browned. If you notice the tops are getting too brown too quickly, loosely tent the pan with aluminum foil and continue baking. If you want to be precise about their doneness, their internal temperature taken with an instant read thermometer should be around 195\u2013200\u00b0F (91\u201393\u00b0C) when done. Remove pan from the oven and place pan on a wire rack as you make the icing. (You can also make the icing as the rolls bake.)", "name": "Bake the rolls", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-cinnamon-rolls-from-scratch/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the cream cheese on high speed until smooth and creamy. Add the butter and beat until smooth and combined, then beat in the confectioners\u2019 sugar and vanilla until combined. Using a knife or icing spatula, spread the icing over the warm rolls and serve immediately.\u00a0", "name": "Make the icing", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-cinnamon-rolls-from-scratch/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftover frosted or unfrosted rolls tightly and store at room temperature for a day or in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/easy-cinnamon-rolls-from-scratch/#instruction-step-8"}], "prepTime": "PT1H40M", "cookTime": "PT25M", "totalTime": "PT2H5M", "recipeYield": ["10", "10-12 rolls"], "recipeCategory": "Breakfast", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "945", "ratingValue": "4.7"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Easy Cinnamon Rolls From Scratch | Sally's Baking Recipes", "description": "This video shows the process of making easy cinnamon rolls from scratch with 1 quick rest time and only 1 long rise. My husband loved it."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Susan H."}, "datePublished": "2025-10-07", "reviewBody": "Excellent cinnamon roll recipe! Absolutely  the best! Thank you so much for sharing this. I did 2 things differently,  but didn't change any ingredients or the amounts. First, for the dough, I always put the sugar in the milk and butter mix. This gives the sugar a little help in dissolving. Second. I use dental floss to cut the slices from the log. I roll up the dough with sugar, butter and cinnamon mixture to form the log. Then I take about a 12 inch piece of plain dental floss, raise up one end of dough and place the floss under the dough where I want to cut. I will pick up the ends of the floss, one end in each hand, and cross each end simultaneously  over the log and pull tight. This cuts the slice very easily. Repeat this until all of the log is in slices. If you need to, you can mark where you want each slice cut by indenting the dough to make a mark. Again, thank you very much for this recipe. Yummy!"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "3"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Jenn"}, "datePublished": "2025-10-04", "reviewBody": "The taste is fine with these, but the dough is just way too dense. This recipe is also in my New York Times best-selling cookbook, Sally's Baking 101.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "sugar cookies, royal icing, Christmas cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/sugar-cookies-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/sugar-cookies-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/sugar-cookies-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/sugar-cookies.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/best-sugar-cookies/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 and 1/4 cups (281g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled), plus more as needed for rolling and work surface", "1/2 teaspoon baking powder", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "3/4 cup (150g) granulated sugar", "1 large egg, at room temperature", "2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1/4 teaspoon almond extract (optional, but makes the flavor outstanding)*", "Royal Icing, Easy Glaze Icing, or Cookie Buttercream (royal icing is pictured)", "Assorted sprinkles"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl, whisk the flour, baking powder, and salt together. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/best-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld or a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on high speed until the mixture is light and creamy, about 3 minutes. Add the egg, vanilla, and almond extract (if using) and beat on high speed until combined, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl and beat again as needed to combine. Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and mix on low speed until combined. The dough should be soft. If it seems too soft and sticky for rolling, beat in 1 more Tablespoon of flour.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/best-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Divide the dough in half. Place each portion on a piece of lightly floured parchment paper or a lightly floured silicone baking mat. With a lightly floured rolling pin, roll the dough to about 1/4-inch thickness. Use a bit more flour if the dough seems too sticky. The rolled-out dough can be any shape, as long as it is evenly 1/4 inch thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/best-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly dust one of the rolled-out dough portions with flour. (This prevents sticking.) Place the second rolled-out dough portion, still on the parchment paper, on top of the first. Cover the dough tightly and\u00a0 refrigerate it for at least 2 hours and up to 2 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/best-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/best-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Carefully remove the top piece of dough from the refrigerator. If it&#8217;s sticking to the bottom, run your hand under it to help remove it. Using a cookie cutter, cut the dough into shapes. Gather the scraps, reroll, and continue cutting until all the dough is used. (Note: It doesn&#8217;t seem like a lot of dough, but you get a lot of cookies from the dough scraps you reroll.) Repeat with the second piece of dough. Arrange the cookies 3 inches apart on the prepared baking sheets.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/best-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 11\u201312 minutes or until the edges of the cookies are very lightly browned and set. If your oven has hot spots, rotate the baking sheets halfway through bake time. Allow the cookies to cool on the baking sheet for 5 minutes, then transfer to a cooling rack to cool completely before decorating.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/best-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Decorate the cooled cookies with royal icing, easy cookie icing, or cookie decorating buttercream. Feel free to tint any of the icings with gel food coloring. See post above for recommended decorating tools. No need to cover the decorated cookies as you wait for the icing to set. If it&#8217;s helpful, decorate the cookies directly on a baking sheet so you can place the entire baking sheet in the refrigerator to help speed up the icing setting.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/best-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Enjoy cookies right away or wait until the icing sets to serve them. Once the icing has set, these cookies are great for gifting or shipping. Store plain or iced cookies covered tightly at room temperature for up to 5 days. For longer storage, cover and refrigerate for up to 10 days. If decorated with cookie buttercream, cover and store decorated cookies at room temperature for up to 1 day, or in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/best-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-9"}], "prepTime": "PT40M", "cookTime": "PT12M", "totalTime": "PT3H", "recipeYield": ["24", "24 3-4 inch cookies"], "recipeCategory": "Cookies", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "843", "ratingValue": "4.7"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Cut Out Sugar Cookies | Sally's Baking Addiction", "description": "With crisp edges, thick centers, and room for lots of decorating icing, I know you\u2019ll love these soft cut out sugar cookies. But you'll need to use a different recipe, as subbing out gelatin is not a 1:1 swap. I know many have tried this <a href=\"https://www.seriouseats.com/vegan-marshmallows-recipe\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener\">vegan marshmallows recipe from Serious Eats</a> with great success.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-marshmallows/#faq-question-1732708531475", "position": 2, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-marshmallows/#faq-question-1732708531475", "name": "Can I flavor the marshmallows with anything besides vanilla?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Yes! You'll add the vanilla at the end of the recipe, when you're whipping the cooked sugar syrup. Instead of vanilla, you can use another extract such as peppermint, coconut, lemon, maple, or almond. I would start with only 1/2 teaspoon of any of these, taste, and then whip in more if desired. If adding another flavor, you can leave out the vanilla, or reduce the amount down to 1 teaspoon. You could also add 1/4 to 1/2 teaspoon of cinnamon. Taste, and then add more if desired.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-marshmallows/#faq-question-1732708712890", "position": 3, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-marshmallows/#faq-question-1732708712890", "name": "Can I tint the marshmallows a color?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Yes, absolutely. Add a drop of <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2q4qJCR\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener sponsored nofollow\">gel food coloring</a> when you add the extract. Pink marshmallows are always fun, and you can top them with sprinkles after spreading into the pan and before setting.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-marshmallows/#faq-question-1732882709417", "position": 4, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-marshmallows/#faq-question-1732882709417", "name": "Can I make this into marshmallow cream?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "I make marshmallow creme using egg whites and sugar, and not gelatin and corn syrup. The recipe below would need several adjustments. Try this <a href=\"https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-marshmallow-creme/\">homemade marshmallow creme</a> aka meringue frosting.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "How to Make Homemade Marshmallows", "description": "If ever there was a homemade sweet treat that tastes worlds away from the store-bought version, it's homemade marshmallows. These have just the right amount of sweetness, a delicate kiss of vanilla flavor, and a pillowy soft texture you won't find anywhere else. This is a great make-ahead recipe, as the marshmallows need to set for at least 6 hours, and last for 2 weeks. Avoid making these on a humid day, as the moisture in the air can prevent the marshmallows from setting properly.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "homemade marshmallows", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/homemade-marshmallows-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/homemade-marshmallows-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/homemade-marshmallows-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/homemade-marshmallows.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-marshmallows/", "recipeIngredient": ["1/3 cup (40g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "3 Tablespoons (24g) cornstarch", "3/4 ounce (21g) unflavored gelatin (3 standard 1/4-ounce packets)", "1 cup (240ml) cold water, divided", "1 cup (325g) light corn syrup", "1 and 1/2 cups (300g) granulated sugar", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "1 Tablespoon pure vanilla extract"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Generously spray the bottom and sides of a 9&#215;13-inch glass or ceramic baking pan with nonstick cooking spray. (I do not suggested a metal pan, as it can affect the taste of the marshmallows.) Sift the confectioners&#8217; sugar and cornstarch together into a bowl and sprinkle some of it very lightly all around the pan, to dust it. Set the remaining sugar/cornstarch mixture aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-marshmallows/#instruction-step-1", "image": {"@type": "ImageObject", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/sifting-confectioners-sugar-cornstarch-in-pan.jpg", "height": "1600", "width": "1200"}}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the gelatin and 1/2 cup water in the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment. (Or, if using a handheld mixer, a regular large mixing bowl.) Whisk/beat on low speed for 1 minute to briefly combine. Allow to sit as you cook the sugar syrup\u2014no need to cover.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-marshmallows/#instruction-step-2", "image": {"@type": "ImageObject", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/gelatin-water-mixture-in-bowl.jpg", "height": "1600", "width": "1200"}}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the remaining 1/2 cup water, the corn syrup, granulated sugar, and salt in a 3-quart heavy-duty saucepan over medium heat. Stir with a wooden spoon until the sugar has dissolved. Attach a candy thermometer to the side of the saucepan. Do not let it touch the bottom of the pan. As the sugar syrup begins cooking, brush down the sides of the pan with a water-moistened pastry brush to prevent the sugar from crystallizing.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-marshmallows/#instruction-step-3", "image": {"@type": "ImageObject", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/cooking-sugar-syrup-in-pot.jpg", "height": "1600", "width": "1200"}}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Without stirring, brushing down the sides of the pan as needed, cook the sugar syrup until it reaches soft ball stage (when it reaches 235\u2013240\u00b0F (113\u2013116\u00b0C) on a digital candy thermometer). Remove the pan from heat and let sit for 5 minutes.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-marshmallows/#instruction-step-4", "image": {"@type": "ImageObject", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/cooked-sugar-syrup-in-pot.jpg", "height": "1600", "width": "1200"}}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Turn the mixer on low speed and slowly pour the hot syrup into the gelatin mixture as the mixer runs. The syrup will be extremely hot, so use caution.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-marshmallows/#instruction-step-5", "image": {"@type": "ImageObject", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/pouring-cooked-sugar-mixture-in-bowl.jpg", "height": "1600", "width": "1200"}}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Gradually increase the mixer speed until it reaches high. Whip the mixture for 10\u201315 minutes, or until it is white, thick, and shiny. If using a handheld mixer, this could take longer. During the last minute of whipping, add the vanilla extract.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-marshmallows/#instruction-step-6", "image": {"@type": "ImageObject", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/making-homemade-marshmallows.jpg", "height": "1800", "width": "1200"}}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour/spoon the marshmallow into the prepared pan and smooth out the top with a silicone or offset spatula. Allow to sit, uncovered, at room temperature for at least 6 hours, and up to 48 hours.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-marshmallows/#instruction-step-7", "image": {"@type": "ImageObject", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/pouring-marshmallow-mixture-into-pan.jpg", "height": "917", "width": "1200"}}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Once completely firm, you can cut the marshmallows. To do so, cover a large surface or cutting board with parchment paper. Liberally sprinkle the surface as well as the top of the marshmallow with some of the remaining cornstarch/sugar mixture. Using a sharp knife, loosen the edges of the marshmallow from the pan, and then invert the pan onto the prepared surface. Lift a corner of the pan and use your fingers to help peel the marshmallow away from the pan.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-marshmallows/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a sharp knife, cut the marshmallow into 1.5-inch squares, coating the knife blade with some of the leftover cornstarch/sugar mixture as needed. I find running the blade under hot water and wiping it dry helps to make clean cuts as well. Roll the edges of the marshmallows in the cornstarch/sugar mixture, if desired, so they are no longer sticky.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-marshmallows/#instruction-step-9", "image": {"@type": "ImageObject", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/cut-homemade-marshmallows.jpg", "height": "1800", "width": "1200"}}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Store leftover marshmallows at room temperature in an airtight container, with parchment paper between layers, in a cool, dry place for up to 2 weeks.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-marshmallows/#instruction-step-10"}], "prepTime": "PT35M", "cookTime": "PT15M", "totalTime": "PT6H50M", "recipeYield": ["54", "about 54-60 marshmallows"], "recipeCategory": "Candy", "cookingMethod": "Cooking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "28", "ratingValue": "4.7"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Marshmallows | Sally's Baking", "description": "If ever there was a sweet treat that tastes tons/miles/years better made from scratch vs. store-bought, it\u2019s homemade marshmallows. They're rich, fudgy, chewy, dense, and perfect!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "nutella brownies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/easy-nutella-brownies-2-1-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/easy-nutella-brownies-2-1-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/easy-nutella-brownies-2-1-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/easy-nutella-brownies-2-1.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-brownies/", "recipeIngredient": ["1/3 cup (5 Tablespoons; 71g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1/2 cup (100g) packed light brown sugar", "2 large eggs, at room temperature", "2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1 and 1/4 cups (370g) Nutella, divided", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "3/4 cup (94g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "optional: 3/4 cup (135g) semi-sweet chocolate chips; a sprinkle of sea salt"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line the bottom and sides of an 8-inch square baking pan or 9-inch square baking pan with aluminum foil or parchment, leaving an overhang on all sides to easily lift the brownies out of the pan when cool. (If using a 9-inch pan, the bake time will be a few minutes less.) Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-brownies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "With a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter on high speed in a large bowl until smooth and creamy, about 1 minute. Add the brown sugar and beat on high speed for 1-2\u00a0minutes until creamed. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed.\u00a0With the mixer running on low speed, add the eggs and vanilla extract. Beat on medium-high speed until combined, then beat in 1 cup Nutella and salt. Mix until smooth and fluffy.\u00a0Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. With the mixer running on low speed, add the flour, mixing just until combined.\u00a0Do not overmix. If using chocolate chips, gently fold them in.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-brownies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour the batter into prepared baking pan. Drop teaspoonfuls of the remaining 1/4 cup Nutella on top. Using a knife, swirl the Nutella into the batter. Top with a sprinkle of sea salt.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-brownies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake the brownies for 32-36 minutes. Keep your eye on them and test with a toothpick to determine doneness. If the toothpick comes out with only a couple moist crumbs, the brownies are done. The brownies may take a few minutes longer; all ovens vary. Mine took 36 minutes.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-brownies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Allow the brownies to cool completely in the pan set on a wire rack.\u00a0Once cool, lift the foil out of the pan using the overhang on the sides and cut into squares. You can top each with more sea salt if desired. Store in an airtight container at room temperature or in the refrigerator for 3-4 days. In a medium bowl, combine the blueberries and blackberries together. In a large bowl, combine the strawberries and cherries together. Stir 1/4 cup of cornstarch mixture into blueberries/blackberries. Stir remaining cornstarch mixture into strawberries/cherries. Add 1 teaspoon of lemon juice and 1/4 teaspoon of almond extract to each fruit mixture.\u00a0Place in the refrigerator for a few moments as you roll out the crust.", "name": "Make the filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/american-flag-pie/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to\u00a0400\u00b0F (204\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/american-flag-pie/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0On a floured work surface, roll out one of the\u00a0discs\u00a0of chilled dough (keep the other one in the refrigerator). Turn the dough about a quarter turn after every few rolls until you have a circle 12 inches in diameter. Carefully place the dough into a 9-inch pie dish. Tuck it in with your fingers, making sure it is smooth. Fold the aluminum foil several times to form a 2-inch wide strip. Place into crust, dividing it into 1/3 and 2/3 sections as pictured above.", "name": "Roll out the chilled pie dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/american-flag-pie/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon strawberry filling into large section, leaving any excess liquid in the bowl (you don&#8217;t want that in the filling\u2014discard it). Spoon blueberry filling into smaller section. Again, discarding the excess liquid. Place the pie in the refrigerator until top design is ready.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/american-flag-pie/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove the other disc of chilled pie dough from the refrigerator. Roll the dough into a circle that is 12 inches diameter. Using a sharp knife, pastry wheel, or pizza cutter, cut 4 strips that are 2 inches wide and 6 inches long. Using your star cookie cutter, cut 12-14 stars. Re-roll any dough scraps if needed. Remove the pie from the refrigerator, remove aluminum foil strip, and add top decor to pie. Stars over the blueberries; strips over the strawberries to form an American flag design. Use a small knife to trim off excess dough on the sides. Crimp the edges with a fork or flute the edges. (Review my how to crimp and flute pie crust tutorial if you need extra help with this step.)", "name": "Design the flag", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/american-flag-pie/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly brush the pie crust with the egg wash mixture. Drizzle 1/2 cup (145g) of salted caramel evenly on top. Place the pie in the refrigerator as you work on the top crust.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/caramel-pear-pie/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Remove the other disc\u00a0of chilled pie dough from the refrigerator. Roll the dough into a circle that is 12 inches diameter. Using a sharp knife or pizza cutter, cut ten 1-inch strips. (I cut four of the strips in half, as you can see above.) Remove the pie from the refrigerator and carefully thread the pie dough strips over and under one another to create the look in the pictures pie, pulling back strips as necessary to weave. Press the edges of the strips into the bottom pie crust edges to seal. Use a small knife to trim off excess dough. Flute the edges or crimp with a fork. (Alternatively, you can simply cover the filling with the 12-inch pie dough circle. Cut slits in the top to form steam vents. Trim and crimp the edges. See my how to crimp and flute pie crust tutorial for extra help with this step.)", "name": "Arrange\u00a0the lattice", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/caramel-pear-pie/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly brush the top of the pie crust with the egg wash mixture and sprinkle with coarse sugar, if desired.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/caramel-pear-pie/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the pie onto a large baking sheet and bake for 20 minutes. I left out as much liquid from the filling as I could. I wonder if my pears were just a little too ripe. They weren\u2019t soft, but they were juicy when I cut into them. Also, I made the caramel sauce the day before and warmed it up before adding it to the pie filling. Was it supposed to sit on top of the pear mixture? Mine did not incorporate much into the filling, which made topping with a lattice pie crust a bit difficult because the dough pieces kept sticking to the caramel sauce and tearing apart as I tried to weave the pieces. So, all that to say, flavor was 5 stars, but assembly and technicalities were about 3 stars."}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "RayMo"}, "datePublished": "2024-11-28", "reviewBody": "Y'all...this is SO GOOD. SO GOOD!!!! Here's what I did: I had picked some pears and needed to use them up, and they were really hard yet had a lot of flavor and were sweet. This was a benefit, because they kept some texture in the pie; I did not want mealy mushy pear goo in my pie. I actually cooked them down in the juices and sugar mix for about 5 or 10 minutes just to soften them up a bit and release some of the moisture. My mom tried to argue with me to put ALL the juices in the pie, but I followed the recipe, and it was fine (the caramel adds back to the filling so it's not dry at all.) The caramel was actually easy to make (BE CAREFUL), and it really elevates the pie. I wouldn't use just regular caramel here, because the salt balances it out so well. I used her pie crust recipe, too, and it was phenomenal, however I did swap out the vegetable shortening for lard (same amount) because I wanted it to be as old school as possible and lard is cheap! Let me tell yah, it worked like a dream. It was flaky and rich, just delicious. Just keep it all cold and you're good. If you think your dough mix is warming up just pop it into the freezer for 5 minutes while you're washing dishes or something. You can mix it for a bit, let it chill, mix some more, chill it again, etc. Just keep that lard and butter as cold as you can. I dusted the top of the pie crust (the one lining the pan bottom) with tapioca flour just in case it needed any help setting. I had consumed a bit of wine at this point, so I tried the lattice thing and I couldn't get it right, so I just rolled it out and put it on top, crimped the edges, and cut some decorative slits into the top of the pie crust and it worked out just fine! Cheers to all of you who got the lattice thing down, you're better than I am, lol. Another thing to keep in mind: you want to give a pie at least 4 or 5 hours to sit and set after you cook it, so that might be why some of the commenters had issues with runny pies. I will definitely make this pie again, and the salted caramel, and the pie dough! 3 great things came from me making this recipe, so that's really neat. Thanks to the author!"}], "datePublished": "2017-11-03", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/caramel-pear-pie/#recipe", "isPartOf": {"@id": The mixture will be thick and tacky at first, then thin out and appear frothy on top. To test that it\u2019s ready, you can use your finger or an instant read thermometer. Lightly and quickly dip your finger (it\u2019s very hot, be careful) and rub the mixture between your thumb and finger. You shouldn\u2019t feel any sugar granules. Top with flaky sea salt and serve with homemade cinnamon butter for a side dish that will upstage the main course! If you're a bread beginner, reference my Baking with Yeast Guide for answers to common yeast FAQs.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "sweet potato rolls", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/sweet-potato-dinner-rolls-cinnamon-butter-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/sweet-potato-dinner-rolls-cinnamon-butter-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/sweet-potato-dinner-rolls-cinnamon-butter-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/sweet-potato-dinner-rolls-cinnamon-butter.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sweet-potato-dinner-rolls/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 medium sweet potato, about 250\u2013290g, peeled and chopped (to yield 1 cup mashed)", "3/4 cup (180ml) whole milk, warmed to about 110\u00b0F (43\u00b0C)", "2 and 1/4 teaspoons Platinum Yeast from Red Star (1 standard-size packet)", "1/3 cup (113g) honey, divided", "2 large eggs, at room temperature", "5 Tablespoons (71g) unsalted butter, softened", "1 and 3/4 teaspoons salt", "5 and 1/2 cups (715g) bread flour* (spooned &amp; leveled), plus more as needed", "optional: 2 Tablespoons (28g) melted butter and flaky sea salt, for finishing"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Place the chopped sweet potato in a medium saucepan and add enough water to cover. Bring to a boil over high heat, then reduce the heat to medium-high and boil until the sweet potato is very soft and tender, about 10\u201312 minutes. Drain off the water, then mash the sweet potato as well as you can\u2014a few small lumps are okay. Measure 1 cup (230g) of mashed sweet potato to use in the dough, and set aside to slightly cool. (Do not use more than 1 cup in your dough. Discard or eat any leftover.)", "name": "Prepare the sweet potato", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sweet-potato-dinner-rolls/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the warm milk, yeast, and 2 Tablespoons of honey together in the bowl of your stand mixer. Cover and allow to sit for 5 minutes. *If you do not own a stand mixer, you can do this in a large mixing bowl and in the next step, mix the dough together with a large wooden spoon/silicone spatula. It will take a bit of arm muscle. I don&#8217;t recommend using a hand mixer because the sticky dough repeatedly gets stuck in the beaters. Mixing by hand with a wooden spoon or silicone spatula is a better choice.*", "name": "Proof the yeast", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sweet-potato-dinner-rolls/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the remaining honey, eggs, butter, mashed sweet potato, salt, and 1 cup (125g) flour to the yeast mixture. With a dough hook or paddle attachment, mix/beat on low speed for 1 minute. Stop and scrape down the sides of the bowl with a silicone spatula, then add the remaining flour. Beat on medium speed until the dough comes together and pulls away from the sides of the bowl, about 3 minutes. If the dough seems too wet to a point where kneading (next step) would be impossible, beat in more flour 1 Tablespoon at a time until you have a workable dough. Don&#8217;t be nervous if you&#8217;re adding a lot more flour; there are a lot of variables such as moisture in the sweet potato, humidity, weather, etc. Dough should be soft and a little sticky, but still manageable to knead with lightly floured hands.", "name": "Make the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sweet-potato-dinner-rolls/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Keep the dough in the mixer fitted with a dough hook and beat on low speed for an additional 5 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 5 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. After kneading, the dough should feel soft and smooth. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sweet-potato-dinner-rolls/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly grease a large bowl with oil or nonstick spray. Place the dough in the bowl, turning it to coat all sides in the oil. Cover the bowl and allow the dough to rise in a relatively warm environment for 1\u20132 hours or until double in size. (I always let it rise on the counter. Takes about 1 and 1/2 hours. For a tiny reduction in rise time, see my answer to Where Should Dough Rise? in my Baking with Yeast Guide.)", "name": "1st Rise", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sweet-potato-dinner-rolls/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Grease a 9&#215;13-inch baking pan.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sweet-potato-dinner-rolls/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "When the dough is ready, punch it down to release the air. Divide the dough into 20 equal pieces, about 65\u201375g each (doesn\u2019t need to be exact!). A bench scraper is always helpful for cutting dough. Shape each piece into a smooth ball. Arrange in prepared baking pan.", "name": "Shape the rolls", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sweet-potato-dinner-rolls/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover shaped rolls and allow to rise until puffy, about 30 to 45 minutes.", "name": "2nd Rise:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sweet-potato-dinner-rolls/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Adjust oven rack to a lower position and preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). (It&#8217;s best to bake the rolls towards the bottom of the oven so the tops don&#8217;t burn.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sweet-potato-dinner-rolls/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 25 minutes or until golden brown on top (internal temperature if taken with an instant-read thermometer should be 190\u00b0F), rotating the pan halfway through. If you notice the tops browning too quickly, loosely tent the pan with aluminum foil (I usually add it after 20 minutes). Remove from the oven, brush with melted butter and sprinkle with flaky sea salt, and allow rolls to cool for 15 minutes before serving. We&#8217;ve learned that the longer they cool, the better their flavor.", "name": "Bake the rolls", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sweet-potato-dinner-rolls/#instruction-step-10"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftover rolls tightly and store at room temperature for up to 3 days, or in the refrigerator for up to 1 week.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sweet-potato-dinner-rolls/#instruction-step-11"}], "prepTime": "PT3H20M", "cookTime": "PT25M", "totalTime": "PT3H45M", "recipeYield": ["20", "20 rolls"], "recipeCategory": "Dinner", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "395", "ratingValue": "4.9"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Sweet Potato Rolls | Sally's Baking", "description": "Fluffy, flaky, soft, and extra tall sweet potato dinner rolls are a wonderful accompaniment to a holiday meal\u2014but you don\u2019t have to wait for a holiday to enjoy them.\n\nGet the full recipe: https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/sweet-potato-dinner-rolls/ \n\n\u2022 Ask your recipe question or leave a review over on the recipe page.\n\n#baking #recipes #sweetpotatorolls #dinnerrolls #dinnerrollsrecipe #sweetpotatodinnerrolls \n\n\u2022 More of Sally's baking recipes: https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/", "duration": "PT2M", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/4EY7VR4L2Oo?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4EY7VR4L2Oo", "thumbnailUrl": ["https://i.ytimg.com/vi/4EY7VR4L2Oo/hqdefault.jpg"], "uploadDate": "2025-05-15T13:00:09+00:00"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sunny"}, "datePublished": "2025-12-07", "reviewBody": "My scale wasn\u2019t calibrated so I was using WAY more flour than needed\u2026. lesson learned lol. Gently blot them with a towel to rid some moisture. (No need to thaw and blot if you&#8217;re using frozen strawberries.) The wetter the berries are, the more difficult they are to combine with the dough. Freeze the fresh chopped strawberries as you prepare the other dough ingredients. The colder, the better.", "name": "Strawberries", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/strawberry-biscuit-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "You can use a food processor for this step, but I encourage you to do it by hand so you don&#8217;t accidentally over-work the dough. Overworked dough lends tougher cookies. Whisk the flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt together in a large bowl (or pulse together in your food processor). Add the cubed butter and cut into the dry ingredients with a pastry cutter until coarse crumbs form. (Or pulse several times in a food processor.) See photo above for a visual. This recipe is also in my New York Times best-selling cookbook, Sally's Baking 101.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "strawberries, pink", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/homemade-strawberry-cake-4-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/homemade-strawberry-cake-4-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/homemade-strawberry-cake-4-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/homemade-strawberry-cake-4.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/strawberry-cake/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 pound (454g) fresh strawberries, rinsed and hulled", "2 and 1/2 cups (295g) cake flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "2 teaspoons baking powder", "1/2 teaspoon baking soda", "1 teaspoon salt", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 and 3/4 cups (350g) granulated sugar", "5 large egg whites, at room temperature", "1/3 cup (80g) full-fat sour cream or plain Greek yogurt, at room temperature", "2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1/2 cup (120g/ml) whole milk, at room temperature", "1/2 cup reduced strawberry puree (from step 1)", "optional: 1\u20132 drops red or pink food coloring", "1 cup (about 25g) freeze-dried strawberries*", "8 ounces (226g) full-fat brick\u00a0cream cheese, softened to room temperature", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "3 cups (360g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1 Tablespoon whole milk", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "pinch of salt, to taste"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a blender or food processor, puree the fresh strawberries. You should have a little more than 1 cup (about 270g). Transfer the puree to a small saucepan over medium-low heat. Simmer, stirring occasionally, until it&#8217;s reduced to 1/2 cup (about 135g). This usually takes around 25\u201335 minutes, but could take longer depending on your pan or the ripeness of your strawberries. Remove from heat, pour into a heat-safe bowl, and cool completely before using. I always make the reduced puree the day before so it has plenty of time to cool down. Cover and refrigerate overnight. Allow it to come back to room temperature before adding to the cake batter. (See Notes for additional make-ahead instructions.)", "name": "Make the reduced strawberry puree first, and let cool", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/strawberry-cake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Grease two 9-inch round cake pans, line with parchment paper rounds, then grease the parchment paper. Parchment paper helps the cakes seamlessly release from the pans. (If it&#8217;s helpful, see this parchment paper rounds for cakes video &amp; post.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/strawberry-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl, whisk the cake flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt together. Set aside.", "name": "Make the cake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/strawberry-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on medium-high speed until light and creamy, about 3 minutes. Add the egg whites and beat on high speed until combined, about 2 minutes. Scrape down the sides of the bowl as needed. Add the sour cream and vanilla extract and beat on medium-high speed until combined, about 1 minute. Add the dry ingredients and then, with the mixer running on low speed, slowly pour in the milk and beat until just combined. Do not overmix. Whisk in the room-temperature reduced strawberry puree and food coloring (if using), making sure there are no lumps at the bottom of the bowl. The batter should be slightly thick. Pour the batter evenly into the prepared cake pans.\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/strawberry-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 24\u201325 minutes or until a toothpick inserted in the center of the cake comes out clean. Cool the cakes in the pans set on a cooling rack for 1 hour. Run a knife around the edges to loosen the sides, remove the cakes from the pan, peel off the parchment, and place on the rack to finish cooling. The cakes must be completely cool before frosting and assembling.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/strawberry-cake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a blender or food processor, process the freeze-dried strawberries into a fine powder. If any larger bits remain, sift the powder through a fine-mesh sieve. Set aside.", "name": "Make the frosting:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/strawberry-cake/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the cream cheese and butter on medium-high speed until smooth, about 2 minutes. Scrape down the sides of the bowl as needed. Add the confectioners&#8217; sugar, strawberry powder, milk, and vanilla. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, then gradually increase to high speed and beat for 3 minutes until completely combined and creamy. Taste, then beat in a pinch of salt if the frosting is too sweet. Cover and refrigerate it for 1 hour before using. Yields about 3 cups (720g) of frosting.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/strawberry-cake/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "(For additional help with this step, see this how to assemble a layer cake video &amp; post.) First, level the cakes: using a large serrated knife, slice a thin layer off the tops of the cakes to create a flat surface. Discard (or crumble over ice cream!). Place 1 cake layer on your cake stand, cake turntable, or serving plate. Spread 3/4\u20131 cup (180\u2013240g) of frosting in an even layer on top. Top with the second layer, upside down, and spread 1 cup (240g) of frosting all over the top and sides in a very thin layer to make a crumb coat. Run a bench scraper around the cake to help smooth out the frosting on the sides. Refrigerate the cake until the crumb coat has set, about 20 minutes. Cover the top and sides with the remaining frosting. Before slicing, refrigerate the cake for at least 20 minutes to set the frosting and help the cake keep its shape when slicing\u2014it could slightly fall apart without time in the fridge.\u00a0", "name": "Assemble and frost", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/strawberry-cake/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftover cake tightly and store in the refrigerator for up to 5 days. If the cake has been in the refrigerator for more than 4 hours, take it out 2 hours before serving so it can mostly come to room temperature.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/strawberry-cake/#instruction-step-9"}], "prepTime": "PT1H30M", "cookTime": "PT25M", "totalTime": "PT6H", "recipeYield": ["10", "serves 10-12"], "recipeCategory": "Cakes", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "689", "ratingValue": "4.7"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Strawberry Cake | Sally's Baking Recipes", "description": "The one thing that sets this strawberry cake apart from others? These soft, slightly fudgy cookies get their bold flavor from cocoa and espresso powder, and their intricate look comes straight from the stamp\u2014no decorating skills required. Perfect for gifting, holiday baking, or anytime you want an impressive-looking cookie with minimal effort.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "stamped chocolate espresso cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/stamped-chocolate-espresso-cookies-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/stamped-chocolate-espresso-cookies-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/stamped-chocolate-espresso-cookies-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/stamped-chocolate-espresso-cookies-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/stamped-chocolate-espresso-cookies/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 and 1/2 cups (188g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "3/4 cup (62g) unsweetened natural or Dutch-process cocoa powder, plus more as needed", "2 teaspoons espresso powder", "1 teaspoon baking powder", "1/8 teaspoon salt", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 cup (200g) granulated sugar", "1 large egg, at room temperature", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1 teaspoon espresso powder", "2 Tablespoons (30g/ml) warm water", "1 and 1/2 cups (180g) confectioners&#8217; sugar, sifted", "2 Tablespoons (30g/ml) milk (dairy or nondairy)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, cocoa powder, espresso powder, baking powder, and salt. Set aside.", "name": "Make the cookies", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/stamped-chocolate-espresso-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld or a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on medium-high speed until smooth and creamy, about 3 minutes. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Add the egg and vanilla and beat on medium-high speed until combined, about 1 minute. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl and beat again as needed to combine.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/stamped-chocolate-espresso-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients and mix on low speed until combined. The dough will be soft and sticky. Cover the bowl tightly and refrigerate for at least 1 hour and up to 2 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/stamped-chocolate-espresso-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Line large baking sheets with\u00a0parchment paper\u00a0or\u00a0silicone baking mats. Scoop a heaping Tablespoon (about 30g) of chilled cookie dough per cookie and roll into balls. Arrange dough balls 3 inches apart on the prepared baking sheets. Place the cookie stamp directly on top of each cookie dough ball, centering it as best as you can, then firmly press down until the dough extends nearly to the edges of the cookie stamp. Lift straight up. If your cookie dough is sticking to the cookie stamp, use a pastry brush to lightly brush cocoa powder on the stamp before stamping the cookie dough ball. You can then brush the excess cocoa powder off the tops of the stamped cookies, if desired.", "name": "Roll and stamp", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/stamped-chocolate-espresso-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Chill the stamped cookies in the refrigerator for 1 hour before baking.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/stamped-chocolate-espresso-cookies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/stamped-chocolate-espresso-cookies/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake the cookies until the edges are set, about 11\u201313 minutes. Whisk in the confectioners&#8217; sugar and milk/cream. For thinner glaze, whisk in more milk. For thicker glaze, whisk in more confectioners&#8217; sugar. Using a pastry brush, brush the glaze on top of the cookies (or you can dip the tops of the cookies in the glaze). Add the sugar and beat on high speed for 2 minutes until creamed together. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a rubber spatula as needed. Add the egg whites and vanilla extract. Beat on medium-high speed until combined, then beat in the sour cream. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. With the mixer on low speed, add the dry ingredients until just incorporated. With the mixer still running on low, slowly pour in the milk until combined. Do not over-mix. You may need to whisk it all by hand to make sure there are no lumps at the bottom of the bowl. The batter will be slightly thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/6-inch-cake-recipes/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour batter evenly into cake pans.\u00a0Bake for around 18-21 minutes or until the cakes are baked through.\u00a0To test for doneness, insert a toothpick into the center of the cake. Add 4 and 1/2 cups confectioners\u2019 sugar, the heavy cream, and vanilla extract. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, then increase to medium-high speed and beat for 2 full minutes. Add up to 1/2 cup more confectioners\u2019 sugar if frosting is too thin or another Tablespoon of cream if frosting is too thick. Add a pinch of salt if frosting is too sweet. Top with 2nd cake layer and evenly cover the top with about 3/4 cup of frosting. Top with the third cake layer. Spread the remaining frosting all over the top and sides. A bench scraper and small offset spatula are handy for decorating. The batter will be very thick, like pudding.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-white-chocolate-cupcakes/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Divide the batter between 12 liners in your cupcake pan. Set it aside to cool at room temperature for 20 minutes. (Be sure the melted white chocolate has cooled for 20 minutes, so it&#8217;s still melted but not scorching hot, which would melt the butter.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/chocolate-white-chocolate-cupcakes/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter on medium speed for 1 minute. Switch the mixer to medium speed and beat for 2 minutes until combined and creamy. Add the cream, vanilla extract, and salt. Beat for 1 minute until combined. Taste. Add 1 more Tablespoon of heavy cream/milk if needed to thin out, if desired. Set that aside as well.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-swirl-pound-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In the bowl of a stand mixer, or using a handheld mixer, beat the softened butter and sugar together on medium speed until light and fluffy; about 3 minutes. With the mixer running on low speed, add the egg/vanilla mixture and continue to beat until smooth and light in color. With the mixer running on low speed, slowly add the dry ingredients until just combined. The batter is very thick and very sticky. Do not overmix the batter.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-swirl-pound-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread 1/3 of the batter into prepared loaf pan. Spread 6 Tablespoons of the Nutella on top. Nutella is very thick and hard to spread, but do your best to make it one even layer. Repeat with another 1/3 of the batter and the rest of the Nutella. Top with remaining cake batter.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-swirl-pound-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake the pound cake for 50-60 minutes. Cover with aluminum foil after 25 minutes to avoid the top and sides form browning too much. Slight browning is OK. The cake is done when a toothpick inserted in the center comes out free of cake crumbs (with some Nutella). The original recipe stated 1 hour and 15 minutes, but that was much too long for my cake. I fear it would be burnt and dry. 50 minutes is how long mine took, but yours may take longer.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-swirl-pound-cake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Allow the cake to cool completely in the pan on a wire rack before slicing and serving. Filling the crinkle cookies with Nutella is completely optional. If you don't want to take the time for this extra shaping step, you can make these Nutella crinkle cookies without filling. There's still plenty of Nutella flavor in there! After chilling the dough, roll the dough into balls, about 1.5 Tablespoons (35\u201340g) of dough per cookie, and then continue with rolling the dough balls in the sugars.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-crinkle-cookies/#faq-question-1701424070738", "position": 2, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-crinkle-cookies/#faq-question-1701424070738", "name": "Do I have to add hazelnuts to the dough?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "There needs to be an add-in in this cookie dough, or else they will spread too much. Instead of chopped hazelnuts, you can use chocolate chips.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Nutella Crinkle Cookies", "description": "Chocolatey and packed with crunchy hazelnuts, these Nutella crinkle cookies are thick and soft-baked, and stuffed with a little extra Nutella in the middle for good measure! Filling the cookies is optional\u2014see Notes.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "Nutella crinkle cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/11/nutella-crinkles-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/11/nutella-crinkles-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/11/nutella-crinkles-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/11/nutella-crinkles-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-crinkle-cookies/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 and 1/2 cups (313g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "2 Tablespoons (10g) unsweetened natural cocoa powder", "1 teaspoon baking soda", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "3/4 cup (150g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1/3 cup (67g) granulated sugar", "1 large egg + 1 egg yolk, at room temperature", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "3/4 cup\u00a0(225g)\u00a0Nutella", "3/4 cup (94g) chopped hazelnuts", "1/3 cup (100g) Nutella", "1/3 cup (67g) granulated sugar", "3/4 cup (90g) confectioners&#8217; sugar, plus more as needed to sift on top"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "This first step is optional, but I highly recommend it for best hazelnut flavor. Spread the chopped hazelnuts on a lined baking sheet. Bake in a 300\u00b0F (149\u00b0C) oven for 5\u20137 minutes, or until slightly darkened. Allow to cool for at least 5 minutes before using in the dough in step 4.", "name": "Optional toast the hazelnuts:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-crinkle-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl, whisk the flour, cocoa powder, baking soda, and salt together until combined. Set aside.", "name": "Make the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-crinkle-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter, brown sugar, and granulated sugar together on medium-high speed until fluffy and light in color, about 3 minutes. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) Add the egg, egg yolk, and vanilla extract, and beat until incorporated. Add the Nutella, then beat on high speed until combined. Scrape down the sides and bottom of the bowl as needed.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-crinkle-cookies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the dry ingredients to the bowl with the wet ingredients, and beat on low speed until combined. Add the chopped hazelnuts and beat on low until incorporated. The cookie dough will be very thick, soft, and sticky. Cover dough tightly and chill in the refrigerator for at least 2 hours and up to 3 days. Chilling is mandatory for this soft cookie dough.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-crinkle-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line large baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. (Always recommended for cookies.) Place the granulated sugar in a small bowl and the confectioners&#8217; sugar in another bowl, for rolling. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-crinkle-cookies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "After chilling in the refrigerator, the cookie dough will be very crumbly and that&#8217;s ok. The warmth of your hands quickly makes the dough workable. Scoop dough and roll into balls, a very scant Tablespoon (17g) of dough each. Make an indent with your finger or thumb in the center of each dough ball, and pinch and mold until they resemble small &#8220;bowls.&#8221; Add a scant 1/2 teaspoon of Nutella into the indent of half of the dough &#8220;bowls.&#8221; Place the other (empty) bowl-shaped pieces of dough over the top of the Nutella-filled pieces, and gently pinch the sides together to seal. Gently roll each of the stuffed dough balls in your hands to smooth out into a nice round ball.", "name": "Shape &amp; fill the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-crinkle-cookies/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Roll the cookie dough ball first in the granulated sugar, then very generously in the confectioners&#8217; sugar. (Altogether, each filled and sugared dough ball should weigh about 40g.) Place the dough balls 3 inches apart on the lined baking sheets.", "name": "Coat the dough balls", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-crinkle-cookies/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake the cookies for 11\u201312 minutes or until the edges appear set and the centers still look soft.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-crinkle-cookies/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cool cookies for 5 minutes on the baking sheet, and then transfer to a cooling rack to cool completely. You&#8217;ll notice the confectioners&#8217; sugar coating is quite sticky while the cookies are warm, and it may absorb into the cookie a bit. The coating may take on a yellow tint because of this.
