Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mini-powdered-sugar-donut-muffins/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on high speed until creamy and combined, about 3 minutes. (Here\u2019s a helpful tutorial if you need guidance on\u00a0how to cream butter and sugar.) On medium speed, beat in the egg and vanilla extract. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a silicone spatula and beat again as needed to combine. (Mixture may appear curdled\u2014that\u2019s ok.) Add the flour, baking powder, cinnamon, and salt. Beat on low speed and with the mixer running, slowly pour in the milk and beat on low until combined. The batter will be thick.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mini-powdered-sugar-donut-muffins/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon batter into mini muffin wells filling 2/3 full.\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/mini-powdered-sugar-donut-muffins/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 12-14 minutes or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean or when lightly poked, the donut muffin bounces back. Melt butter in a heatproof bowl in the microwave or melt over low heat on the stove. Pour the confectioners&#8217; sugar in a medium bowl. Lightly dunk a muffin (they can still be warm at this point) in the melted butter. Submerge in the confectioners&#8217; sugar to coat the surface generously. 56g) unsalted butter, melted", "1/4 cup (50g) granulated sugar", "32 ounces (904g) full-fat brick cream cheese, softened to room temperature", "1 and 1/2 cups (300g) granulated sugar", "1/3 cup (80g) full-fat sour cream, at room temperature", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "3 large eggs, at room temperature", "1 cup (227g) pumpkin puree*", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons ground cinnamon", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons store-bought or homemade pumpkin pie spice*", "topping suggestions: salted caramel\u00a0and\u00a0whipped cream"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Adjust the oven rack to the lower-middle position and preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-cheesecake/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Using a food processor, pulse the\u00a0gingersnap cookies into crumbs. Pour into a medium bowl and stir in ginger, cinnamon, sugar, and melted butter until combined. (You can also pulse it all together in the food processor.) Mixture will be sandy. Press firmly into the bottom and slightly up the sides of a 9-inch or 10-inch springform pan. No need to grease the pan first. I use the bottom of a measuring cup to pack the crust down tightly. Pre-bake for 10 minutes. Remove from the oven and place the hot pan on a large piece of aluminum foil. The foil will wrap around the pan for the water bath in step 5. Allow crust to slightly cool as you prepare the filling.", "name": "Make the crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-cheesecake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the cream cheese and granulated sugar together on medium-high speed in a large bowl until the mixture is smooth and creamy, about 2 minutes. Add the sour cream and vanilla extract, then beat until fully combined. On medium speed, add the eggs one at a time, beating after each addition until just blended. After the final egg is incorporated into the batter, stop mixing. To help prevent the cheesecake from deflating and cracking as it cools, avoid over-mixing the batter as best you can.", "name": "Make the filling:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-cheesecake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Scoop out 2 cups of batter and place in a medium mixing bowl. Stir in the pumpkin, cinnamon, and pumpkin pie spice until combined. Begin adding spoonfuls of each batter, the plain and the pumpkin, on top of the crust. Alternate until all the batter is used and pan is filled. Using a toothpick or knife, swirl the batters together by dragging the toothpick top to bottom, then left to right.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-cheesecake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If needed for extra visuals, see my How to Make a Cheesecake Water Bath; the visual guide will assist you in this step. Boil a pot of water. You need 1 inch of water in your roasting pan for the water bath, so make sure you boil enough. I use an entire kettle of hot water. Place the pan inside of a large roasting pan. Carefully pour the hot water inside of the pan and place in the oven. (Or you can place the roasting pan in the oven first, then pour the hot water in. Whichever is easier for you.)", "name": "Prepare the simple water bath (see note)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-cheesecake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "(Note: if you notice the cheesecake browning too quickly on top, tent it with aluminum foil halfway through baking.) Bake cheesecake for 55-70 minutes or until the center is almost set. When it&#8217;s done, the center of the cheesecake will slightly wobble if you gently shake the pan.\u00a0Turn the oven off and open the oven door slightly. Let the cheesecake sit in the oven for 1 hour as it cools down. Remove cheesecake from the oven and allow to cool completely at room temperature, then refrigerate the cheesecake for at least 4 hours or overnight.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-cheesecake/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Use a knife to loosen the chilled cheesecake from the rim of the springform pan, then remove the rim. Add toppings, if desired. Using a clean sharp knife, cut into slices for serving. For neat slices, wipe the knife clean and dip into warm water between each slice.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-cheesecake/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover and store leftover cheesecake in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/pumpkin-cheesecake/#instruction-step-8"}], "prepTime": "PT45M", "cookTime": "PT1H", "totalTime": "PT9H45M", "recipeYield": ["12", "serves at least 12"], "recipeCategory": "Cheesecake", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "106", "ratingValue": "4.9"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Heidi"}, "datePublished": "2025-11-27", "reviewBody": "Absolutely amazing! You really want it packed in tight- as tight as possible. Bake for 20-22 minutes. Remove from the oven and allow to cool completely in the pan set on a wire rack for 1 hour, then transfer to the refrigerator to chill for 1 more hour. This helps firm up the bars which makes\u00a0them stay compact. Remove\u00a0bars from the pan using the overhang on the sides\u00a0and cut into bars.\u00a0Individually wrap each bar in plastic wrap or parchment. Set aside. Using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with the paddle attachment, beat the butter on medium speed in a large bowl until smooth and creamy, about 2 minutes. Add the brown sugar and mix on medium until light and fluffy, about 3 full minutes. Using a silicone spatula, scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. Add the egg whites and vanilla extract and mix until fully incorporated, about 2 minutes.", "name": "Make the cookie dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookie-dough-frosting/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add half of the flour mixture and mix on low just until the powdery texture of the flour disappears, about 15 seconds. Add the vanilla extract, milk, and salt and beat until combined. Using a silicone spatula, scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. Add the confectioners&#8217; sugar, then beat on low speed for 15 seconds. Switch to medium-high speed and beat the frosting until super light and fluffy, about 4-5 minutes. The frosting will become lighter in color as air is whipped into it.", "name": "Make the buttercream", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/cookie-dough-frosting/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Break the cookie dough into quarter-size chunks. The classic mint chocolate combination!", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "mint chocolate brownies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/Classic-Mint-Chocolate-Brownies-Recipe-on-sallysbakingaddiction.com-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/Classic-Mint-Chocolate-Brownies-Recipe-on-sallysbakingaddiction.com-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/Classic-Mint-Chocolate-Brownies-Recipe-on-sallysbakingaddiction.com-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/Classic-Mint-Chocolate-Brownies-Recipe-on-sallysbakingaddiction.com-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/classic-mint-chocolate-brownies/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup (16 Tbsp; 226g) unsalted butter", "8 ounces semi-sweet chocolate, coarsely chopped", "1 and 1/2 cups (300g) granulated sugar", "1/2 cup (100g) packed light brown sugar", "4 large eggs, at room temperature", "2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "1/2 cup + 3 Tablespoons (86g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1/4 cup (21g) natural unsweetened cocoa powder", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "2 cups (240g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "2 Tablespoons (30ml) milk", "1 and 1/4 teaspoons peppermint extract*", "optional: 1 drop liquid or gel green food coloring", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter", "1 heaping cup (around 200g) semi-sweet chocolate chips"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Melt the butter and chopped chocolate in a medium saucepan on medium heat, stirring constantly, about 5 minutes. Or melt in a medium microwave safe bowl in 20 second increments, stirring after each, in the microwave. Remove from the heat, pour into a large mixing bowl, and allow to slightly cool for 10 minutes.", "name": "For the brownies", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/classic-mint-chocolate-brownies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Adjust the oven rack to the lower third position and preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Line the bottom and sides of a 9&#215;13-inch baking pan* with parchment paper, leaving an overhang on all sides. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/classic-mint-chocolate-brownies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the granulated and brown sugars into the cooled chocolate/butter mixture. Add the eggs, one at a time, whisking until smooth after each addition. Whisk in the vanilla. Gently fold in the salt, flour, and cocoa powder. Pour batter into the prepared baking pan and bake for 35-36 minutes or until the brownies begin to pull away from the edges of the pan. A toothpick inserted in the center should come out with only a few moist crumbs when the brownies are done. All ovens are different, so keep an eye on them after 30 minutes and use the toothpick test to see when yours are finished. Allow the brownies to cool completely in the pan set on a wire rack. Once completely cooled, lift the foil out of the pan using the overhang on the sides.\u00a0Place\u00a0the whole thing on a baking sheet\u00a0as you make the frosting. Do not cut into squares yet.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/classic-mint-chocolate-brownies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0In a medium bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter on medium speed until smooth and creamy, about 2 minutes. Add the confectioners\u2019 sugar and milk. Beat for 2 minutes on low speed, then increase to high speed and beat for 1 additional minute. Add the peppermint\u00a0extract and food coloring (if using) and beat on high for 1 full minute. Taste and add a drop or two more peppermint extract if desired. Frost cooled brownies, that you placed\u00a0on the baking sheet, and place the baking sheet in the refrigerator. This allows the frosting to &#8220;set&#8221; on top of the brownies which makes spreading the chocolate layer easy. Keep in the refrigerator for at least 1 hour and up to 4 hours.", "name": "For the mint frosting layer", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/classic-mint-chocolate-brownies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "\u00a0Melt the butter and chocolate chips in a medium saucepan on medium heat, stirring constantly, about 5 minutes. Or melt in a medium microwave safe bowl in 20 second increments, stirring after each, in the microwave. Once melted and smooth, pour over mint layer. Gently spread with a knife or offset spatula. Place the\u00a0brownies, that are still on the baking sheet, in the refrigerator and chill for 1 hour (and up to 4 hours or even overnight) to set the chocolate.", "name": "For the chocolate layer", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/classic-mint-chocolate-brownies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Once chilled, remove from the refrigerator and cut into squares. For neat cutting,\u00a0make very quick cuts, using a\u00a0very sharp large knife, and\u00a0wiping the knife off\u00a0with a paper towel between each cut. Brownies are OK at room temperature for a few hours.\u00a0Cover tightly\u00a0and keep leftovers in the\u00a0refrigerator for up to 5 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/classic-mint-chocolate-brownies/#instruction-step-6"}], "prepTime": "PT1H", "cookTime": "PT35M", "totalTime": "PT6H", "recipeYield": ["24", "24-30 brownies"], "recipeCategory": "Brownies", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "31", "ratingValue": "4.9"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Karoline Schafir Brock"}, "datePublished": "2025-08-03", "reviewBody": "This recipe makes amazing mint brownies!  Tons of compliments!  The process was a bit cumbersome and baking the brownies on top of parchment paper and removing them to a baking sheet was difficult.  (The parchment made uneven and overcooked edges and I broke each sheet of brownies in half while transferring to baking sheet.) The third batch, I baked in a greased 9x13\" pan and kept the brownies in the pan as I layered the mint frosting and ganache topping.  Worked much better!  \r\nCutting them was actually simple.  Be sure the entire pan is cold!  (Maybe a touch longer than 1 hr in refrigerator.). Soak a long sturdy, but thin, sharp knife, in very hot clean water; wipe excess water from knife before quickly slicing brownies.  Resoak and wipe knife between each line.  Works great and the brownies were delish!!"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "wowza"}, "datePublished": "2025-08-08", "reviewBody": "These brownies are amazing. Reducing the apple cider and using lots of cinnamon spice are both key to the incredible flavor.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "apple pie, apple cider, cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/apple-spice-whoopie-pies-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/apple-spice-whoopie-pies-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/apple-spice-whoopie-pies-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/apple-spice-whoopie-pies-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-spice-whoopie-pies/", "recipeIngredient": ["2 cups (480ml) apple cider", "3 cups (375g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 teaspoon baking powder", "1/2 teaspoon baking soda", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons ground cinnamon", "1/2 teaspoon ground ginger", "1/2 teaspoon ground nutmeg", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "3/4 cup (150g) granulated sugar", "1/4 cup (50g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "2 Tablespoons (30ml) vegetable oil\u00a0(or melted coconut oil)", "3/4 cup (180g) unsweetened applesauce, at room temperature", "2 large eggs, at room temperature", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "optional: cinnamon sugar for topping (see note)", "3/4 cup (12 Tbsp; 170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "4 cups (480g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "1/8 teaspoon ground nutmeg", "1/8 teaspoon ground ginger", "3 Tablespoons (45ml) apple cider (or milk)", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "pinch of salt"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Stirring occasionally, boil the apple cider in a small saucepan over medium-high heat until you\u2019re left with 1/2 cup. Start checking at 15 minutes, 20 minutes, 25 minutes, etc until you have 1/2 cup (120ml). Mine takes about 25 minutes. Cool for 10 minutes before using in step 4. You can even reduce the apple cider the day ahead of time. Cover and refrigerate overnight, then bring to room temperature before using.", "name": "Reduce the apple cider", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-spice-whoopie-pies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). In another large bowl using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter, granulated sugar, and brown sugar together on medium-high speed until creamed, about 1 minute. Add the oil, applesauce, eggs, and vanilla extract and beat on high speed until combined, about 1-2 minutes. The mixture will look curdled as a result of the varying textures trying to combine. This is OK and it will come together when you add the dry ingredients. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl and beat again as needed to combine.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-spice-whoopie-pies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the dry ingredients to the wet ingredients, pour in the 1/2 cup of reduced apple cider, then mix on low until completely combined. See recipe note.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-spice-whoopie-pies/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake the cookies for 12-14 minutes or until the edges are very lightly browned and the tops spring back when lightly touched. Mine usually take 13 minutes. Remove from the oven and allow cookies to cool on the baking sheet for 5 minutes before transferring to a wire rack to cool completely. I love this recipe. I followed the whoopie pie recipe exactly but made one change to the baked whoopie to increase the apple cider flavor.  I reduced 4 cups of cider so I would have a total of 1 cup of reduction: Mix 1/4 cup of the extra reduced cider with two tablespoons of melted unsalted butter. Using a pastry brush, brush the tops of the whoopies with that mixture as soon as they are removed from the oven and immediately sprinkle with the cinnamon sugar topping. Quick tip, only brush the reduction on a few whoopies at a time. They seemed to dry quickly and the cinnamon sugar topping didn\u2019t stick as well. 113g) unsalted butter", "2 ounces semi-sweet baking chocolate", "1 heaping Tablespoon instant coffee*", "1/2 cup (41g) unsweetened cocoa powder\u00a0(not Dutch processed)", "3/4 cup (94g) all-purpose flour* (spooned &amp; leveled)", "1/2 teaspoon baking soda", "3/4 teaspoon baking powder", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "2 large eggs, at room temperature", "1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar", "1/4 cup (50g) packed\u00a0light brown sugar", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1/2 teaspoon peppermint extract", "1/2 cup (120ml) buttermilk*", "1 cup (16 Tbsp; 226g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "3-4 cups (360-480g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1/4 cup (60ml) heavy cream*", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1/4 teaspoon peppermint extract", "salt, to taste", "optional for garnish: 4 ounces melted semi-sweet baking chocolate and\u00a0crushed candy canes"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Microwave in 30 second increments, stirring between each time. You may also melt the butter and chocolate over low heat on the stovetop. Stir until combined, then mix in the instant coffee. Set aside to slightly cool.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peppermint-mocha-cupcakes/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl, toss the cocoa powder, flour, baking soda, baking powder, and salt together until thoroughly combined. Set aside. In a large bowl, whisk the eggs, sugar, brown sugar, vanilla extract, and peppermint extract together until smooth. Add the cooled butter/chocolate and whisk until smooth. Add half of the flour mixture, then half of the buttermilk. Repeat until everything is added. Stir until *just* combined; do not overmix. The batter will be very thick like pudding.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/peppermint-mocha-cupcakes/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Divide the batter between 12 liners in your cupcake pan. Beat for about 3 minutes until smooth and creamy. Add confectioners&#8217; sugar, heavy cream, vanilla extract, and peppermint extract with the mixer running. Increase to high speed and beat for 3 full minutes (the longer you beat, the creamier the frosting!). Add more confectioners&#8217; sugar if frosting is too thin or more cream if frosting is too thick. Sally\u2019s work has been featured on TODAY, Good Morning America, Taste of Home, People, and more.", "sameAs": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"]}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Tiramisu Crepe Cake", "description": "This recipe yields a 50 layer 8-inch wide crepe cake. Make sure you chill the crepe batter in the refrigerator before cooking the crepes and chill the assembled cake before serving. With the piped whipped cream on top, this cake is about 7 inches tall.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "tiramisu, crepes, cake", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/crepe-tiramisu-cake-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/crepe-tiramisu-cake-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/crepe-tiramisu-cake-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/crepe-tiramisu-cake.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tiramisu-crepe-cake/", "recipeIngredient": ["6 Tablespoons (85g)\u00a0unsalted butter, plus 5 more Tablespoons (71g) for the pan", "2 cups (250g)\u00a0all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1/4 cup (50g)\u00a0granulated sugar", "1/4 teaspoon\u00a0salt", "2 cups (480ml) whole milk, at room temperature*", "1/2 cup (120ml) room temperature water", "4\u00a0large\u00a0eggs, at room temperature", "2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "2 teaspoons\u00a0espresso powder*", "2 teaspoons\u00a0warm water", "1 and 1/2 cups (360ml) cold heavy cream", "1 Tablespoon (15ml) rum or Grand Marnier* (optional)", "8 ounces (1 cup) mascarpone, cold or at room temperature", "1 cup (120g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1/4 cup (21g) unsweetened natural or dutch-process cocoa powder (optional)", "1/2 cup (120ml) cold heavy cream", "1 Tablespoon (15ml) rum or Grand Marnier* (optional)", "2 Tablespoons (15g) confectioners&#8217; sugar", "1 teaspoon unsweetened natural or dutch-process\u00a0cocoa powder (optional)"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "If you&#8217;ve never made crepes before, I strongly recommend reviewing my How to Make Crepes tutorial post, which includes plenty of helpful success tips and a video tutorial.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tiramisu-crepe-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Melt 6 Tablespoons of butter in the microwave or on the stove. Cool for about 5 minutes before using in the next step. The remaining butter is for the skillet.", "name": "Make the crepes batter", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tiramisu-crepe-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the cooled melted butter, flour, sugar, salt, milk, water, eggs, and vanilla in a blender or large food processor. If you don\u2019t have a blender or food processor, use a large mixing bowl and whisk by hand. Blend on medium-high speed for 20-30 seconds until everything is combined. The mixture will be silky smooth and the consistency of cream, much thinner than pancake batter. Cover the blender tightly or pour into a medium bowl, cover tightly, and chill in the refrigerator for 1 hour and up to 1 day. This time in the refrigerator is imperative because it gives the flour a chance to become fully hydrated.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tiramisu-crepe-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Use the remaining butter for greasing the pan between each crepe. Place an 8-inch skillet over medium heat and generously grease it with some of the reserved butter. If you don\u2019t have a skillet this size, use a larger one but make sure you keep the crepes thin. Once the skillet is hot, pour 3-4 Tablespoons (closer to 3 is best) of batter into the center of the pan. Tilt/twirl the pan so the batter stretches as far as it will go. The thinner the crepe, the better the texture. Cook for 1-2 minutes, then flip as soon as the bottom is set. Don\u2019t wait too long to flip crepes or else they will taste rubbery. Cook the other side for 30 seconds until set. Transfer the cooked crepe to a large plate and repeat with the remaining batter, making sure to butter the pan between each crepe. If desired, separate each crepe with parchment paper so they do not stick together. Though, if using enough butter in your pan, the crepes won\u2019t stick. Yields about 28 crepes.", "name": "Cook the crepes", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tiramisu-crepe-cake/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Loosely cover and set your crepes aside at room temperature as you prepare the tiramisu filling. You can also tightly cover and refrigerate the crepes for up to 1 day. Crepes must be room temperature or cold before you begin assembling the cake.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tiramisu-crepe-cake/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "First part of the tiramisu filling is to prepare concentrated espresso flavoring. Using a fork, mix the espresso powder and warm water together in a very small bowl. Set aside to cool down for a few minutes. You will mix it with the mascarpone. Using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, whip the heavy cream and rum (if using) together on medium-high speed until medium peaks form, about 3-4 minutes. Medium peaks are between soft/loose peaks and stiff peaks. Set whipped cream aside. With a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle or whisk attachment, beat the mascarpone, confectioners&#8217; sugar, vanilla extract, and cooled espresso liquid together on medium speed in a large bowl until combined and smooth, about 2 minutes. Fold the whipped cream into the mascarpone mixture. Don&#8217;t worry if it looks curdled\u2014mine sometimes does\u2014it doesn&#8217;t taste that way and will smooth out when it&#8217;s stacked in the cake. Use filling immediately or cover and chill in the refrigerator for up to 1 day. Yields about 4 cups filling.", "name": "Make the tiramisu filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tiramisu-crepe-cake/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread 1-2 teaspoons of filling on the center of your cake stand or cake serving plate. This helps adhere the cake to the plate. Place a crepe on top. Spread about 2 heaping Tablespoons of filling evenly on top. If desired, dust with cocoa powder. Repeat layering crepes, filling, and a dusting of cocoa powder. Top with final and last crepe.", "name": "Assemble the cake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tiramisu-crepe-cake/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "You can frost the cake with whipped cream before or after chilling the cake in the refrigerator in step 9. My advice\u2014I find it tastes better and slices easier if you chill the cake WITH the whipped cream on top. Using a hand mixer or a stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, whip the heavy cream, rum (if using), and confectioners&#8217; sugar together on medium-high speed until medium peaks form, about 3-4 minutes. Medium peaks are between soft/loose peaks and stiff peaks and are the perfect consistency for spreading or piping. Spread or pipe whipped cream on top of the cake. If you have extra, feel free to spread all around the sides of the cake too. If desired, dust with cocoa powder.", "name": "Whipped Cream Topping", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tiramisu-crepe-cake/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Refrigerate the cake for at least 3 hours and up to 1 day before serving. Chilling the cake in the refrigerator is imperative because the cake won&#8217;t slice otherwise. No need to cover the cake if you&#8217;re chilling it for only 3 hours. If chilling longer than that, I recommend loosely covering the cake.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tiramisu-crepe-cake/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftover cake and store in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tiramisu-crepe-cake/#instruction-step-11"}], "prepTime": "PT2H", "cookTime": "PT1H", "totalTime": "PT5H", "recipeYield": ["8", "serves 8"], "recipeCategory": "Dessert", "cookingMethod": "Stovetop", "recipeCuisine": "French", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "22", "ratingValue": "4.7"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Tiramisu Crepe Cake | Sally's Baking Addiction", "description": "Learn how to make an impressive tiramisu crepe cake featuring 25 paper-thin homemade crepes, 24 layers of fluffy tiramisu filling, dustings of cocoa powder, and sweet whipped cream on top!\n\nGet the full recipe: https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/tiramisu-crepe-cake/\n\n\u2022 Ask your recipe question or leave a review over on the recipe page.\n\n#baking #recipes #crepecake\n\n\u2022 More of our favorite recipes: https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/", "duration": "PT2M", "embedUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/embed/H1xBmHDNMX4?feature=oembed", "contentUrl": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H1xBmHDNMX4", "thumbnailUrl": ["https://i.ytimg.com/vi/H1xBmHDNMX4/hqdefault.jpg"], "uploadDate": "2021-02-02T16:43:21+00:00"}, "review": [{"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Chris"}, "datePublished": "2022-02-20", "reviewBody": "My turkey baster allowed the perfect amount of batter for each crepe with very little mess - enjoyed the process of this cake, thanks for sharing!"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "5"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Kim Brauchle"}, "datePublished": "2022-08-09", "reviewBody": "I absolutely love this recipe and will definitely be making it again!!!"}, {"@type": "Review", "reviewRating": {"@type": "Rating", "ratingValue": "4"}, "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "CH"}, "datePublished": "2022-08-29", "reviewBody": "Made it for the first time but ran into a few issues. Hopefully they can be answered by the assistants here.\r\n\r\n1. At 3 Tbsp of batter per crepe (43g per crepe), the batter is enough to make 28 crepes. However the author suggests pouring 3-4 Tbsp of batter per crepe which is a wide range and changes things quite a bit. Since this was my first time making it and I found it challenging to twirl all the batter around a 8\" non-stick skillet, I was only able to squeeze 22 crepes out of the batter as I often found myself using 3.5~ Tbsp per crepe.\r\n\r\n2. After assembling 22 crepes + 22 layers of filling plus a layer of piped whip cream at the top, my cake was still less than 3\" high... how did the author reach 7\" in height? Was there an error in the recipe where we were not provided enough filling? Is the suggested measurement of \"2 heaping tablespoons\" not enough? Because when I tasted the cake, it tasted more crepe-y instead of creamy, and now when I cross reference between different recipes I am seeing pictures where the cream layers are more defined and thicker. Other recipes are calling for 1:1 ratio of crepe to cream/filling, so a 43g crepe should have 43g of cream/filling to match, yet we were only told to put \"2 heaping tablespoons\" which is ~30g at best. Meanwhile my crepes were closer to 50g (3.5 Tbsp) which means i was missing almost double the cream/filling per layer.\r\n\r\nThoughts on my observations? With only 8 ingredients, these bars are perfectly balanced\u2014not too sweet\u2014allowing the bright, bold lemon flavor to take center stage.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "greek yogurt lemon bars", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/tangy-lemon-greek-yogurt-bars-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/tangy-lemon-greek-yogurt-bars-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/tangy-lemon-greek-yogurt-bars-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/tangy-lemon-greek-yogurt-bars.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/130-calorie-greek-yogurt-lemon-bars/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 cup (120g) graham cracker crumbs (about 8 full-sheet graham crackers)", "1 Tablespoon (12g) granulated sugar", "3 Tablespoons (43g) unsalted butter, melted\u00a0(or melted coconut oil)", "6 ounces (170g) brick cream cheese, softened to room temperature", "3/4 cup (181g) plain nonfat or low-fat Greek yogurt, at room temperature", "2 large eggs, at room temperature*", "1 large egg yolk, at room temperature*", "1/3 cup (67g) granulated sugar", "1/3 cup (80ml) fresh lemon juice (about 2-3 lemons)*", "1 Tablespoon lemon zest*", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "optional for garnish: lemon slices and fresh blueberries"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 300\u00b0F (149\u00b0C). Line the bottom and sides of an 8-inch square baking pan with parchment paper, leaving an overhang on 2 sides to easily lift the bars out of the pan before cutting. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/130-calorie-greek-yogurt-lemon-bars/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a medium bowl, whisk the graham cracker crumbs and sugar together. Add the melted butter and stir until combined. Press evenly into the prepared baking pan. Bake for 8 minutes. Remove from the oven and set aside to cool slightly.", "name": "Make the crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/130-calorie-greek-yogurt-lemon-bars/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment, beat the cream cheese on high speed until completely smooth, about 1 minute. Add yogurt and beat on medium-high speed until completely combined. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a silicone spatula and beat again as needed to combine. Beat in the eggs and egg yolk. Once combined, add the sugar, lemon juice, lemon zest, and vanilla extract and beat until everything is combined and no lumps remain. Filling is thin. Pour filling into the crust\u2014it&#8217;s ok if the crust is still slightly warm.", "name": "Make the filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/130-calorie-greek-yogurt-lemon-bars/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 34\u201338 minutes or until the middle is no longer wobbly. A little jiggle is ok\u2014the bars will continue to set up as they chill in the refrigerator, so you don&#8217;t need to bake them until the center is perfectly solidified. Don&#8217;t over-bake these bars, or the surface may crack.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/130-calorie-greek-yogurt-lemon-bars/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Set the pan on a cooling rack and cool for 1 hour, then transfer to the refrigerator to chill for 3\u20134 hours or even overnight.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/130-calorie-greek-yogurt-lemon-bars/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Once chilled, lift the bars out of the pan using the parchment overhang on the sides and cut into bars. I recommend making the cheesecake batter first because the brownie batter thickens as it sits. And the thicker it is, the more difficult it is to swirl with the cheesecake.\u00a0", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "coconut cheesecake brownies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/coconut-brownies-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/coconut-brownies-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/coconut-brownies-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/08/coconut-brownies.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/coconut-cheesecake-brownies/", "recipeIngredient": ["8 ounces (226g) full-fat brick cream cheese, softened to room temperature", "2 Tablespoons (26g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "2 Tablespoons (15g) all-purpose flour", "1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar", "1 large egg, at room temperature", "1 teaspoon coconut extract", "1\u00a0and 1/4 cups (100g)\u00a0sweetened shredded coconut*", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter", "2 Tablespoons (30ml) vegetable oil or melted coconut oil", "1 cup (200g) granulated sugar", "2 large eggs, at room temperature", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "3/4 cup\u00a0(62g) unsweetened natural or dutch-process cocoa powder", "1/2 cup (63g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "1/4 teaspoon salt", "1 cup (180g) semi-sweet chocolate chips"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C).\u00a0Line a 9-inch square baking pan (I love this one) with parchment paper, leaving an overhang on the sides to easily lift the bars out of the pan. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/coconut-cheesecake-brownies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Using a handheld mixer or\u00a0stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the cream cheese and butter together on medium-high speed in a large bowl until the mixture is smooth and creamy, about 2 minutes. Add the flour, granulated sugar, egg, and coconut extract and beat until fully combined. Finally, beat in the shredded coconut on low speed until combined. Set aside at room temperature.", "name": "Make the cheesecake batter first", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/coconut-cheesecake-brownies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Slice the butter into Tablespoon-size pieces and melt in the microwave in a large heatproof bowl or in a small saucepan on the stove. (Transfer melted butter to a large bowl if using the stove.) Whisk the oil and granulated sugar into the melted butter. Let it sit for 3-5 minutes to slightly cool. Whisk in the eggs and vanilla extract until combined. Add the cocoa powder, flour, and salt and whisk until combined. Batter will be thick. Fold in the chocolate chips.", "name": "Make the brownie batter", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/coconut-cheesecake-brownies/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "(This step does NOT have to be exact or perfect. Do not overthink it&#8211; just spoon and swirl.) Spoon about 1/3 of the brownie batter into the prepared pan. Spread it all over the bottom as best you can. Take about 1/3 of the cheesecake batter and drop spoonfuls of it on top of the brownie batter. Use your spoon or a knife to gently swirl together. Use another 1/3 of the brownie batter and drop spoonfuls of it on top. Use another 1/3 of the cheesecake batter and drop spoonfuls of it on top. Gently swirl together. Repeat spooning remaining brownie and cheesecake batters. Gently swirl together.", "name": "Assemble", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/coconut-cheesecake-brownies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 40-42 minutes or until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out with only a few moist crumbs. I recommend tenting the brownies with aluminum foil after about 25 minutes to protect the top from over-browning. Remove from the oven and place the pan on a wire rack. The easy dough requires just 6 ingredients and there\u2019s hardly any rise time, so this is a wonderful recipe for yeast beginners. Have fun shaping the bites (they don\u2019t need to be perfect!) and enjoy warm flavorful homemade pretzels within an hour. Review recipe notes and watch the video tutorial before starting.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "soft pretzel bites", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/soft-pretzel-bites-homemade-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/soft-pretzel-bites-homemade-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/soft-pretzel-bites-homemade-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/soft-pretzel-bites-homemade.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-pretzel-bites/", "recipeIngredient": ["1\u00a0and 1/2 cups (360ml)\u00a0warm water (lukewarm\u2013no need to take temperature but around 100\u00b0F (38\u00b0C) is great)", "2\u00a0and 1/4 teaspoons (7g)\u00a0instant\u00a0or\u00a0active dry yeast\u00a0(1\u00a0standard packet)", "1 Tablespoon brown sugar or\u00a0granulated sugar", "1 teaspoon\u00a0salt", "1 Tablespoon (14g)\u00a0unsalted butter, melted and slightly cool", "3 and 3/4 &#8211; 4 cups (469-500g)\u00a0all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled), plus more for hands and work surface", "topping: coarse salt/coarse sea salt", "1/2 cup\u00a0(120g)\u00a0baking soda", "9 cups\u00a0(2,160ml)\u00a0water", "spicy cheese sauce or your favorite mustard"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk warm water, yeast, and sugar together in the bowl of your stand mixer fitted with a paddle or dough hook attachment. (If you do not have a stand mixer, just use a regular large mixing bowl and a wooden spoon or silicone spatula.) Cover yeast mixture and allow to sit for 5 minutes or until foamy on top. Add salt, melted butter, and 3 cups (375g) of flour. Beat on low speed for 1 minute, scrape down the sides of the bowl with a rubber spatula if needed, then add 3/4 cup (95g) of flour. Beat on low speed until the dough comes together and pulls away from the sides of the bowl, about 2 minutes. If dough is extremely sticky after 1 minute of mixing, add remaining 1/4 cup of flour and continue to beat for 1 more minute. (You can see in the video that I add the remaining flour.)", "name": "Make the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-pretzel-bites/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Keep the dough in the mixer (and switch to the dough hook if using the paddle) and beat for an additional 5 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 5 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my How to Knead Dough video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-pretzel-bites/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover lightly with a towel and allow to rest for 10-30 minutes. (Meanwhile, I like to get the water + baking soda boiling as instructed in step 5.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-pretzel-bites/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 400\u00b0F (204\u00b0C). Line 2 baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone baking mats. Silicone baking mats are highly recommended over parchment paper. If using parchment paper, lightly spray with nonstick spray or grease with butter. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-pretzel-bites/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "With a sharp knife, pizza cutter, or bench scraper, cut dough into 6 equal pieces (just eyeball it, doesn&#8217;t have to be perfect). Sprinkle work surface very lightly with flour. (Tip: The heavier you flour the work surface, the harder it is to roll the dough. A little stickiness actually helps. You only need *a very light* dusting of flour.) Roll each piece of dough into a 20-inch rope. If the ropes keep shrinking and stretching the dough becomes difficult, stop what you&#8217;re doing, lightly cover all of the dough, and let it rest for 10 minutes so the gluten can relax. Then, return to rolling it into ropes. Cut each rope into 1.5 &#8211; 2 inch pieces to make bites.", "name": "Shape", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-pretzel-bites/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Mix water and baking soda together in a large pot. Bring to a boil. Place 8-10 pretzel bites into the boiling water for a quick 10-15 seconds. (Any longer and your pretzels could take on a metallic taste.) Using a slotted spatula or spoon, lift the pretzel bites out of the water and allow as much of the excess water to drip off. Place bites onto prepared baking sheets. Sprinkle each with coarse sea salt while they are still wet or leave plain if using cinnamon sugar topping listed in the notes. Repeat baking soda bath with remaining pretzel bites. If needed, you can cover and refrigerate the boiled/unbaked bites for up to 24 hours before baking.", "name": "Baking Soda Bath", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-pretzel-bites/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 15 minutes or until golden brown. Remove from the oven and serve warm.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-pretzel-bites/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover and store leftover pretzel bites at room temperature for up to 3 days. They lose a little softness over time. If your peaches are mushy, your dessert will taste mushy.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/fresh-peach-cobbler/#faq-question-1689157554031", "position": 2, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/fresh-peach-cobbler/#faq-question-1689157554031", "name": "Do you have to peel peaches for peach cobbler?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "While I usually do, you don't have to peel the peaches when making this dessert.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/fresh-peach-cobbler/#faq-question-1689157495869", "position": 3, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/fresh-peach-cobbler/#faq-question-1689157495869", "name": "Can I make this cobbler with frozen or canned peaches?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Fresh peaches are best for cobbler, though you can get away with unsweetened frozen peaches. If using frozen peaches, thaw, chop, and blot them dry before using. Readers have raved about this dessert using frozen, thawed peaches. Canned peaches are not ideal because they\u2019re already too soft and mushy.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/fresh-peach-cobbler/#faq-question-1689157515837", "position": 4, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/fresh-peach-cobbler/#faq-question-1689157515837", "name": "Can I add or use other fruits?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "Many readers have asked about mixing in blueberries, cherries, plums, pluots, nectarines, etc. You can absolutely swap fruits, or use a mix of fruits, as long as you have a total of about 10 cups (1.5\u20131.8kg). I particularly love equal parts blueberries and peaches here. You may also like this <a href=\"https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/berry-cobbler/\">mixed berry cobbler</a>.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@type": "Question", "@id": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/fresh-peach-cobbler/#faq-question-1689157540711", "position": 5, "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/fresh-peach-cobbler/#faq-question-1689157540711", "name": "Can I make this without egg wash?", "answerCount": 1, "acceptedAnswer": {"@type": "Answer", "text": "I brush the biscuit topping with an egg wash (egg beaten with some buttermilk), so it's golden-brown, crisp, and shiny. You can skip the egg and brush with just buttermilk if desired.", "inLanguage": "en-US"}, "inLanguage": "en-US"}, {"@context": "https://schema.org/", "@type": "Recipe", "name": "Fresh Peach Cobbler", "description": "Juicy sweet peaches and buttery biscuits come together in this classic summer dessert. Cut the peaches into chunks for the best texture, and use this easy buttermilk biscuit topping for the best flavor. The egg wash promises a golden crisp topping.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "peach cobbler", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/delicious-peach-cobbler-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/delicious-peach-cobbler-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/delicious-peach-cobbler-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/delicious-peach-cobbler.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/fresh-peach-cobbler/", "recipeIngredient": ["10 cups (around 1.8kg) peeled chopped fresh peaches (1- to 1.5-inch chunks)", "1/4 cup (50g) packed light or dark brown sugar", "1 Tablespoon (7g) cornstarch", "1 Tablespoon (15ml) fresh lemon juice", "1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract", "1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon", "1/8 teaspoon ground nutmeg", "1/8 teaspoon ground ginger", "1/8 teaspoon salt", "2 cups (250g) all-purpose flour (spooned &amp; leveled)", "1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons baking powder", "1/4 teaspoon baking soda", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "1/2 cup (8 Tbsp; 113g) unsalted butter, cold and cubed", "1/2 cup (120ml) buttermilk, cold*", "egg wash:\u00a01 large egg beaten with 1 Tablespoon (15ml) milk or buttermilk", "optional: 2 Tablespoons (25g) granulated sugar mixed with 1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Lightly grease a 9&#215;13-inch baking pan. Any 3- to 4-quart baking dish works.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/fresh-peach-cobbler/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Mix all of the filling ingredients together in a large bowl, then spread into the baking pan. Bake for 10 minutes. Remove from the oven and set aside as you prepare the topping. Keep the oven on.", "name": "For the filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/fresh-peach-cobbler/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, sugar, baking powder, baking soda, and salt together in a large bowl. Using a pastry cutter or 2 forks, cut in the cold butter until the mixture resembles coarse pea-sized crumbles. A pastry cutter makes this step very easy and quick! You could also pulse in a food processor. Pour in the buttermilk, and gently mix until evenly combined. Dough should be slightly sticky once completely combined, but if it&#8217;s too dry, add 1 more Tablespoon of buttermilk.", "name": "For the topping", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/fresh-peach-cobbler/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Take handfuls of dough and use your hands to gently flatten out into patties. Place dough all over the top of the warm peach filling. There&#8217;s no special trick to this\u2014just flatten the dough in sections and cover most of the peaches.", "name": "Assemble the cobbler", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/fresh-peach-cobbler/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Brush the top of the biscuit dough with egg wash, then sprinkle with cinnamon-sugar, if using.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/fresh-peach-cobbler/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 40\u201350 minutes, or until the biscuit topping is golden brown and peach filling is bubbling around the edges. Everything comes together easily in one bowl, and the cook time is less than 10 minutes. Cook and store in the refrigerator or freezer for a quick grab-and-go breakfast perfect for busy mornings. Cook the patties in batches in a large skillet over medium-low heat. If using a nonstick skillet, I find medium heat is better.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "maple chicken sausage", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/homemade-maple-chicken-breakfast-sausage-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/homemade-maple-chicken-breakfast-sausage-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/homemade-maple-chicken-breakfast-sausage-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/homemade-maple-chicken-breakfast-sausage.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/maple-chicken-breakfast-sausage/", "recipeIngredient": ["1 pound (454g) ground chicken (92\u201394% lean)", "3/4 teaspoon salt", "1/2 teaspoon freshly cracked black pepper (1/4 teaspoon if using ground)", "1 teaspoon dried thyme", "1 teaspoon garlic powder", "1/2 teaspoon smoked paprika", "1/2 teaspoon ground sage", "1/2 teaspoon fennel seeds (optional)", "1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg", "3 Tablespoons (45ml) pure maple syrup", "1\u20132 Tablespoons (15\u201330ml)\u00a0olive oil, for cooking", "optional for garnish: fresh thyme &amp; fresh sage"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a large spoon or spatula, mix together all the ingredients except for the oil. It may be easier to use your hands to combine it all. Mixture is sticky.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/maple-chicken-breakfast-sausage/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Heat a large skillet over medium-low heat. Add the olive oil. (If using a nonstick skillet, I find medium heat is better.)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/maple-chicken-breakfast-sausage/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Scoop a portion of the mixture, about 1.5\u20132 Tablespoons (35\u201345g) in size, and drop into the hot pan. Slightly flatten into a patty using the back of a spoon or spatula. Repeat with remaining mixture until you have around 8 patties on the skillet, depending on the skillet&#8217;s size. Don&#8217;t over-crowd the skillet.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/maple-chicken-breakfast-sausage/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cook for 5 minutes, then flip the sausage patties and cook for an additional 3\u20134 minutes, or until cooked through. Set aside to use in step 4.", "name": "Make the streusel first", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-chocolate-coffee-cake/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, baking powder, and salt together in a medium bowl. Set aside. In a large bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and sugar together on medium-high speed until combined and creamy, about 1-2 minutes. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. Add the egg and vanilla extract and beat until combined. Add the dry ingredients and begin beating on low speed. With the mixer running, slowly pour in the buttermilk. Finally, add the chocolate chips. Beat on low until everything is combined. Avoid over-mixing. Using a large spoon or silicone spatula, gently fold in the raspberries. They&#8217;ll break a little bit, but try to be extra careful.", "name": "Make the cake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/raspberry-chocolate-coffee-cake/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spread the batter into the prepared baking pan. That time is a guideline; the cake is done when a toothpick inserted in the middle comes out clean. Using a silicone spatula or wooden spoon, slowly stir in 3 Tablespoons of ice water. You only want to add enough water to bring the dough somewhat together. Using floured fingers or the bottom of a flat and lightly floured measuring cup, press the dough evenly into a 9-inch tart pan. You want it extremely tight in the pan.\u00a0You&#8217;ll need to use pie weights for the next step, so line the crust with aluminum foil or parchment paper and add pie weights.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-tart-toasted-hazelnut-crust/#.3j4zd9aznk.4.3.0.1.1.0.2:$0.2:$s-0"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake (with pie weights) for 18-20 minutes.\u00a0Remove from the oven and place on a\u00a0wire rack so it can slightly cool as you prepare the filling.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/nutella-tart-toasted-hazelnut-crust/#.3j4zd9aznk.4.3.0.1.1.0.2:$0.2:$s-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the cornstarch and 1/2 cup of the heavy cream together in a small bowl. (You want a little cream mixed with the cornstarch to avoid white cornstarch lumps in your filling.) Combine the cornstarch mixture, the rest of the heavy cream, Nutella, and salt into a medium saucepan over medium heat. Whisk to combine all of the ingredients and bring to a boil. While constantly whisking, allow to boil for 3 minutes as it thickens. Dough will be sticky. If it&#8217;s too sticky, add a little more flour. If it seems too dry, add 1-2 more Tablespoons heavy cream. Definitely a keeper (: I made them as the recipe states but with buttermilk instead of cream and with no coarse sugar since I didn't have it, and used more zest in the scones and added zest to the glaze which intensified the flavor even more and made it prettier. I froze the unbaked scones for 15 min per the recipe and they kept their shape. I was worried they wouldn't be rich enough with lowfat buttermilk but they were tender and rich on the inside and crispy on the outside. There's simply no need to take this extra step because the apple pie bakes for a really long time in the oven. If your pies have soggy crusts, you may not be baking them long enough. See <em>How Do I Know When Apple Pie Is Done</em> above. Additionally, and this is important, I strongly recommend using a <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2LJYp1w\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener sponsored nofollow\">glass pie dish</a>. This recipe is also in my cookbook, Sally's Baking 101.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "apple pie", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/slice-of-apple-pie-2-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/slice-of-apple-pie-2-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/slice-of-apple-pie-2-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/slice-of-apple-pie-2.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-pie-recipe/", "recipeIngredient": ["Homemade Pie Crust or All Butter Pie Crust (both recipes make 2 crusts, 1 for bottom and 1 for top)", "10 cups (1250g) 1/4-inch-thick apple slices (about 8 large peeled and cored apples)*", "1/2 cup (100g) granulated sugar (or packed brown sugar)", "1/4 cup (31g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 Tablespoon (15ml) lemon juice", "1 and 1/2 teaspoons ground cinnamon", "1/4 teaspoon ground allspice", "1/4 teaspoon ground nutmeg", "egg wash: 1 large egg beaten with 1 Tablespoon (15ml) milk", "optional: coarse sugar for sprinkling on crust"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Prepare either pie crust recipe through step 5. The pie dough needs to be refrigerated for at least 2 hours before using.", "name": "The crust", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-pie-recipe/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "On a floured work surface, roll out one of the discs of chilled dough (keep the other one in the refrigerator). Turn the dough about a quarter turn after every few rolls until you have a circle 12 inches in diameter. Carefully place the dough into a 9-inch pie dish that&#8217;s 1.5 to 2 inches deep. Tuck the dough in with your fingers, making sure it is smooth. Place the pie shell in the refrigerator while you prepare the filling.", "name": "Roll out the chilled pie dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-pie-recipe/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl, stir the apple slices, sugar, flour, lemon juice, cinnamon, allspice, and nutmeg together until thoroughly combined.\u00a0", "name": "Make the filling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-pie-recipe/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Pour the apple filling into a very large skillet or Dutch oven. Cook over medium heat, stirring gently, until the apples begin to soften, about 5 minutes. Remove from heat and set aside to slightly cool. This step is optional, but I&#8217;ve found it makes for a juicier, more flavorful filling because it helps begin to soften the apples. If you can, take the few extra minutes to do this, because the flavor is worth it!", "name": "Optional pre-cook", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-pie-recipe/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat oven to 400\u00b0F (204\u00b0C).\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-pie-recipe/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Spoon the filling into the crust. It&#8217;s ok if it is still warm from the precooking step. It will seem like a lot of apples; that&#8217;s ok. Pile them high, and tightly together.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-pie-recipe/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove the other disc of chilled pie dough from the refrigerator. Roll the dough into a circle that is 12 inches diameter. Using a pastry wheel, sharp knife, or pizza cutter, cut strips of dough; in the pictured pie, I cut 12 1-inch-wide strips. Carefully thread the strips over and under one another, pulling back strips as necessary to weave. (Here&#8217;s a lattice pie crust tutorial if you need visuals.) Use a small paring knife or kitchen shears to trim off excess dough. Fold the overhang back towards the center of the pie, and pinch the edges to adhere the top and bottom crusts together. Crimp or flute the pie crust edges to seal.", "name": "Finish assembling", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-pie-recipe/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly brush the top of the pie crust with the egg wash. Optional: Refrigerate the pie for 20\u201330 minutes to help set the lattice&#8217;s shape.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-pie-recipe/#instruction-step-8"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake the pie on the middle oven rack for 25 minutes. I recommend placing a baking sheet on the bottom rack to catch any bubbling-over juices. After 25 minutes, keeping the pie in the oven, reduce the oven temperature to 375\u00b0F (190\u00b0C). Add a pie crust shield (see Note for homemade shield) to prevent the edges from over-browning. Continue baking until the pie is golden brown and the filling is bubbling through the lattice, 35\u201345 more minutes. If you want to be precise, the internal temperature of the filling taken with an instant-read thermometer should be around 200\u00b0F (93\u00b0C) when done. Tip: If needed towards the end of bake time, remove the pie crust shield and tent an entire piece of foil on top of the pie if the top looks like it&#8217;s getting too brown.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/apple-pie-recipe/#instruction-step-9"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Remove pie from the oven, place on a cooling rack, and cool for at least 3 hours before slicing and serving. (If it&#8217;s helpful, see this parchment paper rounds for cakes video &amp; post.)", "name": "Increase the oven temperature to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C)", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/my-favorite-carrot-cake-recipe/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl, whisk the brown sugar, granulated sugar, oil, eggs, applesauce, and vanilla until combined and no brown sugar lumps remain.", "name": "Make the cake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/my-favorite-carrot-cake-recipe/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In another large bowl, whisk the flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, cinnamon, ginger, nutmeg, and cloves together. Fold in the carrots and 1 cup (about 120g) of the toasted nuts. (The rest of the nuts are for garnish.) Pour/spoon the batter evenly into the prepared cake pans.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/my-favorite-carrot-cake-recipe/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. If using three cake pans, this takes about 20\u201325 minutes. If using two cake pans, this takes about 30\u201335 minutes. Cool the cakes in the pans set on a cooling rack for 1 hour. Run a knife around the edges to help loosen the sides, remove the cakes from the pans, peel off the parchment, and place on the rack to finish cooling. Allow the cakes to cool completely in the pans set on a cooling rack. The cakes must be completely cool before frosting and assembling.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/my-favorite-carrot-cake-recipe/#instruction-step-5"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a handheld or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the cream cheese and butter together on medium-high speed until smooth, about 2 minutes. Scrape down the sides of the bowl as needed. Add the confectioners\u2019 sugar, vanilla, and a pinch of salt. Beat on low speed for 30 seconds, then increase to high speed and beat for 3 minutes until completely combined and creamy. Add more confectioners\u2019 sugar if frosting is too thin, a little milk if frosting is too thick, or an extra pinch of salt if frosting is too sweet.\u00a0", "name": "Make the frosting:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/my-favorite-carrot-cake-recipe/#instruction-step-6"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "(For extra help with this step, see this video &amp; post on how to assemble a layer cake.) First, using a large serrated knife or cake leveler, slice a thin layer off the top of each cake to create a flat surface. Place a cake layer on your cake turntable, cake stand, or serving plate. Evenly cover the top with 3/4 to 1 cup (180\u2013240g) of the frosting. Top with the second cake layer, upside down, and spread the same amount of frosting as on the first layer. Top with the third layer, right side up, and spread the top and sides with the remaining frosting. Garnish with the remaining toasted nuts. Refrigerate the cake for at least 20 minutes before slicing. This helps the cake hold its shape when cutting. If you refrigerated the cake for longer than 4 hours, take it out of the refrigerator 2 hours before serving so it can mostly come to room temperature.\u00a0", "name": "Assemble the cake", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/my-favorite-carrot-cake-recipe/#instruction-step-7"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Cover leftover cake tightly and store in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/my-favorite-carrot-cake-recipe/#instruction-step-8"}], "prepTime": "PT30M", "cookTime": "PT25M", "totalTime": "PT3H30M", "recipeYield": ["12", "serves 12"], "recipeCategory": "Dessert", "cookingMethod": "Baking", "recipeCuisine": "American", "aggregateRating": {"@type": "AggregateRating", "reviewCount": "702", "ratingValue": "4.8"}, "video": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "VideoObject", "name": "Favorite Carrot Cake | Sally's Baking Recipes", "description": "With its outstanding spice flavor, super moist crumb, and velvety cream cheese frosting, this is truly the best carrot cake. Cover and allow to sit for 5 minutes. *If you don\u2019t have a stand mixer,\u00a0simply use a large mixing bowl and mix the dough with a wooden spoon or silicone spatula in the next step.", "name": "Prepare the dough", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-everything-bagels/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Add the flour, brown sugar, and salt. Beat on low speed for 2 minutes. The dough is very stiff and will look somewhat dry.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-everything-bagels/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Keep the dough in the mixer and beat for an additional 6-7 full minutes, or knead by hand on a lightly floured surface for 6-7 full minutes. (If you\u2019re new to bread-baking, my\u00a0How to Knead Dough\u00a0video tutorial can help here.) If the dough becomes too sticky during the kneading process, sprinkle 1 teaspoon of flour at a time on the dough or on the work surface/in the bowl to make a soft, slightly tacky dough. Do not add more flour than you need because you do not want a dry dough. After kneading, the dough should still feel a little soft. Poke it with your finger\u2014if it slowly bounces back, your dough is ready to rise. You can also do a \u201cwindowpane test\u201d to see if your dough has been kneaded long enough: tear off a small (roughly golfball-size) piece of dough and gently stretch it out until it\u2019s thin enough for light to pass through it. Hold it up to a window or light. Does light pass through the stretched dough without the dough tearing first? If so, your dough has been kneaded long enough and is ready to rise. If not, keep kneading until it passes the windowpane test.", "name": "Knead the dough:\u00a0", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/homemade-everything-bagels/#instruction-step-3"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Lightly grease a large bowl with oil or nonstick spray. Press your index finger through the center of each ball to make a hole about 1.5 &#8211; 2 inches in diameter. Watch video below for a visual. Full-fat sour cream is the secret to their tender softness.", "author": {"@type": "Person", "name": "Sally", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/about-sally-mckenney/"}, "keywords": "cakey sugar cookies", "image": ["https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/pink-frosted-sugar-cookies-225x225.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/pink-frosted-sugar-cookies-260x195.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/pink-frosted-sugar-cookies-320x180.jpg", "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/pink-frosted-sugar-cookies.jpg"], "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-cakey-sugar-cookies/", "recipeIngredient": ["3 cups (375g) all-purpose flour\u00a0(spooned &amp; leveled)", "1 teaspoon baking powder", "1/2 teaspoon baking soda", "1/2 teaspoon salt", "1 cup (16 Tbsp; 226g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature", "1 and 1/2 cups (300g) granulated sugar", "2 large eggs, at room temperature", "1 cup (240g) full-fat sour cream, at room temperature", "2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract", "1/2 teaspoon almond extract", "vanilla buttercream\u00a0and sprinkles for decorating*"], "recipeInstructions": [{"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Whisk the flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt together. Set aside.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-cakey-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-1"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "In a large bowl using a hand mixer or stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, beat the butter and granulated sugar together on high speed until smooth and creamy, about 2 minutes. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl with a rubber spatula as needed.\u00a0Add the eggs, sour cream, vanilla extract, and almond extract. Beat on medium-high speed until combined. The mixture may look curdled; that&#8217;s ok. Scrape down the sides and up the bottom of the bowl as needed. With the mixer on low speed, mix in the dry ingredients until combined. The dough will be very thick, creamy, and silky.\u00a0Cover dough tightly with aluminum foil or plastic wrap and chill for 1 hour and up to 2-3 days.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-cakey-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-2"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Preheat the oven to 350\u00b0F (177\u00b0C). Arrange 3 inches apart on the baking sheets.", "url": "https://sallysbakingaddiction.com/soft-cakey-sugar-cookies/#instruction-step-4"}, {"@type": "HowToStep", "text": "Bake for 13-14 minutes or until a cookie\u00a0springs back when lightly poked with your finger. Pour the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients, add the hot water, and whisk or beat it all until the batter is completely combined. I weigh out all my  dry ingredients instead of using measuring cups, and just love the fact you list weight measurements in the recipe. I made two small deviations from the recipe, one is that I was a tiny bit short on natural cocoa powder so I added 13 grams of dutch processed cocoa powder to make up the difference, but such a miniscule amount didn't affect the end product at all... also, using a 1A piping tip I piped in the cheesecake filling instead of spooning it in... I think piping it in worked fine, but using that tip I had to go around the pan more than once, so it was a little trickier making sure none touched the sides of the pan, but I managed it just fine. At 53 minutes I pulled the cake out and it was cooked to perfection, but I have a feeling your oven must be quite similar to mine as your cooking times are always spot on for me. All in all I ended up with a cake that looked exactly like the picture and that really was pretty easy to put together. I'm disabled and was able to make this reasonably easily so it's a win on that front. My husband is definitely wanting me to make this again and we both really really like the chocolate flavor in this cake as well as the cheesecake filling.
